column2: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9-- Consecutive home runs, a triple steal and an easy victory for Roger Craig helped bring the most successful road trip in New York Met history to a joyous conclusion today as the Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6--3.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 9 --A "freedom school" for pupils who have been boycotting a predominantly Negro school in the Malverne School District was started here today at the Unitarian-Universalist Church of Central Nassau.
The stock market bounced around in undecided fashion yesterday. Prices went up, down, up again and then down again, closing moderately down.
Despite a two-month shut down of a copper mine, the Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd., raised sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30.

A room-count standard that may guide apartment hunters confused by floor plans that include balconies, foyers and other open space in the total number of rooms has been published by the Real Estate Board of New York.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP)--A Federal judge today ordered Dr. George Anderson, a Negro, to return to Albany, Ga., to face a conspiracy charge.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9--Government troops inflicted heavy losses today on the Communist guerrillas in savage fighting in the Mekong Delta. The fighting was still going on tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--The Senate Commerce Committee discussed today a plan to provide direct remedies through the courts for Negroes who are denied union membership because of their race.
Leaders of the United Federation of Teachers asserted yesterday that the new contract worked out with the Board of Education would set a pattern for bargaining efforts by teachers across the nation.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9--George Low Farnsworth, executive vice president in charge of the international division of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, died today in Huntington Hospital after a long illness. His age was 50.
Ely A. Landau, who less than one week ago had three independent films scheduled for immediate production, announced changes of directors yesterday that involve all three of them.

Whereas, the threat of forced and unwarranted integration of the public schools of this state is detrimental to the public interest; and, Whereas, integration of the public schools will totally disrupt and effectively destroy the educational process and constitutes an abridgement of the civil rights of other children attending the schools...

A sixth-grade pupil yesterday stabbed a 54-year-old woman teacher on the opening day of school at P.S. 261 in downtown Brooklyn. The police said later he had told them he did not know why he had done it.

The first liquor control official to be convicted on a criminal charge since the investigation into the statewide scandal began more than a year ago received a suspended sentence yesterday of one and a half to two and a half years in Sing Sing Prison.

WASHINGTON Sept. 10 A strategy hastily devised at the White House between 10 o'clock last night and dawn led to the successful integration of several Alabama schools today without reliance upon "a Federal presence."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) Sandy Koufax set a National League strike-out record and Wally Moon slammed a decisive two-run homer as the leagueleading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-2, tonight.

Title to a newly remodeled seven-story office building with one store at 7 West 44th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has been taken by clients of Jacob Bernstein for cash over a mortgage of $118,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Following is a summary of the main features of the tax bill approved today by the House Ways and Meats Committee:
The American Merchant Marine Library Association, which has distributed nearly 14,000,000 books in 43 years, will open its annual book week on Oct. 1.

Governor Rockefeller's campaign promise last fall that he would not increase taxes in the whole four years of his second term was a mistake that has dogged him ever since. He repeated the promise right up to Election Day Nov. 6. Within three months he had broken it with a budget message requesting a $105 million "fee" increase that was taxation by euphemism.

PARIS, Sept. 10--The principal financial officials of the European Common Market agreed today that solution of the United States balance of payments problem should take priority over the development of new international payments machinery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The United States has apologized to Ghana for the beating of three Ghanaian college students by a gang of white men near Tuscaloosa, Ala., Sunday night.
GROSSE POINT, Mich., Sept. 10 The Oldsmobile division of General Motors introduced a hybrid car series today as its new entry for 1964.

The Actors' Gallery, 414 West Broadway, was found guilty yesterday of presenting theatrical performances without a license. Judge Evelyn Richman, in Municipal Term Part of Criminal Court, suspended sentence.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 President Kennedy has asked the American people to be "patient" about Vietnam, but it would be nice to know what we ars being asked to be patient about.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 10 The second race of the world championship sailing in the 5.5Meter Class could not be sailed within the four-hour time limit today because the wind wasn't strong enough to give the flame of a candle a good fight.
Price changes all on the up side were announced yesterday in a number of industries. Most of them were in the pulp and paper industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A dragging, poorly attended Senate debate on the nuclear test ban treaty was momentarily enlivened today when Senator John O. Pastore made an impassioned plea to "the doubters" to resolve their doubts in favor of ratification.

Former President Harry S. Truman disclosed yesterday that he had turned down an offer to review "My Reminiscences," the memoirs of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur sold recently to Life magazine.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept, 10 (AP) Mrs. Katherine Price's Carry Back, continuing his comeback after a stay on the breeding farm, heads a field of 10 named today for the $125,000 United Nations Handicap at the Atlantic City race course Saturday.
Gerardo A, (Jerry) Re and his son, Gerard F., were sentenced yesterday in United States District Court to serve six months in prison and to pay $15,000 fines in a multimilliondollar stock swindle.
The appointment of a committee to study proposed changes in the rules of the New York County Republican Committee was announced yesterday by Vincent F. Albano Jr., county chairman.

New York City borrowed $25,550,000 on housing bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 3.6621 per cent. The bonds went to First National City Bank and associates and the group reoffered the bonds at prices to yield 2 to 3.65 per cent on 1964 to 2012 maturities. All but $5,530,000 of the bonds was sold yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 10 Denmark's Premier Jens Otto Krag warned today that a protectionist European Common Market could create "a serious situation for countries like Denmark and Austria that need access to European markets."

IS this a Spanish omelet?" Mrs. David Sandeman asked a New York waiter recently as he set a red, yellow and green mixture before her. Receiving an affirmative answer, she tactfully refrained from further comment.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 10 (UPI) An unarmed Air America plane on a rice-dropping mission over central Laos with three Americans and four Laotuns aboard was shot down in flames by pro-Communist Pathet Lao antiaircraft guns, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--The House of Representatives approved today a $238,000,000 program to combat mental retardation. The vote was 335 to 18.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Sept. 10 (AP) Willie Heston, a University of Michigan football hero, died last night in Munson Hospital here on his 85th birthday. He played halfback on coach Fielding H. (Hurry Up) Yost's "point a minute"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and Mayor Joseph M. Barr of Pittsburgh called on the Federal Government today to get behind a move to clean up the air.
Sophia Loren has been signed as guide for a television tour of Rome, for which she will receive at least $100,000.

THE red carpet was rolled out yesterday at Lord Taylor for a queen. The store had been chosen by the State Department to entertain Queen Homaira of Afghanistan at luncheon, during which an informal fashion show emphasizing the American look was put on. Following the luncheon, the Queen toured the store.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 President Kennedy signed an Executive order today that had the effect of halting the draft of married men into the armed forces. The order affects the draft status of 340,000 men.
The bond market was active yesterday. Prices advanced, except in the municipal sector.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 Premier Khrushchev is now being referred to in Peking without any pretense of civility. He is being assailed in the same breath with such "arch-enemies" of Communist China as the leaders of the United States, Yugoslavia and India.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 10 Nearly 2,000 scientists have spent the last nine days her a laying the groundwork for what may be a dramatic change in the future of mankind.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation offered yesterday to purchase 47 per cent of the Garrett Corporation for $35,000,000.

Jerry Re swindled millions of dollars out of friends and strangers impartially through slick stock frauds over the last 45 years, doing it half of that time under the nose of Federal regulatory agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission concluded in 1961.

Controller Abraham D. Beame predicted last night that the city would not need new taxes to balance the 1964-65 budget--even with improvements in services--if it "gets reasonable adjustments in state aid."
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10 The lavishness and lushness of Cynthia Phipps's debutante party yesterday has left society a bit impressed and slightly surprised.
BISMARCK, N.D., Sept. 10 Discrimination against Indians comparable to that against Negroes was reported by an Indian leader today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 10 A 34-year-old Afghan named Niamatullah Maroof, who comes from Kabul, discussed educational problems today with a 10-year-old American named Rosalie Winard, who comes front Larchmont.
THE deal today comes from the American Bridge Digest, latest entry among the world's many bridge magazines, which is published in California. The deal occured ...

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 10 Howard Anthony Smith of 212 St. Clair Avenue, a former executive vice president of the American Express Company and former chairman of the board of governors of Rutgers University, died today in a nursing home at Manasquan. He was 75 years old.

Many New York City taxi drivers have been puzzling their passengers lately by asking, "Do you happen to smoke Paxton cigarettes?" When the passengers reply the cabbies simply shrug and go back to their driving.
The House Ways and Means Committee came to the aid of the stock market yesterday.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept.10 An academic institution better known for smashing atoms than for creating sculpture hopes to cause a stir in Parisian art circles this fall.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 10 The Yankees' gay dash to the pennant was slowed down again tonight as the Kansas City Athletics defeated them for the second straight time, 2 0.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept.10 Local government in California was indicted today for what was called an appalling failure to protect communities from beauty-destroying land usage.
Three airframe manufacturers and three engine manufacturers have informed the Government that they will submit designs for the proposed United States supersonic airliner.

PORTLAND, Ores, Sept.10 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will picket Local 8 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union Friday despite plans to include Negroes in a planned registration of 300 additional longshoremen.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 10 A tall, striking wo man with piercing dark brown eyes is almost always in the courtroom eye of the hurricane surrounding the struggle for civil rights throughout the South.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A modified version of President Kennedy's tax program emerged from the House Ways and Means Committee today. The vote was 17 to 8.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz will go to Ottawa tomorrow to explore solutions to a labor controversy that threatens to strain relations betweeen the United States and Canada.

LONDRINA, Brazil, Sept.10--A United States Air Force Hercules transport delivered food today to the people of fire-ravaged Parana State. This was part of a major United States relief operation in response to a disaster. It was reliably estimated that 80 persons had died in the fire.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UPI) Most grain futures rallied sharply to post firm to strong gains today on the Board of Trade.

The big rush of oil companies to gain a foothold in the mushrooming fertilizer industry continues apace. The Gulf Oil Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to acquire the Spencer Chemical Company, Kansas City, Mo.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Sept. 10 Tuskegee High School desegregated without incident today.
Fletcher J. (Joe) Perry broke into professional football with the San Francisco Forty-Niners of the defunct All-America Conference in 1948.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 Racially inspired marches on City Hall and the Federal Courthouse by opposing groups were being planned here today.
EASTON, Pa., Sept. 10 Ken Bunn, Lafayette's new head football coach, seems to be feeling his way around.

The United States chemical industry was warned yesterday not to expect much in special exemptions from reductions in tariffs. The warning was delivered by a key member of the Administration's team for next year's negotiations with the Common Market.
The American Civil Liberties Union is supporting Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi in his demand for a jury trial on criminal contempt charges against him.
LAST winter, in front of peat fires in the Aran Islands and Donegal, women were knitting sweaters that American college girls and matrons will be buying this fall.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 10 A boycott of a predominantly Negro elementary school continued here today as-more than 900 or the 955 children registered stayed away.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 An Ocean City man today was granted an injunction to stop the Atlantic City race course from paying off a $51,225 twin double on a $2 bet he says he gave a friend to bet for him.

ROME, Sept. 10 The Italian state oil agency, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, announced today the signing of an accord with the United Arab Republic to explore for oil and develop production in the area of the Nile River Delta and the Zeit (Kalig) region along the African coast of the Gulf of Suez.
SANA, Yemen, Sept. 10 The year-old civil war in Yemen appears to be settling into a stalemate that could last for years.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 Tiffany Co. opened a store here today. Fittingly perhaps symbolically it is above a bank.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 10 (AP) Dr. Claude M. Fuess, headmaster of Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass., from 1933 until 1948, died last night after a long illness. He was 78 years old.
Robert Moses gave the back of his hand to critics of the 1964-1965 New York World's Fair and to the Bureau of International Expositions yesterday.

CORNWALL-on-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 10 Tom Gola, one of the most respected men in basketball, believes that "speed and desire" should be the objectives of the New York Knicks in the 1963-64 National Basketball Association season.
LIDO BEACH, L.I., Sept. 10--Donnell (Buck) Adams of Winston-Salem, N.C., today came within inches of giving the Lido Golf Club's course record its second beating in two days.
MOBILE, Ala,, Sept. 10 Two Negroes entered Murphy High School today without opposition from the 2,777 white students.
WHEN William Faulkner died in July of 1962 his reputation was at its height. He had won a Nobel prize. He was read and admired and imitated by younger writers in many countries.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept, 10 (AP) The American Legion charged today that Federal agencies had been directed to hire persons without regard to civil service and veterans' preference rules.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Following are the texts issued today of the Presidential proclamation forbidding interference with integration in Alabama and the Exective order authorizing the nationalizing of the Alabama National Guard:

A novel about a Jewish boy who was kidnapped in New York by his Roman Catholic tutor and taken to Canada, where he became a priest, may not be issued because of objections by members of the Catholic clergy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 10-- Eric H. Louw, Foreign Minister, denounced three leading members of the Kennedy Administration tonight, implying that they were responsible for increasing United States criticism of South Africa's policy of apartheid, or separation of races.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 The scene has changed sharply in South Vietnam since the conflict between the Government and the Buddhists erupted four months ago.
Edward Albee has stipulated that a touring company's version of his drama, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," be presented in South Africa only before desegregated audiences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department estimated today that this year's production of corn would reach a new high of 3,938,720,000 bushels. Wheat production was set at 1,134,051,000 bushels in the department's early-harvest report.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 10 (AP) Hall Thomas McGee, former vice president and general manager of The Charleston Evening Post and The News and Courier, died today. He was 74 years old.
New rules aimed at curbing some abuses of real estate syndicates were announced yesterday by the State Attorney General's office.
An aviation consultant described the country's transportation network yesterday as "a sprawling, expensive, uncoordinated, unmanageable mess."
Prices receded again on the London stock market, but most individual losses were small in light trading.
Whatever it was, it made musical history, from 6 P.M. Monday to 12:40 P.M. yesterday at the Pocket Theater, 100 Third Avenue near 13th Street.
MONICA MORALES-SCHILDT is a glass designer who multiplies the optical illusions inherent in cut blocks of plain crystal by sandwiching intense colors between layers of clear glass.
ONE of the most exciting moments for this observer at least at Judson Hall last night, where "Five Queens" opened, was off stage and not on.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10 A new state law that requires lawyers to pay a registration fee of $15 was attacked today in State Supreme Court here as unconstitutional.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Sept. 10 (Reuters) An explosion injured seven African children today during a news conference given at the airport here by Arthur Goldreich and Harold Wolpe, refugees from South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- President Kennedy's policy on South Vietnam, ruling out a reduction in aid "at this time," was described today as intentionally flexible.
The Transit Authority took a dim view yesterday of the Transport Workers Union's aim to obtain a $100,000,000 package increase in its new contract.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 10 Stokeley W. Morgan, a former State Department official who lived here in retirement, died today in Nantucket Cottage Hospital. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Soviet Union has an nounced an offer of "ample" economic aid to British Guiana to break "the imperialist blockade" against the regime of Premier Cheddi B. Jagan.
OSLO, Norway, Sept. 10 Vice President Johnson ended his goodwill visit to Finland today on a note of apparent success.
Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians has changed the basic method of financing the union.
PARIS, Sept. 10 Premier Georges Pompidou outlined today the Government's "stabilization plan" intended to check the inflation that is weakening the French economy.
The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers called yesterday for the indictment and arrest of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.
Justice Francis Bergan was nominated last night by the state committee of the Liberal party as the party's candidate for associate judge of the Court of Appeals.
Twenty-four hours after they started the academic year in a new school building, 600 Bronx pupils were attending makeshift classes yesterday in another school.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10--The Actor's Workshop and Stanford University have broken off negotiations aimed at establishing a theatrical production organization as a part of the university.
Possible state controls over the drinking habits of individuals are being studied by the Moreland Act Commission.
DES MOINES, Sept. 10 Labron Harris Jr. played relaxed golf today as he scored decisively in the second round of the National Amateur championship.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 10 Twenty Negroes attended previously white schools in three Alabama cities today after President Kennedy's federalization of the state's, National Guardsmen ended the defiance of Gov. George C. Wallace.
BRIGGS CUNNINGHAM will have a three of the new lightweight Jaguar XKE's in the 500-kilometer race for Grand Touring cars at the Bridgehampton, L.I., course on Saturday.
YONKERS, Sept. 10 It could be that Meadow Skipper, purchased less than three months ago by Norman Woolworth from Hugh Grant for some $80,000, will have "won himself out" by 10 o'clock Thursday night.
Black Mountain, Joseph M. Roebling's undefeated 2-yearold colt, did everything wrong at Aqueduct yesterday except one thing. He didn't forget the way to the winner's circle.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept.10 Christ Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katrina Farnham Windisch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Windisch, to Patrick E. Cooper.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages unless otherwise noted.

After seven years of confusion and controversy, the Cadman Plaza site in downtown Brooklyn was turned over by the city yesterday to builders who will erect co-operative apartment houses costing $23,400,000.

Foote, Cone Belding, Inc., went public yesterday. The first among the nation's top 10 advertising agencies to do so, it is now one of the few publicly owned agencies in the country. The shares were sold by the officers and did not represent new financing.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 10 (UPI)--Representative Charles A. Vanik called today for an investigation of reports that Senator Barry Goldwater and other politicians flew to Cleveland for a political rally yesterday in planes owned by the Timken Roller Bearing Company of Canton, Ohio.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept., 10 (UPI) A Federal court jury found for the defendants today in a $600,000 damage suit stemming from student expulsions and teacher dismissals at the predominantly Negro Kentucky State College in 1960.
New York City staged a reception fit for a king yesterday. The guest of honor, King Mohammad Zahir of Afghanistan, responded with warmth and informality.
ROME, Sept. 10 (AP) A private audience that Pope Paul VI had ben scheduled to give to the brother of President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam was called off today.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 10 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk proposed today that new talks with the Soviet Union be held on a wide range of subjects. He warned at the same time that the Soviet presence in Cuba remained "a major obstacle" to normal relations with Moscow.
MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 10 Three Negroes were arrested tonight for staging a sit-in after a school board meeting in Malverne Junior High School broke up in a dispute over racial imbalances.
HENRI BENDEL, the staid specialty store that has been revamped in the image of its ex-fashion editor president, has a new crop of all-its-own clothes.
MOSCOW, Sept.10 A secretpolice official called today for the extension of powers of the citizens' courts to curb petty speculation.

Carlyle Hodgkinson, a director and large stockholder of the Bank of Smithtown, Smithtown, L.I., said yesterday he had never favored an abandoned proposal for sale of the bank to the Marine Midland Corporation.
ALGIERS, Sept. 10--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella called on his critics today to join him and his party to "work together for the common good."

AN extraordinary exhibition opens today at the Museum of Modern Art when 40 canvases by Hans Hofmann, the Grand Old Man of abstract expressionism and the foster father of much avant-garde American art, go on view.
Cocoa fell and coffee and sugar futures were irregular in active trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Cuba said today that the Soviet Union had warned the United States that further raids on Cuba by exiles "will not bed tolerated." Moscow was said to have warned that such raids might again push the world "to the brink of a thermonuclear war."
A drug that promises new freedom to physicians in the treatment of chronic pain was described here yesterday to the American Chemical Society.

ALBANY, Sept, 10 State Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, called upon the Republican-controlled Legislature today to order an impartial and professional review of Governor Rockefeller's financing methods.

UNLIKE politicians, who concede elections when the trend becomes obvious, baseball managers concede nothing. "I still pick the Giants to win the pennant," said Alvin Dark, their indomitable skipper. "I still think we have a chance."
A $25,000,000 suit was filed against the Federal Government yesterday by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (UPI) Stan Musial and Bob Gibson, a pitcher, hit homers and drove in three runs apiece tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to their second straight shutout victory over the Chicago Cubs, 8 0.
Shareholders of the American Agricultural Chemical Company and the Continental Oil Company approved yesterday the sale of Agrico's assets to a Conoco subsidiary.
A BANDIT who separated a Bronx milkman from his money the other day used a crossbow as an instrument of persuasion.
Leslie Abraham Hyam, president of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, was found dead yesterday morning in his automobile outside his country home in Cancan, Conn. He was 62 years old.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 10 (UPI) Gov. George C. Wallace said today he would obey Federal court orders restraining him from interfering with racial integration in Alabama schools. He said he could not "fight bayonets with my bare hands."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 Britain told the Security Council today that Southern Rhodesia was "enjoying a period of enviable tranquility" and denied African charges that the transfer of powerful armed forces to Southern Rhodesia would constitute a threat to international peace.

Frederick Hainfeld Jr., president of the Long Island Trust Company, Garden City, L.I., disclosed yesterday that he had asked Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon, to block further expansion into the suburbs of the First National City Bank, New York.
A BANDIT who separated a Bronx milkman from his money the other day used a crossbow as an instrument of persuasion.
The Presidents and deans of 34 major colleges and universities in 21 states urged the Senate yesterday to ratify the nuclear test ban treaty.
LONDON, Sept.10 A spokesman for the Martha Graham dance company, now appearing here, rejected tonight the criticism of a Congresswoman who said the troupe's ballet "Phaedra" was "erotic."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 Troops removed the students from five more Saigon high schools today in an attempt to prevent new protests. Some of the schools were occupied by the soldiers.
Overflow crowds applauded the opening of New York's first film festival yesterday at Lincoin Center for the Performing Arts and the Museum of Modern Art.
The Board of Education bowed to a court ruling yesterday and enrolled 51 white chitdren at a Brooklyn school that has indirectly figured in an integration controversy.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 10 Dartmouth's chances of repeating as Ivy League football championship rose yesterday when it was learned that Tom Spangenberg would resume practice later this week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--A suit that could determine the constitutionality of Federal and State aid to church--related schools and colleges was filed today in Maryland.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 10 Al Scheinkler didn't throw his No. 7 iron into the air today, until the 18th hole.

Long Island is a key area of New York, and one of its most articulate spokesmen is the Franklin National Bank. For 30 months, Long Island has enjoyed a bustling economy and, at present, the bank says "major economic indicators still point to an uptrend."

Governor Wallace finally achieved what he had been seeking for a week--Federal intervention. President Kennedy, after exercising monumental forbearance in the hope that the clear will of Alabama's own citizens would make their Governor cease his reckless defiance of law, had no choice but to use his powers to enforce Federal court orders for school integration in Birmingham, Mobile and Tuskegee.
Support for preparatory schools has reached a new high, with five gifts of $1,000,000 or more pledged since Jan. 1, a financial consultant to colleges and secondary schools said yesterday.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., continued to set new records in sales in the second quarter. Earnings also improved in the second quarter after a first-quarter dip which resulted in lower profits for the first half of the current fiscal year.
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 10 On the eve of its annual conference, Britain's Liberal party called tonight for an early general election.
Suddenly unrecognizably ferocious, the rampaging New York Mets scored their fourth victory in their last five games last night by routing the San Francisco Giants, 4-2, at the Polo Grounds.
A transcontinental tug of war has developed between the Garrett Corporation of Los Angeles and the Curtiss-Wright Corpoation of Wood-Ridge, N. J.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 11-- Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Army Chief of Staff, told the American Legion today that the United States was prepared to meet the "military thread aimed at the free world by the Communuist bloc."

Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver Jr., advertising and television executive, has been named president and chief executive officer of Subscription Television, Inc., a pay-TV company that hopes to begin operating next year in California.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)--A bill to tighten laws governing Americans who lobby for foreign governments or business interests has been introiduced by J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Faculty members of the City University are expected to receive pay increases totaling about $2,500,000 as a result of the raises that public school teachers will get here over the next two years.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The State Board of Education today sharply criticized local school boards that have continued to authorize school ceremonies that include Bible-reading and The Lord's Prayer.

Suburban bankers are up in arms. Their complaint is that Federal and state regulatory authorities are letting the big New York City banks invade the suburbs willy nilly, opening bank branches as if they were gasoline stations.

Buoyed by the announcement that Japanese exports reached a postwar high in August, prices climbed sharply on the Tokyo Stock Market. Investors received further encouragement from reports that the Bank of Japan and the Finance Ministry did not intend to tighten Japan's financial policies.

Handling the top burden of 125 pounds with little trouble, William Haggin Perry's Lamb Chop won the $29,750 Gazelle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by a length and threequaters. Ridden by Braulio Baeza, Lamb Chop beat 11 rivals in the 1 1/8-mile race for 3-year-old fillies. Her nearest pursuer was Delhi Maid. Next came Smart Deb, a neck farther back.

Price changes were announced yesterday on both consumer and industrial products. Publication printing papers went up, as did glycerine and industrial belting. Suggested retail prices on blenders were cut.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)--An executive of United Press International testified today that "under no circumstances would we favor any Government subsidy" to reduce the burden of proposed communications rate increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- An agreement is shaping up on a compromise solution of the hotly debated issue of "international liquidity." The compromise is expected at next month's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
Mayor Wagner announced at 4:05 A.M. today that the Board of Estimate had arrived at "a major decision" on the Breezy Point Park project in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Air Force Association expressed concern today that the Administration was adopting a "nuclear stalemate" strategy that would provide an "open invitation" to Soviet aggression.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11--More than the usual crowd gathered today on the platform of the Yaroslavl railroad station here to await train No. 7, the Peking-Moscow express.

THE vast mainland of Communist China is often de picted on maps in bright red, but a stubborn Chinese Nationalist general insists that the color belies the sympathies of most of his 700,000,000 countrymen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)--A House Committee endorsed today an agreement by railroad labor and management that would reduce the take-home pay of many employes and increase company expenses.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Administration's tax bill faced a week's delay in the House of Representatives today as Republicans pressed a drive to add an antispending provision.

A 25-year-old impostor who taught for almost a year in a Long Island high school although he himself had little more than a high school education pleaded guilty yesterday to obtaining employment fraudulently.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept, 11 --The reaction to public school desegregation in four Alabama cities ranged today from continuing boycotts by white students to peaceful acceptance.
GALILEE, R.I., Sept. 11-- The annual United States Atlantic Tuna TOurnament began this morning under Conditions as salubrious as they have ever been in the 21 times the derby has been held.
New Haven came to New York this week in an attempt to get New Yorkers to go to New Haven.
The Booth Fisheries Corporation has ended merger talks with the United Fruit Company and is now being courted by the Consolidated Foods Corporation.
Ground has just been broken for a chapel within the walls of the Eastern Correctional Institution at Napanoch, N. Y. The building is to be paid for with 100,000 books of trading stamps.
YONKERS, Sept. 11--The William H. Cane Futurity Pace, piece de resistance of the Westchester County harness racing year, is expected to draw 30,000 fans to Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 10--British and French diplomats and high-ranking church officials protested to the Israeli Government today over yesterday's demonstrations by Jewish religious zealots against Christian mission schools.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 11--The United States supported Britain today in opposing Security Council action to press for a revision of Southern Rhodesia's status.
Archbishop Ngo Dinh Thuc, brother of President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, arrived unexpectedly from Rome yesday and said he would confer with Cardinal Spellman.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11-- Rear Adm. Alberto Teisaire, vice president during the last year of the reign of Juan Peron died early today. He was 72 years old.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI)--Perris, a graduate of the claiming ranks, scored a surprise neck victory today in the $96,200 Del Mar Futurity.
Igor Gorin, the Ukrainianborn baritone who made his recital debut here in 1941, will make his debut with the New York City Opera on Oct. 5 in the title role of Verdi's "Rigoletto."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The House of Representatives approved without dissent today a full-scale investigation into the scope, conduct and progress of the Government's research programs, which will cost 14,900,000,000 this year.

The award of a $130,000,000 contract to a GermanFrench group for construction of a large oil refinery and pipelines in Iran was announced yesterday.
Plans for two experimental centers to help narcotics addicts break the habit were announced yesterday by the National Association for the Prevention of Addiction to Narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--President Kennedy said today that he did not favor military action against Cuba. Such action was suggested by the American Legion at its convention in Miami.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 --A family counseling service for well-to-do residents of Westchester will open here on Monday.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 12 --Amherst's Lord Jeffs, who captured the Little Three crown while compiling an over-all 7--1 won-lost record a year ago, may do as well again this year if Coach Jim Ostendarp solves one or two problems.

Work on the city's second new ship terminal in the $40, 000,000 Lower East River waterfront redevelopment program will get under way immediately, Leo Brown, Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation, said yes terday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- President Kennedy said today that he doubted that Pakistan would make a military alliance with Communist China because such a step would disrupt her treaty ties with the West.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 12 --Aladar Olgyay, Hungarianborn architect, who specialized in designing houses to fit the climate, died Tuesday in Princeton Hospital, after a short illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 87 Deer Path.
Mayor's Wagner's political allies in Brooklyn received a setback last night from forces controlled by the borough's regular Democratic leader, Assemblyman Stanley Steingut.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 7, which included the Labor Day holiday, was 2.7 per cent ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1962.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12-- Two suits seeking to force the Malverne school Board to implement a plan by the State Education Commissioner to end racial imbalance in the school district were dismissed in State Supreme Court here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Leaders of Southern communities where schools have been racially integrated this month drew high praise today from President Kennedy.

WHEN the Giants meet the Colts in Baltimore on Sunday in their opening game of the National Football League season, the principals with whom the New Yorkers must contend are John Unitas, the quarterback, and Gino Marchetti, the defensive left end.

Like so many things that involve the New York Mets, Duke Snider Night had an element of beautiful illogic to it. Admirers of the silver-haired outfielder crowded into the Polo Grounds last night to honor an authentic baseball hero in a far from perfectly appropriate setting.

Discriminatory tariffs of West European trade blocs were cited yesterday as an increasing obstacle to the reduction of the United States' large international payments deficit.

America's most spectacular "growth" industry in the last quarter-century has been scientific research and development. It still is, Government spending--for defense, space research, efforts to conquer disease and a multitude of other purposes--has been the chief force propelling this growth. A plan that would permit Negro longshoremen to work on the luxury liner piers on the Hudson River in more than token numbers was reported under consideration yesterday.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 17 (UPI)--Supporters of the Uganda People's Congress demonstrated outside the United State Embassy tonight to protest the racial killings in Alabama.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 17--India, has instructed her High Commissioner in Karachi to "press Pakistan to desist from disturbing the peace" on the East Pakistan-Assam border, Prime Minister Jawaharal Nehru said today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept.17 --"It [the bombings] would stop if people would quit waving Confederate flags and other things like that."
At 7:45 this morning in Green Bay, Wis., Vince Lombardi will start downtown with his teen-age daughter, Susan.
Ten church leaders will go to Washington today to ask Congressional leaders and possibly President Kennedy for swift passage of civil rights legislation.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 17--Fred Gronauer of Sleepy Hollow today paced 35 Westchester district golfers who qualified for the metropolitan open golf championship to be played Sept. 25 to 27 at Plainfieid, N.J.

QUEBEC, Sept. 17--No general increase in dividend rates at savings and loan assocations in New York City is likely for at least three months and possibly six, despite increases at many savings banks scheduled for Oct. 1.

The Tokyo stock market resumed its recovery yesterday after a one-day decline as the Dow-Jones average for the main market broke through the 1,400 mark for the first time in a month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Both profits and sales of the nation's manufacturing corporations soared to new highs in the second quarter of this year. It was considerably more of a rise than would normally be expected for seasonal reasons alone.

President Kennedy's television appeal tonight to enlist public support for tax reductions has been long overdue. He could have gained backing for speedy action on his original program of reduction and reform if he had mounted a vigorous public campaign from its inception.
A DRIVE through the countryside these days of golden foliage is fraught with temptation to stop and shop.
A couple of Met pinch hitters --Joe Hicks and Frank Thomas --slammed homers last night. These were the first Met pinch homers of the season.

The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad has completed the second installment of a refunding operation it undertook this summer to meet the maturity of $34,065,000 general unified 4 per cent bonds due June 1, 1964.
A group of men and women who regard retirement as an opportunity to develop neglected interests or to discover new ones met yesterday at the New School for Social Research.

Nothing sends Madison Avenue into a bigger flap than the news that a major advertising account is "on the loose." The latest account to cause an uproar is Eastern Air Lines, Inc., whose advertising has been handled by Fletcher Richards, Calkins Holden, Inc., for nearly two decades.

Bobbie Brooks, Inc., Cleveland manufacturer of women's apparel, reported yesterday a net income for the quarter ended July 31 of $1,234,500, equal to 39 cents a share.

Golf won't be the same, if the rules are followed, for Americans and the British in 1964. The two lawmaking bodies, the United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient of St. Andrews, Scotland, have failed to agree on a worldwide code. WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- The most powerful Senate opponent of the nuclear test ban treaty, Richard B. Russell, took the floor today to denounce it as a "step toward unilateral disarmament."
Treasury bills declined a basis point in price yesterday as the market lined up with the higher yield level established at Monday's auction of new bills. Trading was light.

The Port of New York Authority plans to sell soon at public offering as much as $50,000,000 of consolidated bonds to be in its 24th series.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 17 --Herman M. Pekarsky, executive director of the Jewish Community Council of Essex County, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 2 Washington Park. He was 56 years old.

By a 10-vote margin, musicians rejected last night a contract offer from producers and called a strike that could close all Broadway shows this week. The vote was 166 to 156.

The Yankees announced yesterday they were accepting ticket orders for the World Series games to be played at Yankee Stadium. A limited number of box and reserved seats will go on sale immediately, by mall only. There will be no overthe-counter sale of box and reserved seats.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17-- A network of unmanned weather stations for predicting sudden weather changes in the immediate vicinity of airports is being tested here by the Federal Aviation Agency.

"No boom, but no recession" for the rest of 1963 was the description of the economy given yesterday by John Harriman, economist for the TriContinental Corporation and the Broad Street Group of mutual funds.

IF the way of life that Mainbocher's clothes represent vanishes, it will be a great pity. His designs speak serenely of leisure and elegance. DENVER, Sept. 17 (U.P.)-- Frank Tripucka, quarterback of the Denver Broncos, kept his foot in the door for an offer from the New York Jets, as he announced his retirement today from professional football.

The significance of the huge Russian purchases of Canadian wheat goes far beyond the immediate economic consequences to both countries. It affords an opportunityfor the West, particularly for the United States, to carry out our objective of expanding world trade.

Richard Burton, last seen here as King Arthur in "Camelot," will return to Broadway as Hamlet under John Gielgud's direction. The engagement, limited to 12 weeks, will open March 19. The theater has not been designated.

New Orleans borrowed $14,700,000 yesterday at an interest cost of 3.2791 per cent. The city sold street improvement bonds to the Chase Manhattan Bank and associates and the group reoffered the securities priced to yield 2.15 per cent to 3.40 per cent on 1965 to 1988 maturities.

Lollipops, with their bold colors of red, green, orange and yellow, seldom brighten a stockholders' meeting. But they did yesterday at the annual meeting of the United States Plywood Corporation at its headquarters here.

Control of The New York Law Journal, for 75 years the official newspaper of the city's legal profession, was acquired yesterday by a holding company headed by Jerry Finkelstein, industrialist, publisher and former chairman of the City Planning Commission.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 18--The hatch slid open and an agitated man carrying a dispatch case scampered out of the jetliner and down the ramp. "What's happened?" he asked the airline man at the foot of the steps.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday plans for simplifying its organizational structure beginning Jan. 1, One result of the changes would be that customers will deal with only one district sales office, rather than up to three in the same city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18--The
Teacher raises and other benefits authorized by the Board of Education will ultimately cost the city about $31,500,000 a year--not $26,000,000, as originally indicated.
The four surviving Dionne quintuplets said yesterday in a magazine article that their childhood had been unhappy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The National Maritime Union has been judged in violation of the merged labor federation's internal disputes plan in a case involving the nuclear ship Savannah.

Theodore W. Kheel, the impartial arbitrator of contracts between the National Maritime Union and steamship lines held an all-day hearing yesterday on a union charge of racial discrimination on the liner America. The hearing will be resumed today.
Mayor Wagner has told close associates that he is considering running for a fourth term because he fears old-line politicians will regain control of city affairs if he leaves.

MAMARONEK, N. Y., Sept. 18--John N. Ledbetter of Scarsdale, N. Y., the Metropolitan senior golf champion, today led the field in the opening round of the Westchester senior championship. Playing the West Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club, Ledbetter scored a 5-overpar 77 despite a recently injured side that was tightly taped.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The Senate will vote next Tuesday on the nuclear test ban treaty.
BRASILIA, Sept. 18--President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived today for a five-day official visit that has provoked the protest of Roman Catholic and rightwing political groups.

A Czechoslovak anesthesiologist sought asylum here yesterday. He defected from a 25member group of medical men on a tour of the United States because, he contended, "spiritual terror reaches into all areas of public and private life" in his Communist homeland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--The head of the United States Travel Service told Senators today that he had no apology for giving away 200 sets of cuff links and 45 bracelets to win friends for the agency.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 18--The president of the Oranges and Maplewood Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People resigned today, charging a "total lack of support by ministers of our community and other informed leaders."

THE mother of a 12-year-old was less than enthusiastic when her son took an interest in magic. She feared that through magic the boy would retreat into the unreal and attempt to "manipulate his environment."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18--Russell Cone, the senior skipper on hand at the Larchmont Yacht Club for the International One-Design Class world championship regatta, won the third race of the series today.

Two of the most picturesque parts of Greenwich Village-- Patchin Place and its adjoining court, Milligan Place--will be renovated and possibly sold to individuals or demolished if they fail to produce more rent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- President Kennedy appealed tonight for support "in the national interest" of a tax reduction that he said was both "insurance for prosperity and insurance against recession."
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18-- Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester, has decided neither to seek nor to accept by draft another term as the Republican County Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- An expert medical panel advising the Food and Drug Administration on Enovid has effectively cleared the birth control pill of suspicion that it caused fatal blood clotting in healthy women.

WASHINGTON, Sept.18--The United States has had indications that French diplomats in Vietnam have been promoting President, de Gaulle's proposal for neutralizing and unifying North and South Vietnam, informed sources said today.

New and expanded research efforts to ascertain the risks inherent in "specialized" ships is necessary by ship classification societies and other groups interested in the financing and operation of a growing class of vessels, according to Miles F. York, president of the Atlantic Companies.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept, 18 --President Jorge Alessandri Rodriguez castigated Chile's Congress this afternoon in an Independence Day radio address to the nation.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)--The United States' first space payload with wings was launched down the Atlantic Missile Range today, but after several hours recovery vessels had failed to find it and officials feared that it had sunk in the sea.
Several executive changes at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman.
The number of shares sold short on the New York Stock Exchange at mid-September was the largest this year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 18-- A candidate for a District Court bench has startled voters with a proposal to scrap those venerable procedures under which motorists find it shorter--and sometime sweeter--to pay fines for traffic tickets than to fight the case in court.
Soviet representatives are reported to have approached American traders with offers to buy wheat.

The inflow of foreign capital into Canada has been a worry below the border. Proposing his itnerest-equalization tax in July, President Kennedy expressed the hope that foreign nations would be induced to raise less capital here and thus lessen the drain on the gold stock.
More than 2,000 patrons of the New York Film Festival were mystified last night by an ambiguous, avant-garde French drama about the Algerian war.

IT IS disquieting to keep hearing rumors that the Milwaukee Braves may soon depart from what once was a land of milk and honey for newer, but not necessarily greener, fields in Atlanta. The harvests have grown lean in Milwaukee. The bumper crop was reaped in 1957 when attendance reached 2,215,404, then a National League, record, But it dwindled to 766,921 last year and will go lower this season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18--The General (Steering Committe recommended today. that the General Assembly discuss the South Vietnamese Government's differences with Vietnamese Buddhists. It overrode an effort by South Vietnam to block such discussion.
WRIGHT MORRIS, a distinguished existentialist of the Nebraskan prairie, writes symbolic novels of quite fathomable depth.
ALGIERS Sept. 18--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella announced to day a new 15-man Cabinet of "authentic revolutionary militants."
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 18--Malaysia took steps today to call her reserve forces to active duty and to increase the strength of her regular armed forces.

HONG KONG, Sept. 18--Malaysia's severance of diplomatic relations with Indonesia and the Philippines is a severe setback to two potentially significant regional organizations of Asian states.

The Citizens Union asked Mayor Wagner yesterday to "take no action at present" on prospective increase in cab fares here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Corporate profits turned upward and reached a near-record level in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Sept. 18--Mrs. Charles Farmer, the wife of an industrial designer, was shot dead today in her 25-room mansion.

LONDON, Sept. 18--Britain was reliably reported tonight to be considering breaking diplomatic relations with Lndonesia. It was said that the Government was anxious to avoid the step, but was prepared to do so if necessary.
All-day classes and extended summer sessions are part of a plan to increase the capacity of the City University of New York, where the enrollment increases every year.
UNITED--NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18--A special committee urged the United Nations today to consider without delay new measures to combat South Africa's policy of apartheid, or racial separation.

Indonesia's opposition to formation of the new federation of Malaysia, which has brought violent attacks in Jakarta on the British Embassy and its staff, appears to be based primarily on President Sukarno's fear of colonialism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The White House conference of more than 200 businessmen, called to consider expansion of exports, spontaneously recommended today that the Government re-examine its policy on trade with the Soviet bloc.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city was "fighting" to maintain the 15-cent subway and bus fare.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (UPI)-- A Federal judge has raised to $500 a day the fine on a longshoremen's union that has refused since April 22 to load a Canadian freighter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The House Appropriations Committee is threatening to deal a heavy blow to the Administration's ambitions for landing a manned expedition on the moon.
Everybody in Greenwich Village talks about its outdoor art show, but until now no one has done much about it.

ROLAND PETERSEN'S paintings at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, are good enough to force some questions about the California school of neorealists to which he belongs--a school that has distinguished itself in applying the lessons of abstract expressionism to representational subjects.

A visit from President Tito of Yugoslavia to any country in the Western Hemisphere would be expected to arouse excitement. He has already met trouble in Brazil, his first stop in Latin America. Governors Lacerda of Guanabara, which contains Rio de Janeiro, and de Barros of Sao Paulo refused to receive him.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 19--Prince Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of Malaysia, said tonight that he would consider another meeting with Presidents Sukarno of Indonesia and Diosdado Macapagal of the Philippines, but only if the conference were held in Kuala Lumpur.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 19--Fred Olsen, a shipping executive from Oslo, Norway, who has won two of the previous three International One-Design Class world championships, today captured the fourth race of the 1963 championship regatta off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 19-- A prospective political leader of the newly elected Parliament said today that within two weeks Iran's legislators would be working "with all speed and wholeheartedly" for the reform program of the Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

The Shah of Iran and his Government have won an overwhelming and well-deserved victory in the national elections for a Majlis, or Parliament. This time the election was carefully prepared, and while it would not qualify as free and democratic by United States standards, it was doubtless the fairest and most representative election Iran has ever had.
The small community of Aberdeen, S.D., has become the scene of a fierce competitive battle involving many of the nation's leading advertisers and news media.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 19--On a giant's assembly line here, riveters, crane operators and engineers are putting together the massive steel components for the roadway of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge. The bridge will span The Narrows, linking Brooklyn and Staten Island.
STARTING at $35, it is possible for a woman to find a reasonable facsimile of a European couture fashion at several mass-volume New York stores and their branches.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have reported changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on those exchanges.

THE Westchester Interclub Bridge League is a group of six clubs in Westchester County that form eight-man bridge teams and play a series of matches each summer. The deal shown today is from one of their final matches last week.

"LONG ago in 1945 all the nice people in England were poor, allowing for exceptions." There is something that pleases about this sentence, perhaps its deft precision of rhythm, perhaps the charm of its exaggeration, which is sufficient for a faint humor but not too much to obscure its kernel of truth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that he would vote against the nuclear test ban treaty because it offered only an illusion of peace to weigh against damage to this country's military strength.

BURLINGTON, Mass., Sept. 19--One of the more active newcomers on the New York Stock Exchange, the High Voltage Engineering Corporation, is by nuclear age stand ards an old resident of "electronics alley" on Massachusetts' Route 128.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19-- Sometime next week, probably during the series with the New York Mets, the Los Angeles Dodgers expect to observe the formal clinching of the 1963 National League pennant. It will be a moment for joy, vindication, relief and--since this is Hollywood--a special sort of flamboyant hysteria.
The Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation reported yesterday record sales for the 11th consecutive year. Earnings for the fiscal year ended July 31 also set a new peak.
TRENTON, Sept. 19--All but one of the building trade unions in Union County have agreed to an apprenticeship program to end racial discrimination in hiring, Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today.
The security of the West's deterrent force against surprise attack was firmly buttressed Tuesday with the activation of a radar station at a place only the British could have named, Flyingdales Moor.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 19--William M. Byrnes, long an associate of the late George Huntington Hartford in the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company and a director emeritus of the food merchandising chain, died today in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.
ONLY ghosts remain in the Polo Grounds. It is finished as a baseball park and soon will give way to a housing devel opment just like memory's other treasure trove, Ebbets Field.
The last of more than 50,000 patrons jammed into the Philharmonic Hall of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts last night as the first New York Film Festival-came to an end.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19 --A comprehensive program of services to youths for next year was proposed today by the Youths Services Committee of the Health and Welfare Council of Nassau County.

John Tyler, 10th President of the United States, whose history has been shrouded in a political slogan ever since the 1839 election, is treated as an interesting human being in a book coming from McGraw-Hill next Tuesday. Robert Seager titles his book "And Tyler Too: A Biography of John and Julia Gardiner Tyler."

BRASILIA, Sept. 19--President Joao Goulart proposed today that industrially developed capitalist and Socialist countries collaborate to close the gap between the developed nations and "the great majority of mankind."

President Kennedy's unqualified support for tax reductions revealed his determination to win swift Congressional approval at almost any cost. He omitted any reference to his frequent pledges to reform the tax structure, reform he had once accorded equal priority with tax cuts.

LONDON, Sept. 19--Prime Minister Macmillan's office announced tonight that the 50,000word report by Lord Denning on the Profumo scandal would be published in full next week. The date has still to be decided.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Rail freight loading in the week ended Sept. 14 totaled 698,056 cars, an increase of 9,430 cars or 1.6 per cent from the level in the corresponding week in 1962. The rise was the first in several weeks.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 19--Dr. David F. Gillette, chairman of the New York State Commission for the Blind, which he helped to establish in 1913, died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 79 years old.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 19-- A charge of "subtle segregation" against this city's Housing Authority by three Negro leaders apparently led to the cancellation of President Kennedy's visit to Portland.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 19-- The Administration and wheat producers showed considerable interest today in possible grain sales to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- The 22-year-old son of Secretary of State Dean Rusk has gone to work as a full-time, salaried assistant in the office of the Washington Urban League.

Trading in Government securities appeared yesterday to support the Treasury's assertion that investors are confident long-term interest rates will remain stable. The Treasury made its assertion earlier in the week when it announced success in its $32,000,000,000 advance refunding.
FONTANA, Wis., Sept. 19-- The baby American Rembler has become a smooth teen-ager.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 --Eugene A. Sichel, oldest member of the New York Stock Exchange in age and years of membership, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 97 years old. Mr. Sichel had been ill since February, but as late as last Aug. 29 had carried out stock exchange transactions.

Joe Mooney, a blind singer, organist, pianist and accordionist whose following among his fellow musicians is legendary, has returned to New York after an 11-year stay in Miami. He is currently performing at The Most, 875 Second Avenue, near 46th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- President Kennedy named a two-man committee today to try to bridge the chasm between the white and Negro communities in Birmingham, Ala.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 19 --Western Democrats not only opened their 1964 campaign today but also practically nominated the Republican candidate for President 10 months before the Republicans get around to the decision.
Stock market averages broke through to new highs yesterday despite expectations of a dull market because of the Jewish holidays.

SID CAESAR and Edie Adams will be alternating again this season in the same Thursday evening half-hour over the American Broadcasting Company. The Washington Post Company has asked the united States Supreme Court for permission to file a "friend of the court" brief supporting an appeal by The New York Times against an Alabama libel award.

Ru-Son Products, Inc., of Jersey City, which makes home and garden accessories, has leased a one-story building being constructed to its specifications on the Belleville Turnpike, off the Newark-Harrison Turnpike, in Kearny, N.J.

D.C. Andrews Co., freight forwarders, have leased a floor containing 17,000 square feet in the new building constructed by Samuel Rudin at 1 Whitehall Street. Bertram F. French of Cushman Wakefield was the broker.

THE New York Jets play for the first time in their home city on Sunday. The opposition is fearsome, the Houston Oilers on the field and the New York Giants at the box office. "Come on up and bring your friends," said Sonny Werblin. "We'll have plenty of elbow room."
Oil Royalty tapped a gusher in the $86,650 Beldame Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. And so did those players in the crowd of 37,389 who had the daring to back her.

Stockholders of the Commercial Solvents Corporation at a meeting in Boston yesterday approved the issue of 1,000,000 shares of a new 4 per cent, $20 par, convertible preferred voting stock. Mrs. Anna Maria Rappaport, who celebrated her 23d birthday last Sunday, has been elected second vice president and associate actuary of the Standard Security Life Insurance Company of New York, it was announced yesterday.

The Municipal Bond Women's Club of New York elected Elaine C. Haggerty president at a meeting held last night at Oscar's Delmonico Restaurant. Miss Haggerty is a bond trader for Phelps, Fenn Co.
Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan announced plans yesterday to end the use of Greenwich Village residential streets as turnaround and layover points for Fifth Avenue buses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--New orders for durable goods, an important leading indicator of the economy, fell 2 per cent in August. The decline from the July level on a seasonally adjusted basis was reported today by the Commerce Department.
Gen. Lucius D. Clay, who has been called a possible Republican Presidential choice, said yesterday that he would not seek the nomination and was skeptical about talk of a draft.

A Coast Guardsman went on trial before a court-martial here yesterday, charged with having sunk an ocean-going ship at a time when she was not actually in the water and with causing $1,000,000 in damage. Forty crewmen aboard escaped.

The brief flurry that caused stocks to rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Tuesday was well over by yesterday. The over-all tendency of stocks was downward, and prices continued to decline in medium and lowprice shares.
