The Moscow radio complained yestterday that recent burglaries at the Riverside Drive apartments of Soviet newsmen indicated an "exaggerated interest by criminal elements" in Russians.
The National Broadcasting Company will begin next week the filming of a one-hour television tour of the Louvre, the Paris museum that contains the largest art collection in the world.

ALBANY, Sept. 23--The Very Rev. Raphael M. Huber, Professor of Church History at the Roman Catholic seminary of St. Anthony-on-Hudson in Rensselaer, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23-- If the St. Louis Cardinals cooperate, the New York Mets hope to add another glorious chapter to their brief but bizarre history tomorrow night.
AT a publisher's editorial meeting recently, only one of the literati knew who James Huneker was.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23--British officials forced their way into the burned-out British Embassy today and prevented uniformed Indonesians from breaking into the embassy's security room.
LAUREL, Md., Sept. 23 (AP) --Kelso will represent the Unit ed States in the Washington D. C. International on Nov. 11 for the third straight year Laurel Race Course officials said today.
The first-degree murder trial of a man who has confessed to six killings--five of them in New York City--will go to a jury today.

The directors of the McCall Corporation, the magazine publishing and printing concern, authorized yesterday a threefor-two split of the common stock, payable Dec. 23 to holders of record Dec. 3. The board also recommended a 20 per cent Increase in the quarterly dividend on the increased shares after the split.

LAKEVIEW, L. I., Sept. 23-- About 50 parents and their children assembled in front of the Woodfield Road School this morning for a peaceful demonstration officially ending a twoand-a-half week boycott of the predominantly Negro school.
LONDON, Sept. 23--After nearly two years of study, a Government-appointed committee recommended today by a vote of 4 to 2 a decimal currency for Britain, based on 100 cents to the pound.

Orchestral double-bass players, usually hidden in back-row anonymity, can be pardoned for wanting to escape into the spotlight of the recital platform. John Mathews, a member of the Baltimore Symphony, made the break last night, appearing in ...
One of the fastest guns in the country is a lawman based in the canyons of Manhattan.

ALBANY,Sept. 23--The chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee said today that the committee was considering a proposal to sell state office buildings to get cash to balance next year's state budget.

"Montenegro," a novel by Milovan Djilas, imprisoned former Vice President of Yugoslavia, will be published on Oct. 9 by Harcourt, Brace World. This book was written during a prison term that the author served after expulsion from the Communist party leadership.
Dealers in all sectors of the bond market reported few price changes yesterday in quiet trading.
The city asked Mill Basin builders yesterday to pave some dirt streets and improve some streets they had already paved because they were deteriorating.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The White House announced conditional approval today of a compromise proposal for a park-harbor development a'ong the Indiana Dunes of Lake Michigan. The proposal has been the subject of a long and heated controversy.

Assistant Secretary of State Edwin Martin said in a speech in Los Angeles that "the Cuban economy today is a shambles." This, he asserted, was due in part to the "monumental mismanagement" of the Castro regime; but the Secretary seemed to be attributing most of the credit for the debacle to the United States policy of isolating Cuba.

BARRY GOLDWATER is not a bridge player--at least, not a player of any pretensions--but Bob Goldwater (who runs the family store in Phoenix and leaves politics to brother Barry) is a polished player if one can judge from
The allurements of Suburbia had their effect on friend Ponder some 30 years ago and he moved out of the city to a small patch of greenery within reasonable commuting distance. And he found it good.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 23--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon moved today to resume a dominant role in shaping policies of the Republican party.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI)--The University of California said today that a Negro student had been replaced as an escort for national football queen festivities because of his race.
OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 23-- The University of Mississippi's only Negro student was imprisoned today on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon. Later he was suspended by the institution.

Two Greenwich Village residents testified in State Supreme Court yesterday that they had voted in the Sept. 5 Democratic primary election for district leader even though they were not enrolled Democrats.

As almost every investor-- burned or not burned--knows, the big year for hot new issues was 1961. That year, 1,198 came to market, raising about $3,200,000,000 in capital and raising many investors' hopes for capital gains.

THE tide turned last night. "East Side, West Side," the premiere on the Columbia Broadcasting System network, is the season's first new series of promise. In its first show there was sensitivity, substance and style.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, left for Saigon today to determine whether South Vietnam's political crisis was affecting the war against Communist guerrillas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Sharp bargaining over wording was reported today to be the only remaining obstacle to an agreement next week among, the leading industrial nations for a study of the world's future needs for international liquidity.
William Zeckendorf, the real estate developer, now concedes that he probably has lost his battle to persuade the New York Stock Exchange to move to a new finance city he had planned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Justice Department said today that the Constitution required Congressional districts of substantially equal population
Record sales and earnings of the Avco Corporation in the third fiscal quarter raised its results for the nine months ended Aug. 31 to the highest levels in the company's history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Labor and management in the construction industry issued today detailed guidelines for local joint apprenticeship committees designed to eliminate racial discrimination.
Italy and Spain had a minor international skirmish over Fifth Avenue yesterday. Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes, who is English and Dutch, settled it in favor of the Irish.
PARIS, Sept. 23--Britain told the Council of Europe today that the Western powers should explore the possibilities of new agreements with the Soviet Union.

IT is not necessary to be a size 10 to take an interest in fashion, but finding fashionable clothes is a somewhat more difficult problem for women with full and half-size figures. One solution might be Roaman's, 20 West 39th Street, a store that caters to this size range.
TOURIST trinkets are what American Indians have been associated with in the popular mind, at least as far as fashion and furnishings for the home are concerned.

TRENTON, Sept. 23--New York, New Jersey and the Port of New York Authority moved today to end litigation that has delayed the construction of the $270,000,000 World Trade Center on the lower West Side of New York City.

THE Los Angeles Dodgers have clinched at least a tie for the National League pennant and they face the delightful prospect of opening a three-game home series with the New York Mets tonight. This should be regarded as the equivalent of a mathematical certainty and guarantees the formal nailing down of the championship before too many suns have dropped over the horizon into the Pacific.

PARIS--Stirling Moss says Donald Campbell should "move over" in Britain's quest for the world land-speed record. Campbell, heavily subsidized by British industry, made no attempt on the record this year, despite vast outlays of money and a trip to Australia with his jet turbine car,
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- An entire armored division will be flown to Germany next month in the largest transoceanic military airlift in history, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.

THE number of waterfowl hunters in this country has decreased by more than half in the last five years, a study of the sales of Federal duck stamps reveals. A duck stamp must be purchased before one may legally hunt migratory waterfowl.

Word has been received here of the marriage in New Delhi yesterday of Miss Bimla Nanda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pram Nath Nanda of New Delhi, to John Latane Bissell. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Truesdale Bissell of Canton, Conn.
A few weeks ago the Securities and Exchange Commission leveled some criticism at the advertising efforts of the New York Stock Exchange--criticism that raised an interesting philosophical question.
If a parking lot operator is not told that valuables have been left in a customer's car, he is not responsible for their loss, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

President Kennedy is about to depart on a so-called "conservation" trip through eleven states. His itinerary is heavily weighted with recreation and reclamation projects. Mass recreation facilities and hydroelectric power dams are necessary and important uses of our natural resources.
Two painters and the president of a steel company have joined with three jazz musicians to form a jazz group, the Upper Bohemia Six, which made its New York debut last night at the Five Spot Cafe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The record of the manned moon-landing project from the time President Kennedy announced it to Congress on May 25, 1961, was undeviatingly that of an individual United States enterprise until Mr. Kennedy proposed before the United Nations last ...
Trading was slow on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, with most of the major issues closing easier on the day.
HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 23--After having played six and seven-game schedules for more thin three decades, Peddie School today is pointing for a longer season in football.
Manhattan Democrats plan to elect Borough President Edward R. Dudley chairman of the organization's county committee, high party sources reported last night.
ALBANY, Sept. 23--Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, State Commissioner of Health, defended today the use of pesticides and urged caution in drafting regulatory legislation.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 23-The National Securities Traders Association, founded in 1934 for the simple reason that a trader cannot see through a telephone wire, dug into the most industrious convention of its history here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 23Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon charged today that the Federal Reserve Board was incorrect in claiming that banks had been making increasing numbers of risky loans.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the Grand Jury Association of New York County will make another effort next year to have the Legislature restore to grand juries throughout the state the power to make public reports on matters of public interest.

Dr. Leonard Kornberg of 13730 Geranium Avenue, Flushing, Queens, director of the "Bridge" project at Queens College to improve the educational facilities for culturally deprived children, died yesterday of Hodgkin's disease at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 37 years old.
Quest Link overtook Outing Class in the last stride and won the 19th running of the $29,700 Discovery Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
The A.V.C. Corporation, formerly the American Viscose Corporation, said yesterday that it expected to start liquidating its $367,000,000 in assets before the end of this year.

A prominent Swedish banker recommended yesterday that the United States make more of its gold available to defend the dollar by loosening or severing the tie between gold and the domestic money supply.
Larry Garron, whom the Boston Patriot coach, Mike Holovak, said he would not trade for any other fullback in the American Football League, has taken over the league rushing leadership.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23--Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia delivered veiled but vehement attacks in the General Assembly today on Communist China's hostility toward the West.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 23.--Authorities in Danville, Va., have quietly abandoned the most controversial part of their sweeping legal attack on Negro protest demonstrations in their city.
Autumn, surprisingly chilly and blustery, arrived here at 2:24 P.M. yesterday as rosycheeked and wind-blown as a pretty girl at a football game.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP)-- A lawyer argued today that the case of Judge Melvin H. Osterman involved the gravest governmental question: "Shall judgees be placed 'at the tender mercies' of ambitious district attorneys?"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- President Kennedy sets off tomorrow on an 11-state tour dedicated to conservation but tinged with politics.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23-- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration, declared today that he thought the work of the John Birch Society "should be applauded, not opposed."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--West Coast lumbermen and port officials urged Congress today to extend permanently the authority for shipment of lumber from West Coast ports to Puerto Rico in foreign-flag ships.
The stock market bobbed and weaved yesterday. Some stocks suffered sizable losses. On the other hand, some selective buying brought about good advances.

The New York Yankees, who won the American League pennant with a big assist from the reserves, will return to action against the Los Angeles Angels at the Stadium tonight with plans to have a first-string player at every position.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23-- Dr. Abdel Rahman al-Baidany, a former Vice President of Yemen and an enigmatic figure in her civil war, is reported under arrest in Cairo.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 (UPI) --The Braves, admitting they had received "attractive offers" to relocate their National League franchise, said today they would stay in Milwaukee, where they broke baseball attendance records before a slump set in.

The William Alanson White Institute of Psychiatry, Psychoanalysis and Psychology has purchased the five-story elevator building at 20 West 74th Street, formerly occupied by the Manhattan Nursing Home.

The technological revolution in the nation's steel industry gained new strength yesterday. The United States Steel Corporation, the largest producer, announced that it world build three basic oxygen steelmaking furnaces at its Gary, Ind., works.

LONDON, Sept. 23--The debate within the Government on joining the mixed-manned nuclear-armed fleet proposed for the Atlantic powers by the United States goes deep into long-term questions regarding this country's destiny.
The Xerox Corporation is aiming at obtaining a bigger slice of the office-copier pie.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 23-- A $73,517,000 road reconstruction program has been recommended to Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson by a firm of consulting engineers.
TOKYO, Sept. 20--The National Museum of Western Art here is busy with preparations for what it believes may be the largest showing of works by Marc Chagall ever assembled.
This is the second of three articles on recent advances in weather sciences. The third will appear tomorrow.
The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second largest producer of aluminum, announced yesterday the first increase in the base price of aluminum in almost four years.

The absence of a lawyer at a hearing to investigate charges of racial bias in a construction union was called "reprehensible" yesterday by a member of a three-man investigation panel of the State Commission for Human Rights.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 23--Gen. Leon Cantave, the Haitian guerrilla commander who has been leading attacks against the Government of President Francois Duvalier, fled to the Dominican Republic today with 80 of his men. At least 10 of ...
BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) --The American Football League failed today in a second and decisive effort in Federal Court to collect $10,080,000 in damages from the National Football League.

Landlords and tenants and the organizations that represent them agreed on one thing at a hearing yesterday on the City Planning Commission's program of housing rehabilitation--that they mistrusted government when it came to urban renewal.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Senate decisively rejected today all proposed reservations to the nuclear test ban treaty.

Mr. and Mrs. Jere Patterson of 1192 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bettina Baird Patterson, to Second Lieut, Richard Jahn Sands of the Army. He is the son of Maj. Gen. Thomas Jahn Sands of the Army and Mrs. Sands of Dayton, Ohio, and Washington.

Although the 500,000 sneezing, itchy-eyed New Yorkers who have been suffering because of it will undoubtedly not be surprised by this news, the hay-fever season just ending has been the worst in New York since 1946.
BOINZAHRA, Iran, Sept. 23 --The Shah of Iran told a group of peasants today that he would never again permit arch reactionaries to dictate the affairs of Iran for selfish interests.
TRENTON, Sept. 23--Major Republican leaders throughout the state agreed today that Senator Goldwater had increased his political standing here as a result of his Newark appearance on Friday.
BOINZAHRA, Iran, Sept. 23 --The Shah of Iran told a group of peasants today that he would never again permit arch reactionaries to dictate the affairs of Iran for selfish interests.
TRENTON, Sept. 23--Major Republican leaders throughout the state agreed today that Senator Goldwater had increased his political standing here as a result of his Newark appearance on Friday.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23 (AP)-- John Diefenbaker, Conservative former Prime Minister, accused the United States today of unwarranted interference in Canadian Government policy-making, in Canada's efforts to allay Great Lakes labor strife.
LIBERAL, Kan., Sept. 24 (AP)--The world's largest helium recovery plant was dedicated today to the task of providing helium for the United States space program.
A Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered Thomas A. (Rabbi Tom) Trantino extradited to New Jersey, but Trantino's transfer was delayed at least until today to permit an appeal on the ruling.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23--The Government has made public an interview with Ngo Dinh Nhu, the President's brother and political counselor, in which he said that it was "extremely unpleasant, a real martyrship, for me to have to engage in politics," but that the country's struggle demanded it.
SELMA, Ala., Sept. 24 (UPI) --The police broke up two antisegregation demonstrations today and jailed 156 Negroes, many of them students.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The nation's railroads and the five operating rail unions were far apart through the final effort last month to mediate the work rules dispute, memorandums from Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz showed today.

BERN, Switzerland, Sept. 22 (AP)--Rolf Junefeldt of Sweden won the 300-meter swimming event today but Hungary's versatile athletes maintained their hold on first place in the individual and team competition of the world modern pentathlon championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The United States and U Thant, the Secretary General have reached general agreement on a plan to keep United Nations military forces in the Congo for the first half of 1964.

Stockholders of the Equity Corporation were told at their annual meeting in Dover, Del., yesterday about the opposition by Equity's management to the proposed merger of Friden, Inc., with the Singer Company.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 --Gov. Ross Barnett of Mississippi has agreed to address students on Princeton University's campus here next Tuesday night.
State and city mediators succeeded in removing the threat of a theater strike yesterday while efforts to settle the contract dispute between Broadway producers and musicians are under way.

PARIS, Sept. 24--The headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and of the French defense establishment were silent today on the announcement last night that the deputy press officer of the alliance, Georges Paques, had been arrested for spying.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- One hundred two nations have now signed the test ban treaty. The first three were the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union, which signed in Moscow on Aug. 5. Nigeria was the latest, signing today.
The residents of Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village seem to have won several rounds in their battle against coffeehouses, which they say have brought a honky-tonk atmosphere to the area.
The United States Rubber Company has transferred its $6,000,000 tire account from N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., to Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc. The Ayer agency had served U.S. Rubber for only nine months.
The Board of Estimate was warned last night it would face a taxpayer's suit if it sought to commit more than $5,000,000 of city park funds to acquire land in Queens for World's Fair parking.
Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder told President Kennedy in Washington yesterday that the West Germans were in a "permanent state of readiness to participate in probes" with the Soviet Union.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 24 --Kenneth C. Royall and Earl H. Blaik, sent here by President Kennedy to try to make peace between the races, arrived today in the midst of a new conflict between Negro and white leaders.

SOUTH Africa boasts a 9year-old who can play along with the masters and usually finishes above average. A 5-year-old from Memphis was exploited by the American Contract Bridge League some years ago because he could follow suit and remember the bididng rules of the Goren system.

The National Football League yesterday cleared Charlie Conerly, the former New York Giant quarterback, of any wrongdoing in connection with checks he had received from a Memphis man, now under indictment on gambling charges.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 24 --Lebanon has assured a visiting Syrian military delegation that there is no truth in allegations that Syrian Nasserite elements opposed to the Baathist regime in Damascus are being trained at camps on the Lebanese side of border with Syria.
The Rumrill Company, Inc., an advertising and public relations concern, has leased 12,450 square feet, the entire sixth floor, at 300 East 42d Street for its headquarters.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 24-- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi said today the reforms he was making in Iran would bring democracy like that of the West and social advancement to his people.

When a weather scientist thinks of tomorrow, he sees the prospect of controlling the most powerful forces on earth, forces greater by far than those of all the nuclear weapons in existence--the forces that run the atmosphere.
Joseph E. O'Grady, chairman of the Transit Authority, said yesterday that any "substantial" wage increase won by the Transport Workers Union would make a higher subway fare inevitable.
The Northrop Corporation reported yesterday a slight rise in earnings for its final fiscal quarter despite a sharp drop in sales from last year's level.
NEWARK, Sept. 24--European driving experts demonstrated techniques today to minimize the dangers of skidding.
New York society, of the music-loving variety, ended a full night last night and early this morning with a champagne supper dance in the Grand Promenade of Philharmonic Hall.
Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the nation's leading trainer, saddled four losers yesterday at Aqueduct. He also lost a roll of the dice for a horse he tried to claim.
A holdover New York County grand jury will resume its inquiry into the State Liquor Authority this afternoon.
Chauncey J. Hamlin, founder and former president of the International Council of Museums, died Monday at Carmel, Calif., where he had lived recently. His age was 82.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--A new drive to revive the $355 million Administration program to provide permanent employment in distressed areas opened at the Capitol today.

The Moscow State Circus, two rings smaller than the American family-size model, opened at Madison Square Garden last night and parents immediately found one fringe benefit in not having to prod offspring to look here and look there as they do at a nonstop three-ring affair.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24--Following are the texts of a letter from the Secretary General, U Thant, to President Ngo Diuh Diem of South Vietnam and the President's reply, as made public today by the United Nations:

School volunteers, assisting teachers by working with children individually or in small groups, have "begun to knock chunks" off the traditional school organization, Dr. Calvin E. Gross declared yesterday.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes is right to rebel at long last against painting colored lines up Fifth Avenue in honor of parades. The Italians want a royal purple line; the Germans like a blue line; the Irish, who started it all, demand green.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--An effort by New York's two Republican Senators to help get more Government contracts for the Brooklyn Navy Yard fell short of the mark today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The Senate approved the nuclear test-ban treaty today.

A MAJOR memorial loan exhibition of paintings and drawings by George Grosz (1893-1959), the savage German satirist of the First World War and of Berlin after the collapse of 1918, opens today at two galleries, the Forum Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 79th Street, and E.V. Thaw Co., 50 East 78th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- President Kennedy named a space-minded military planner today to take over the Marine Corps when Gen. David M. Shoup retires at the end of the year.

Mayor aluminum producers, with the conspicuous exception of the Aluminum Company of America, decided yesterday to support the price increase on primary aluminum initiated Monday by the Reynolds Metals Company.

RICHMOND, Sept. 24--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the doctrine of nonviolence in the civil rights struggle had received a serious blow because of recent events in Birmingham, Ala.
A legal battle growing out of Carmine G. De Sapio's 41vote defeat in the Sept. 5 primay election for Democratic leader in Greenwich Village was sought on two fronts yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., Sept. 24 --Mrs. Gloria H. Richardson resigned today as head of the Negro protest movement here.

A religious leader, representing more than 150 officials of all faiths, strongly supported a proposal to classify films for children at yesterday's hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Pornography.

A clear night causing ships' lights to blend with lights ashore may have been a factor in the collision of a ferry boat and a tanker off Staten Island early Monday morning, the masters of both vessels told the Coast Guard yesterday.
TWICE a year department stores present model rooms. This year three major New York stores--B. Altman Co., Bloomingdale's, and W J Sloane-- opened their fall rooms within two days of one another.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 24-- Theodore Hill Jr. of Jefferson Valley was overwhelmingly elected Republican leader of Westchester tonight at a convention of the Republican County Committee in County Center.

Carnegie Hall opened its season last night, too, and with another of the country's major ensembles, the Philadelphia Orchestra. It was the first of four visits the organization will make to Carnegie Hall this season, and, given New York's wealth of music-lovers, this concert was sold out.
LONDON, Sept. 24--Britain indicated today that she wanted no part of a joint European nuclear-weapons effort in isolation from the United States.
The security analyst, whose work may now be more circumscribed by a stiffer set of rules issued by the New York Stock Exchange, is an important cog in the freeenterprise system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The United States reaffirmed today its decision to retaliate against the European Common Market in the "Chicken War," but offered for the first time to submit to independent adjudication the volume of imports on which United States tariffs could legitimately be raised.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The large increase in the United States payments deficit in the second quarter of this year may, in part at least, have been freakish and temporary.
Amid the flashing of real jewels, the rustling of silk and the pompous hum of arriving limousines, the New York Philharmonic opened its 122d season last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--It was only six months ago that President Kennedy spoke with dread of the day that passed perfunctorily into history today. For he knew that the Senate's "advice and consent" to a major treaty is rarely obtained as routinely as the final vote suggested.
VIENNA, Sept. 24--American industry is realizing gross annual savings of about $1 billion a year as a result of the use of radioactive isotopes, an international scientific panel was told today.

MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 24 --Striped bass and blue fish are fine fish, lovely fish, wonderfully fighting fish. But they insist on living in the sea rather than some gentle, placid little pond where one might reach them in a rowboat.

Governor Rockefeller has spoken to Jackie Robinson, the former star second baseman for the Brooklyn Dodgers, about the possibility of Robinson being appointed chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, Robinson said yesterday.
Directors of the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 40 cents a share from the 50 cents paid in earlier quarters.
Paul Perham Cram, for many years an instructor in history at Harvard University, was killed Monday afternoon in a horseback riding accident at Hopkinton, N.H. He was 72 years old.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 --Habitually a strong running team from the single-wing formation, Princeton hopes to demonstrate toughness on the defense, along with the ability to move the ball, in its opening game with Rutgers here Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- Senate leaders unexpectedly scheduled today the first civil rights skirmish of the session, to begin Thursday.

A.L. Rowse, the Oxford historian, confronted an audience that he himself described as "embattled literary scholars" at the Pierpont Morgan Library yesterday and assured them that he was "astonished at the simplicity with which the problems connected with Shakespeare's sonnets could be worked out."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 --Members of the House Banking and Currency Committee indicated today that they would like to fob off on someone else the whole controversy over commercial bank underwriting of securities.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 24--The European Common Market offered today two important sets of tariff reductions, one to the United States on poultry and the other to the Soviet Union on caviar, crabmeat and vodka.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 24 --F. Francis D'Addario's sand and gravel pit is known here as one of the largest in the state. His big yellow trucks bear the slogan, "Hi Ho D'Addario," and are a familiar, if often vexing, sight to motorists on Route 25.

The "strategy of peace" pursued by President Kennedy has scored its first signal victory. The Senate has approved the history-making nuclear test-ban treaty by a majority of 80 to 19, expressing an upsurge of hope by the American people for a better and a safer world.
ALBANY, Sept. 24--State Controller Arthur Levitt declared today that proposals to sell state property to balance the next budget would be "an act of desperation."
Twenty-two entries are assured for the Grand Prix of the United States to be run on Oct. 6 at Watkins Glen, N.Y.

The electronics industry is definitely not static. Last week, the Philco Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, announced that it was cutting back on the manufacture of transistors for sale to the electronics industry because nouncement by Philco, Mr. Welch said.
Pakistan International Airlines will suspend its New YorkLondon service from Oct. 4 to next March, the company announced here yesterday.

The market for United States Government securities was quiet again yesterday. Interest centered on the two longer issues of the Treasury advance refunding, the 4s of 1973 and the 4 1/8s of 1994, which slipped 1-32 during the day because of profit taking.
Teen-agers should enjoy the Hans Hofmann exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. The show contains 40 major canvases that date back to 1940. To Nov. 28.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 24--Paul Verna, spokesman for the Haitian liberation forces, said today that efforts were being made to have the Dominican Government grant asylum to Leon Cantave and members of his guerrilla band. They crossed from Haiti yesterday.

An offering of $100,000,000 of 25-year 4.35 per cent debentures of Dow Chemical Company was marketed yesterday by an underwritlng group headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc. They will be issued in registered form.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24--Peru's Foreign Minister told the General Assembly today that "excessive red tape" was preventing President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress from doing effective work in Latin America.

E. William Henry, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told broadcasters yesterday his agency was still concerned about "over-commercialization" in radio and television. He also said it was time for the F.C.C. to say formally just what it means by "overcommercialization" and thus protect both the public and free enterprise.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 24 --Most college football coaches would be appalled if they faced a nine-game schedule with 16 seasoned players. Roy Ilowit of C.W. Post faces it this season. The former Brooklyn Dodger tackle has 31 players, but only 16 are letter men.

NEWCASTLE, Ireland, Sept. 24 (AP)--JoAnne Gunderson, 24-year-old former United States champion from Providence, R.I., moved into the third round of the British women's golf championship today. She gained a 5-and-4 victory over Elizabeth Collis of England.

"FANTASY," a new work choreographed by John Taras, was given its first performance last night by the New York City Ballet. The music is Felix Mottl's orchestration of Franz Schubert's Fantasy for Piano Duet (Op. 103).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24--President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam has told the Secretary General, U Thant, that foreign elements tried to take over the Buddhist movement in his country and might do so in other Asian lands.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24-- The Garrett Corporation asked the United States District Court today to restrain the CurtissWright Corporation from absorbing it through open-market purchase of Garrett stock.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived here tonight to begin a one-week inspection of the military situation in South Vietnam.
Ralph Guglielmi, a reserve quarterback who has played without distinction this season, was traded by the New York Giants to the San Francisco Forty-Niners yesterday for Eddie Dove, a defensive back.

ONE of New York's most impressive halls of gastronomy is the sumptuous Italian grocery called Manganaro's, at 488 Ninth Avenue (near 37th Street). It is one of the largest salons of its kind in the city and one of the oldest.

BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 24 (Reuters)--Demonstrators and counter-demonstrators clashed tonight outside the Basle Municipal Theater before the Swiss premiere of Rolf Hochhuth's controversial drama known as "The Deputy" or "The Representative."
The Legal Aid Society will benefit from a ball to be held on Oct. 10 at the Trianon Ballroom of the New York Hilton.

LONDON, Sept. 24-For men who care about what they wear, the fashion in Britain next year will be two-button suits and wide lapels, according to British manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)--The Senate sent to President Kennedy today legislation designed to put the railroad retirement and unemployment compensation systems on a sound financial basis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The United States disclosed today that it would withhold, at least for the time being, all new economic-aid programs for Indonesia.
LONDON, Sept. 24--Dr. John Carmel Heenan was enthroned today as the eighth Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster.
OTTAWA, Sept. 24 (UPI)-- United States attempts to settle the Great Lakes labor dispute with a private union trusteeship appeared today to have all but failed.

Another attempt to overthrow the Duvalier regime in Haiti has ended ingloriously. With each attack President Duvalier emerges stronger than before. There is no escape today from the sad conclusion that his position is impregnable-- though tomorrow may tell another story.

"The Blacks," a fixture at the downtown St. Marks Playhouse since May 4, 1961, will register its 1,000 performance there tonight. The runner-up in Off Broadway's drama category is Jack Gelber's "The Conection," with 718 performances. Those were not consecutive, however.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Dodgers clinched the National League pennant today when their final challengers, the St. Louis Cardinals, bowed to the Chicago Cubs, 6--3. The defeat was the sixth straight for the Cards.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24-- The National League pennant, which eluded the Los Angeles Dodgers in heartbreaking fashion at Chavez Ravine 51 weeks ago, came effortlessly to them today while they relaxed at their sun-drenched Southern California homes.

TWO fur designers introduced their fall and winter collections yesterday and proved that no fur-bearing animal and no occasion for fashion would be safe from the hands of the furriers this season.

New York's restaurants and nightclubs are apparently beginning to pull out of a long business slump, but hotels are counting an increasing number of empty rooms while they anxiously await the opening of the World's Fair next spring.

Thomas A. (Rabbi Tom) Trantino, 27-year-old ex-convict who has been indicted in New Jersey in the slaying of two Lodi policemen, was finally extradited to that state yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 Loren K. Olson, former Atomic Energy Commissioner, said today that the atomic weapons laboratories had failed to follow commission instructions and thus were unprepared for resumption of nuclear testing in 1961.
American manufacturers of men's clothing voted yesterday against the new British styles unveiled in London Tuesday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 25 President Sukarno declared today that Indonesia was endangered by Malaysia and that she would have to "fight and destroy" the new federation.
Carnegie Recital Hall was swimming in champagne last night as a Donor's Inspection Reception signaled the completion of the extensive renovation of the hall and formally opened it for the season.
SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 25 Miss Margaret Elizabeth Holmes and Jeremiah Gilman MacKenty plan to marry in the spring.
The International Union of Electrical Workers accepted a contract offer from the General Electric Company yesterday. It provides two wage increases averaging 7 cents an hour over three years.

The overthrow of President Juan Bosch of the Dominican Republic in still another LatinAmerican right-wing military coup is an utterly deplorable event. Whatever Mr. Bosch's faults and weaknesses, he had been freely and fairly elected. His inauguration in February was a dawn of hope and freedom after more than three decades of bestial tyranny. Freedom has now been thrown away, as if it were a paltry gift.

Possibilities that the Soviet Union would be asked to join in Western aid to less-developed countries were ruled out yesterday by the administrative head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 University of Pennsylvania football, the best in the Ivy group for most of the 1940's, is on the way back from depths to which it sank during the last decade.
Jack Benny, who left the National Broadcasting company 15 years ago to pick up a quick $2,260,000 at the Columbia Broadcasting System, will return to N.B.C. next fall.
The city has decided to triple a lump-sum appropriation of $500,000 for court pay already included in its record 1963-64 expense budget of $3,083,228,272.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sought a court order yesterday that would halt nearly $10,000,000 in state and city construction projects as long as job discrimination against Negro workkers existed.
A union local last night authorized a strike unless the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed to stop taking photographs in an employes' washroom.

VIENNA, Sept. 25 The United States urged the International Atomic Energy Agency today to tighten its safeguards against adapting to armmament any nuclear knowledge or equipment received through the agency.
SELMA, Ala., Sept, 25 (UPI) Twenty-eight young Negroes were arrested today for picketing at the Dallas County Courthouse here.

Theodore W. Kheel, the maritime arbitrator, yesterday ordered the liner America's unlicensed crewmen to sail on the ship's next voyage to Europe, Oct. 4, but the company canceled the sailing when the dispute over charges of racial discrimination spread.

Cushman Wakefield, Inc., realty brokers, have arranged mortgage financing for office buildings in Raleigh, N.C., and in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
BERLIN, Sept. 25--A twelve-member team of civil rights specialists of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith concluded today a 21-day tour of West Germany.
BELMONT, Mass., Sept. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Whelan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Ann Whelan, to John Robert Kirk.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The House of Representatives passed the Administration's tax bill today, 271 to 155.
Arthur T. Roth, the chairman of the Franklin National Bank, demonstrated the technique of the indirect thrust yesterday.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 25 The seven-month old Govermnent of President Juan D. Bosch was overthrown before dawn today by the military leaders of the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) A Senate-House compromise was reached today on a bill to give pay increases to most persons in the military services with two or more years of service. The cost is estimated at $1.2 billion a year.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Sept. 25 In a last-minute switch, Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., was named today to the United States Davis Cup line-up for the start of the interzone semi-finals tomorrow with Britain on the West Hants clay courts.
Thanks to new listings, stock splits and stock dividends, the shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange have increased steadily year-by-year.
A teaching affiliation between two of the major medical institutions here, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Hospital, was announced yesterday. Both are in the Bronx.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 The National League has called a special meeting to discuss some way of helping the New York Mets and Houston Colts. One simple way to help the Mets made itself plain at Chavez Ravine tonight: let them stop playing the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The House of Representatives passed the Administration's tax bill today, 271 to 155.
Arthur T. Roth, the chairman of the Franklin National Bank, demonstrated the technique of the indirect thrust yesterday.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 25 The chief judge of the state's highest court called tonight for a public debate on the question of abolishing juries in civil actions.

The National Archives, in which the original manuscripts of the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights are kept, was robbed of at least three 19th-century letters more than a year ago, it became known here yesterday.
A Supreme Court jury found Henry P. Dusablon and Emanuel Samperi guilty of felony murder yesterday in the killing of two men in a liquor store here last Dec. 28.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The Consumer Price Index, after rising sharply for two months, leveled off in August.
"More paper work, that's all." This was a typical reaction yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange's expanded set of rules governing member firms' letters and other communications with the public.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has rejected a major air freight forwarder's move to curb raids on its management staff by rival companies.
The Board of Estimate approved a plan yesterday for an 81-acre addition to Flushing Meadow Park in Queens that will include 67 acres of privately owned land now in industrial use.
Members of Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America have voted to reject a proposed merger of their international with the Photo-Engravers Union of North America.

WITH "Luther," John Osborne has ventured on a big theme in a big way. Apart from an important reservation about a basic point in psychology, he has carried it off with dramatic fervor and passionate eloquence.
A decrease of 549,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Broadway's trapeze swings between triumph and tragedy. Yesterday it snapped on the third opening of the new season: "Bicycle Ride to Nevada," which opened Tuesday at the Cort, was withdrawn after one performance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The General Services Administration has rejected a plea by the Architects Council of New York City to build the $60,000,000 Federal Office Building on a revised Foley Square site.

DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 Sixty Eastern and Western scientists proposed today that the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain join in a special study of seismic phenomena to speed the day of a treaty banning underground nuclear tests.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 Chief Justice Earl Warren said tonight that United States Supreme Court decisions would rarely challenge the states' rights if local courts would adequately protect their citizens.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 What Governor Rockefeller has called a plan to make Albany the most beautiful capital in the United States is described by a professional magazine as "an exercise in architectural pop art."
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 The United States is expected to ask for the opening of consular offices outside Moscow in talks with Soviet officials opening here tomorrow.
Susan Reed and Ed McCurdy, two consistently fresh veterans of folk singing, began a fiveday series of concerts last night at the Jan Hus House, 251 East 74th Street.
New orders for machine tools fell in August from the July figures.
Opposition to a purple line up Fifth Avenue for the Columbus Day parade appeared to be fading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 A Labor Department expert said today that rising productivity was eliminating a minimum of nearly 200,000 factory workers' jobs each year.

LONDON, Sept. 26--A letter written by Pope Paul VI before his accession criticizing Rolf Hochhuth's controversial play, "The Representative," was reprinted in the program for the show's London opening here last night.

Bausch Lomb, Inc., one of the nation's largest optical concerns, has been enjoined from fixing prices and rigging bids in the sale of microscopes to public agencies in New York, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.

The Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's fifth largest carrier and the most profitable, reported yesterday net income of $7,969,024 in August, a decline from $8,268,072 in the 1962 month. Net income is compiled under accounting rules laid down by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ALBANY, Sept. 26--Controller Arthur Levitt, the sole Democrat in the state administration, gave reluctant approval today to what he described as a dubious maneuver by Governor Rockefeller to balance the budget.

A California woman who telephoned the New York City police and said she planned to commit suicide was kept busy on a transcontinental line early yesterday while a patrolman gained enough information to identify her and then summon the police in Hollywood.

THE deal shown today was played by Americans in the North-South positions at Cannes on the French Riviera. The game was one of several that members of the Westchester Contract Bridge Association enter each year...
Two leading, United States wheat exporting companies said yesterday that they would not participate in a proposed joint venture to sell 100 million bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union.
FOUR exceedingly pleasant and energetic performers have come up from Washington with a satirical revue called "A Political Party."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Democratic majority of a Senate subcommittee has endorsed a draft bill to prevent excess profits in the Government's stockpiling of strategic materials.
The Wagner administration will press for a quick decision from the state on how much state aid will be available before the city starts condemnation proceedings for two major park projects in Queens.
ROME, Sept. 26 On his 66th birthday today, Pope Paul VI sent a message by Telstar to Georgetown University on its 175th anniversary.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 26 Colombians are nervous and puzzled over the increase in terrorist incidents here in recent months.
TO the layman, the ecologist's projection of the future makes a hopeless picture.

LONDON, Sept. 26--The Soviet Union has sold about 40 tons of gold on the continent, mainly in Paris, in the last two days. It was the second time in three weeks that the Russians... have sold gold heavily in the West.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 26 Kenneth C. Gifford, former board chairman and president of Schick, Inc., electric razor manufacturer, died today at Norwalk Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 36 Chestnut Hill Road, Wilton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) A North Carolina man created alarm and consternation at the White House today by crashing his truck through a street gate and nearly reaching the North Portico entrances to the Executive Mansion.

One month after the slaying of Janice Wylie acid Emily Hoffert, the police have questioned more than 500 persons in one of the most intensive investigations of murder in this city, but the case remains wide open.

PARIS, Sept. 26 Inflation is troubling Europe. Only two countries, France and Italy, are suffering from serious cases, and there is disagreement over how serious they are. But a new outbreak of strikes in the Netherlands is causing official concern that wages will be pushing up prices there.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 26 "Our mood is to cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission."
British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday a sharp increase in sales and earnings for the first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Unanimous Senate passage today sent to the House, for expected quick approval there, a pay increase starting next month for practically all members of the armed forces with more than two years' service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 House-Senate conferees have agreed on a compromise $968 million budget for the National Institute of Health. This is $6 million less than requested by the Administration.
In a kitchen of particular concern to 150,000 New York housewives, 75,000 eggs were boiled hard yesterday and 6,000 gallons of mock scotch broth barley but no beef were cooked.
Free reserves of the commercial banking system fell to a daily average of $56,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the lowest such level in more than three years.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 26 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the Southern Christian Leadership Conference would call for a nationwide boycott of gift purchases during Christmas.
The United States Government bond market was quiet and unchanged yesterday until just before the market closed officially at 3:30 P.M.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. Stars, when they appear, are employed as follows: One star denotes restaurants of more than routine interest; two stars denote those of superior quality, and three stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.

FOR his New York solo recital debut in Town Hall last night, Eugene Mancini managed to avoid most of the cliches of programing and yet provide solid fare. Two duets from Bach's "Klavierubung" began the evening, two Liszt works, "Les jeux d'eaux de la Villa d'Este" and the Tarantella, ended it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Senator Barry Goldwater inched closer today toward a declared candidacy for the Presidential nomination.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26--Austria complained in the General Assembly today that Italy was delaying negotiations designed to resolve a prolonged dispute between the two countries over a Tyrolean province.

The United States and Spain extended yesterday for five years their 1953 agreement on American air and naval bases in Spain, and announced new measures of increased defense cooperation.

A New York dealer in bank stocks sharply criticized yesterday the procedure followed by the National Association of Securities Dealers in furnishing bank stock quotations to newspapers. Bank stocks are generly traded in the over-the-counter market.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Joseph M. Valachi was taken from his local prison cell today, but his public exposure was a brief and restricted one.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board was told today that scheduled air service was essential to the successful operation of the resort industry in Sullivan County, N.Y.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 26 American society has many bases, but few are more socially difficult to touch than Pebble Beach, an exclusive community than calls itself the nation's golfing capital.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Sept. 26 Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., shook off a seven game losing streak and a cramp in his fingers today and battered Billy Knight, 4 6, 8 6, 6 4, 6 4, to give the United States a 2-0 lead over Britain in the Davis Cup interzone semi-finals.
Prices of cottonseed oil, hides and rubber futures climbed sharply yesterday for the third consecutive day. Trading was active.

The first of three important new buildings opening at Yale University this fall will be dedicated today, the latest in a 10year series of spectacular structures that have made the Yale campus one of the leading forces in today's architectural design.

BOAT owners who worry about finding enough time to go boating can take heart from a recent survey by the Outboard Boating Club of America.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 Wes Ellis increased his lead to two strokes in the Metropolitan open golf championship today.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 The resignation of Mayor Thomas Gangemi was accepted unanimously today by the ninemember City Council. He resigned suddenly late last night after the State Department had said he was not a United States citizen.

Fourteen additional singers have been announced by the Metropolitan Opera for its coming season, which opens on, Oct. 14. At the same time the company released its full roster of artists, revealing that 17 singers have not been re-engaged.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26--The 17 Jews of this ancient trading post prepared to celebrate a lonesome Yom Kippur this weekend in one of Europe's oldest synagogues.
The Associates Investment Company, a $1,500,000,000 financial holding company, plans to acquire outright control of the First Bank and Trust Company of South Bend, Ind.
Henry D. Cleveland, former chairman of John S. Emery Co., a Boston shipping concern, died Wednesday in his home at 160 East 48th Street. He was 87 years old.

Infrared rays, used to help shoot down jet fighters, decipher the Dead Sea scrolls, prevent railway wrecks and trace illegal opium, among other things, have caused an uproar on the American Stock Exchange.
Nathan Newman, a retired jewelry manufacturer, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old, and lived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

Mrs. Gareth Martinis, in a surprise appearances, testified yesterday for about an hour before a Bronx County grand jury investigating possible perjury by witnesses in the recent automobile accident trial of her husband.
LONDON, Sept. 26--The political battle over Lord Denning's report on the Profumo scandal was joined tonight by Prime Minister Macmillan and Harold Wilson, leader of the Opposition Labor party.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 Former President Arturo Frondizi said today that his opposition to the incoming administration of President-elect Arturo Illia would be loyal and constructive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that six more applications for grants to help establish or expand educational television broadcast facilities had been accepted for filing. The requests total $1,104,028.

Karl Heitz, Inc., representatives here for Swiss electronic and photographic concerns, have leased the entire 18th floor of 10,000 square feet at 979 Third Avenue, the northeast corner of 58th Street.

Tuberculosis, the "white plague" thought to be near extinction a few years ago, has had an "alarming" resurgence in New York City, health officials reported yesterday.

F. Eugene Dixon Jr.'s confidence in his jumper, Citizenship, proved well-founded at Aqueduct yesterday. Originally listed as an entry with Will I Rule in the Elkridge Hurdle, Citizenship became the sole Dixon colorbearer in the 1 7/8-mile race when, the more highly regarded horse was scratched.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 6 (UPI) James R. Hoffa, teamsters union president, said today that he might throw his support to George Romney, "our good Governor from Michigan," as a candidate for President in 1964.

GENEVA, Oct. 6 At a world conference on space communications that opens here tomorrow the United States is expected to stress the need for keeping satellite research radio channels well isolated from other broadcast bands.

The American Symphony Orchestra with Leopold Stokowski conducting, begins its second season at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:40.

The advertising agency business is acquiring an increasingly international flavor. The latest reflection of this trend is the establishment of a new agency linking organizations in the United States, France, Britain and Italy.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 6 Mayor Wagner advised Governor Rockefeller tonight to "stay home" and "stop wasting his time" pursuing the Presidency.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 6 Graham Hill of England won the Grand Prix of the United States here today, beating his BRM teammate, Richie Ginther of the United States, by 34 seconds.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 As destiny's darlings, the Dodgers could do nothing wrong in this World Series. So today they finished off the Yankees, who could do nothing right. It was a mercy killing and there isn't a court in the land that would return any verdict except justifiable homicide.
LOS ANGELES, Oct, 5 West Coast aerospace manufacturers indicated informally today that they wanted no part of the study commission proposed for the industry yesterday by union officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Violence in South Vietnam has rekindled the Washington policy debate that President Kennedy tried to dampen last week. It his expected to bring new demands that the United States apply strong pressure to change the policies and personnel of the Saigon Government.
BONN, Oct. 6 The Social Democratic party, seeking votes in West Germany's important middle class, turned its back this weekend on "economic planning."
A colorful panorama of the folk arts of Bulgaria was displayed last night at Philharmonic Hall.

There has been a revival in our tax-oriented society of the practice of using life insurance as a vehicle for philanthropic gifts.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday that its petition to Governor Rockefeller for the removal of the four commissioners of the New York City Board of Elections had been rejected.

BUENOS AIRES. Anxiety over the economic policy to be pursued by the new Argentine Government when Dr. Arturo U. Illia takes office Oct. 12 has strained the nerves of domestic and foreign financial interests, weakened the peso and paralyzed a number of investment projects.
The Federal Aviation Agency will demonstrate at Idlewild Airport tomorrow a new jetliner take-off procedure that is intended to provide greater safety without a marked rise in noise.

This year's meeting of the International Monetary Fund paved the way for changes in the world's monetary mechanism. There is as yet no agreement on the form and sub stance of potential improvements, but the "group of 10" nations considering reforms have enhanced the prospects for successful negotiation by ruling out any radical or revolutionary measures.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged yesterday that the automobile industry had failed to end the "serious under-utilization" of Jews in white collar and administrative positions.

The feeling in Congress and in the country that the United States is bogged down in Vietnam has not been erased by the McNamara-Taylor report. The excited shouts of three young women driving in pursuit of a hit-and-run driver in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn early yesterday attracted policemen and led to the suspect's arrest.

Carry Back, Never Bend and The Axe II will head a 14-horse field in the $30,450 Long Island Handicap today as Aqueduct begins one of its biggest racing weeks.

Six anti-Castro Cubans interrupted a performance of the Moscow Circus before 9,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night to do a political act of their own.
A man was killed and seven persons were injured yesterday in a two-alarm fire at 103 Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village.

IN their Brooklyn Heights brownstone, Bob and Ruth Grossman recently collaborated over pots, mixing bowls and typewriter to produce "The Chinese-Kosher Cookbook." The 84page volume has just been published here by Paul S. Ericksson, Inc. It is $2.95 a copy.
A Texas member of Congress declared yesterday that rent control in New York City was just another step in a "master plan" return the nation into a Socialist state.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 6 Shah Mohammad Riza Pahlevi ceremonially inaugurated the Iranian Parliament today after a suspension of two and a half years.

ATHENS, Oct. 6 Twenty-five years ago I entered the tenebrous Balkans on a third-class train released from Nazi Germany where Hitler was shunting troops for the war that didn't come. Instead, at Munich, Britain and France sold out Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has not adopted a New Look in its lending policy but has decided upon "an interesting raising of the hemline of bankability."

THE Russians have culled a respectable but rather plodding movie from Leo Tolstoy's classic novel "Resurrection." The import, which opened Saturday at the Cameo, runs for two and a half hours at least an hour too long.
