HAWORTH, N.J., Oct. 10--The Women's New Jersey Golf Association team of 15 won the Mrs. J.J. Thomson Trophy for the 26th time today by beating the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, 32 to 12 . The competition was held at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club.
The Futterman Corporation, a national realty investment company, has leased a floor containing 10,200 square feet in the building at 529 Fifth Avenue, at 44th Street.

The final act has been accomplished in three capitals --Moscow, Washington and London--today in connection with the conclusion of the treaty on banning nuclear weapon tests in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 10--Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu said today that she would accept as final the verdict of a United Nations mission of inquiry on the responsibility for the killing of nine Buddhist demonstrators in the South Vietnamese city of Hue last May.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10--A battle for control of the Garrett Corporation, California aviation equipment concern, was punctuated unexpectedly today by the disclosure that the Signal Oil and Gas Company of Los Angeles had bought 100,000 shares, or about 6 per cent of Garrett's stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- Detroit and its environs were depicted to Senate investigators today as a rackets paradise where the Mafia grossed $150 million a year from illegal enterprises.
Eighteen Manhattan hotels that the city charges are really rooming houses have been brought back under rent control and their rents reduced by a total of $221,000 a year.
Grain exporters are expecting a stiff battle for the Soviet wheat business.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10--Prime Minister Macmillan notified the Conservative party today that he had decided to retire. The announcement came six hours after Mr. Macmillan, who is 69 years old, successfully underwent an operation.
FEW contemporaries have aroused as much belligerency in their pursuit of peace as Dr. Linus Carl Pauling, who has just been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1962.
Potholes, long a hazard for motorists, are going to get special attention from the City's Department of Highways this winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)--The Navy said today that the completion of the 31 nuclear-powered submarines now under construction had been delayed, partly because of faulty workmanship in both Government and private shipyards.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 10--The Nobel Peace Prize for 1962 was awarded today to Dr. Linus Carl Pauling of the California Institute of Technology. Dr. Pauling also won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1954.

FOR a while, last night at the City Center, it ap peared as though Jerome Moross and Edward Eager were coming up with something unusual--perhaps even a new concept of American opera. The occasion was the world premiere of "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" for which Mr. Eager had supplied the lyrics, Mr. Moross the music.
The New York Mets emerged from the National League's bargain basement yesterday with two young ballplayers of appreciable potential. But they did a much bigger business in shifting coaches.

The Piave River, swollen by waters that overflowed the Vaiont Dam, is the fifth largest in Italy. It rises in the Carnic Alps and flows 137 miles to the Adriatic Sea about 20 miles northeast of Venice.

ALBANY, Oct. 10--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 991 persons who passed the examination for admission to the New York State Bar last July 10 and 11. The test was taken by 1,520 candidates.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 10-- Dartmouth, possessing the longest winning streak (13 games) of any major college football team and favored to repeat as Ivy League champion, nevertheless is not expecting a picnic in Saturday's game here with Brown.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Pentagon said tonight that an Army sergeant at the National Security Agency had passed classified materials to Soviet agents for years before his suicide last summer.

Mayor Wagner made the Columbus Citizens Committee happy yesterday by saying it could have its purple center stripe on Fifth Avenue for the parade tomorrow honoring the Italianborn discoverer of the New World.
WESTPORT, CONN. YOUNG mothers here have returned to riding the school bus for an hour and a half each day to help the driver with the 65 new kindergarten pupils from Coleytown Elementary School.
Construction at the New York World's Fair returned to normal yesterday after a two-day work stoppage, but the dust of controversy has not yet settled.

BERLIN, Friday, Oct. 11-- The Russians ended early this morning a temporary shutdown of East-West traffic on the Berlin autobahn and cleared two convoys that had been held at the Marienborn checkpoint for more than 15 hours.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- The income tax form went to press today. The most noticeable change in it is a window cut in the first page of the booklet, leaving room for the taxpayer's name, address and identification number.
Hundreds of Chinese schoolgirls carrying paper laterns were pursued by dragons through the narrow, winding streets of Chinatown last night.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 10--The start of the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations between the United States and the European Economic Community will be postponed from next spring until next summer, a United States trade official indicated here today.

Harry Winston, who owns and occupies the building at 718 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of 56th Street, for his jewelry business, has sold the five-story building at 712 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, in the same block.
LONDON, Oct. 10--Prime Minister Macmillan's illness, coming at a moment of crisis in his political fortunes, has brought him a degree of compassion and sympathy he has not had for a long time.

TOMORROW is Columbus Day--a day to honor the Italian explorer, a day to recall the perspicacity of a Spanish Queen. It is also the first day of full-fledged combat involving the Ivy League's eight football teams, and by Saturday evening the battle lines of the season-long race

Premier Adoula has appealed to the United Nations to keep its troops in the Congo at least for a short while beyond the Dec. 31 deadline set by Secretary General Thant and to continue its economic and technical aid. The need for such aid is evident.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- The Kennedy Administration sought today to cut its way through the tangled underbrush of Government patenting policies.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., rang up record sales for the 11th straight year, according to the annual report covering the fiscal year ended Aug 3. Earnings were the second highest in the company's history despite two strikes that caused a 2.5 per cent dip.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--There are several possible explanations why President Kennedy considered it necessary to cloak with certain deceptions common to politics his decision to let Communist nations buy United States wheat.
IT was last Aug. 10 that Harry Bachrach, the ticket manager of the New York Giants, sold the last seats for the team's home opener at Yankee Stadium this Sunday against the Cleveland Browns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- High Government officials are worried that difficulties in the savings-and-loan industry in Chicago may mount and impair public confidence elsewhere in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) --American farmers are harvesting the largest volume of crops in the nation's history on relatively small acreage and at a time when the Soviet bloc and much of Western Europe are gathering in short crops.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10-- Dr. Linus Pauling said today that the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to him would encourage workers for peace all over the world.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10--Helicopters brought out today the bodies of 12 United States servicemen from a rugged mountain area near the Laotian border where two Marine helicopters crashed Tuesday while on a rescue mission.
A Czechoslovak physician who announced his defection from the Communist country and sought asylum here three weeks ago has left New York on his way back to Czechoslovakia.
Baseball award-giving in various player-of-the-year categories continued yesterday. The latest winners were Whitey Ford of the Yankees and Dick Stuart of the Boston Red Sox.

YONKERS, Oct. 10--Is Yonkers wicked? Clergymen, policemen, city fathers and others gave conflicting answers today to the charge by the State Investigation Commission that Yonkers was a mecca for bookmakers and that police corruption was rife.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) --Agreement was reached today between the prescriptiondrug industry and the Food and Drug Administration regarding proposed new regulations for advertising, except on what is known as the grandfather clause.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) --The Department of Justice moved today for the second time in a week to block a proposed bank merger already approved by the Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon.

WASHINGTON, Oct 10--An engineer here who has visited the Vaiont Dam in Italy several times reported today that an earlier landslide had so alarmed its builders that they had delayed filling the reservoir with water.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) --The House Interior Committee approved today a bill calling for an outdoor recreation program costing $1 billion.
More than 10,000 persons have been killed this year in natural disasters, including the one Wednesday night in which a landslide into a dam wrought death and destruction near Belluno, Italy.

In a determined effort to avert a strike of musicians that could close all of Broadway's 21 stage shows, Mayor Wagner kept labor and management negotiating all day at City Hall, and, after an evening recess, the talks were resumed at 12:50 A.M. today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10-- The $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Pace final tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway will have seven standardbreds that have done a mile in 2 minutes or less. Five of them hold track records.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, representing all performers in broadcasting, has started contract negotiations with four national networks. Present agreements expire Nov. 15.

IN one of the classic hands of bridge, the West player found himself with the lead, at a three no-trump contract, when his side required four immediate tricks to defeat the contract. The heart suit was distributed as follows:
MOSCOW, Oct. 10--A Jewish writer said today that the Russian Jews had joined the mainstream of Soviet life and would never return to the isolated ghetto existence of the past.

RAMSEY, N.J., Oct. 10-- Oscar O.R. Schwidetzky of 31 Lakeside Drive, director of research of Becton, Dickinson Company, manufacturer of medical and surgical instruments and hospital supplies and developer of the Ace bandage, died yesterday at Hackensack Hospital. His age was 88.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 10--Haiti's narrow southern peninsula, the main source of this poverty-ridden nation's vital export crops, lies devastated and exhausted today from the ravages of a hurricane.
ROME, Oct. 10 (AP)--Prof. Renato Bartoccini, noted Italian archeologist and curator of the Villa Giulia Etruscan museum in Rome, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.
SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 10-- Westminster School, pitched on a well-wooded, highly colored hillock just north of this easymoving New England village, is observing its 75th anniversary this year.
Mickey Mantle will come to New York within 10 days for an operation on his left knee, the New York Yankees announced yesterday.
ARE the waterways of this area really so crowded they look like the Long Island Expressway?

Two former police commissioners fo Mount Vernon told the State Investigation Commission yesterday that they had been dismissed because they had refused to yield to political demands in making promotions and transfers.

THE fourth annual National Decoration and Design Show opens today at the New York Coliseum for the first time. The three previous shows were held at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 66th Street.
THE city's short men have a stanch sartorial sup porter in Leonard Hellman, the 6-foot-2-inch merchandise manager of Saks-34th and originator of its Napoleon Shop.

THE type of interview that educational television is especially well equipped to provide, the leisurely exploration of a person's views without pressure either to make headlines or conduct a crossexamination that is more productive of emotion than information, was admirably illustrated on two successive programs last night over station WNBT.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 (UPI)-- Gordie Howe scored two firstperiod power-play goals tonight to move within three goals of Maurice (Rocket) Richard's National Hockey League record and lead the Detroit Red Wings to a season-opening 5--3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.
ROME, Oct. 10--The Ecumenical Council took up today the historic issue of papal infallibility.
ATLANTA, Oct. 8--Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is touring the South with one of the liveliest political medicine shows of this pre-election year.
Mayor Wagner declared last night he had "no inclination to run away" from the problems and challenges he faced as chief executive of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz indicated today that he thought the Canadian Labor Congress was responsible for the breakdown of efforts to resolve the Great Lakes labor dispute by means of a private, union trusteeship.
FOLLOWERS of the West Town House, the gift and home accessories shop at 260 West 86th Street, will be happy to note that there are some new additions to its attractive wares.
The State Civil Service Employes Association declared yesterday that it might resort to "militant union tactics" to obtain a $100,000,000 package increase it wants from the state.
The Moreland Act Commission created by Governor Rockefeller to recommend revisions in the state liquor law will begin public hearings here on Oct. 30.

THERE were 10,200 persons in Madison Square Garden last night, and they saw what must surely be the most exciting show in town this weekend. It was Asaf Messerer's "Ballet School" performed by the troupe of Bolshoi Ballet dancers currently touring the country under the sponsorship of S. Hurok.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10--Yale University will dedicate tomorrow a striking library building, given by the Beinecke family, that is designed to shelter and display a treasure of rare books and manuscripts.
TIZI-OUZOU, Algeria, Oct.10 --Algerian Government forces began moving in strength today toward the Kabylia mountain stronghold of the dissident "Socialist Forces Front."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- The Senate approved today the first major change in Federal machinery that has been regulating dairy farmers' incomes since 1937.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- Loadings of rail freight in the week ended Oct. 5 reached the best level in nearly two years; truckloadings in the same period registered their most substantial year-to-year gain since late August of this year.

Mayor Wagner was quick to deride yesterday a proposal by a reform Democratic Councilman that celebrated national and state law enforcement figures be asked to give their views on legalized off-track betting at public hearings here.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 10--The Hollywood boycott of the San Francisco Film Festival will end on Oct. 30 when "The Victors" has its world premiere at the opening.

DALLAS, Oct. 10--The Big D is preparing itself for what could be the most interesting weekend of football anywhere this season. The main attraction is the annual Texas-Oklahoma game in the Cotton Bowl Saturday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- President Kennedy told Congress today that if the United States did not sell wheat to the Soviet Union, cold war activity might be renewed.

Paul W. Gibbs, vice president of sports sales for the Dunlop Tire and Rubber Corporation, manufacturer of automobile tires, sporting goods and other products, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Decatur, Ga.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP)-- James R. Hoffa and seven associates, accused of fraudulently obtaining $20, million in loans from a pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were denied today a plea, for an immediate trial.
LONDON, Oct. 10--Sol. M. Linowitz, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, was elected to the board of the Rank Organization today in a further strengthening of ties between the two companies.
LONGARONE, Italy, Oct. 10 (UPI)--"At first there was a loud, distant roar, and then the window panes started trembling," said Alessandro Belluncini.

The Robert Joffrey Ballet left here yesterday for Leningrad, to begin an eight-week tour of the Soviet Union Tuesday. It will perform under the auspices of the United States Department of State and the Rebekah Harkness Foundation.

A continuing shortage of rainfall had reduced the city's reservoirs to 35.5 per cent of capacity yesterday and caused a "critical" forest fire situation upstate. Total water storage in the city's basins stood at 169,300,000,000 gallons, against a capacity of 476,457,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- The House voted today to bar a joint Soviet-American manned flight to the moon.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower says the United States should exploit the split between the Soviet Union and Communist China-- "encourage it and do those things that tend to widen" it.
ST. STEPHEN, N.B., Oct. 10--Maggie had a coming of-age party today. She was lovely and poised as a young lady should be, she was the center of admiring stares and many a compliment was sent her way.
The American Stock Exchange suspended an associate member for a year yesterday and fined him $1,000.

AMONG Max Gordon's cultural assets is the fact that he reads this column.

ALBANY, Oct. 10--Workmen's compensation claims were approved by the Court of Appeals today in the case of a man who took a week's vacation during a business trip in Europe and was killed in a plane crash on his way home.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 10-- Four men accused of operating a big gambling syndicate from a headquarters in Yonkers obtained an order in State Supreme Court here today revoking search warrants and suppressing evidence on which their prosecution was based.
Esther Admon, a mezzo-soprano with considerable charm of person and a reasonably schooled voice, gave a pleasing program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- President Kennedy urged Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo today to help speed the retraining of the Congolese Army in preparation for the eventual withdrawal of United Nations forces.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 10-- Shams-ud-Din, the 41-year-old Minister of Revenue in the state government of Jammu and Kashmir, will succeed Bakshi Ghulam Mohammed as Prime Minister of that disputed state.
Former President Harry S. Truman said here yesterday that Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu, a visiting fireman," would fade from the picture as soon as the news media paid less attention to her.
Dr. George G. Ornstein, a specialist in chest diseases, died yesterday at Doctor's Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 875 Fifth Avenue.
The quarterly dividend is up, and so are sales and profits. This was the news presented to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting of the Consolidated Foods Corporation in Chicago.
Earnings of the Raytheon Company for the first nine months this year plunged to $1,612,000 from $7,819,000 in the 1962 period. The decline in the third quarter was not as sharp.

The Vaiont Dam, over whose rim flood waters cascaded into communities in the Piave River Valley in northeastern Italy Wednesday night, is the third highest dam--and the second highest in concrete--in the world.

The announced decision of Gen. Song Yo Chan not to run for the Presidency of South Korea in the coming elections, and the previous withdrawal of former Premier Huh Chung, give the people of South Korea an opportunity to speak out clearly for or against military rule.

George White's "Scandals" came back to New York Wednesday night for the first time in 24 years. The last "Scandals" appeared in 1939 at the Alvin Theater with Ann Miller and Ben Blue heading the cast. This time the locale is not a theater but a Broadway night club, Jack Silverman's International Theater-Restaurant.

One of Broadway's blue chips, "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," will start its third year at the 46th Street Theater Monday night. The Frank Loesser-Abe Burrows musical hasn't played to an empty seat since the open ing on Oct. 14, 1961.

Jack Sommers, former chairman of the board of Jay Thorpe, Inc., women's specialty store at 24 West 57th Street, which closed last year, died of a heart attack yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

PRAGUE, Oct. 10--With the first snows of what, by official admission, will be a very difficult winter whitening the eastern mountains, the Czechoslovak Government announced today a highly unpopular price increase.

PARIS, Oct. 10--The French Foreign Minister, Maurice Couve de Murville, was reported today to have been encouraged by his talks with President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) --President Kennedy called for greater appreciation of the importance of the space program today as he awarded one of the nation's highest space honors to the seven original astronauts.

WHEN Dr. John Bain Sutherland, autocrat and aristocrat, coached the University of Pittsburgh football team a quarter of a century ago, his Panthers were the scourges of the collegiate gridiron. Whenever they struck, they didn't strike with guile. They drove ahead with sheer power. Jock Sutherland was a perfectionist, a stickler for fundamentals. His blocking assignments were artfully planned and artfully executed.
Free reserves of the nation's banking system rose in the week ended Wednesday.

The police, seeking to curb a continuing rash of burglaries on the East Side, are operating on the theory that professional thieves who prey on well-known entertainment figures may be using daily bulletins that list their whereabouts.
A former bank official and a corporate executive were indicted yesterday by a Federal grnad jury on charges of misapplying $412,137 in bank funds.

ALMA-ATA, U.S.S.R., Oct. 8--An exhibition of graphic art from the United States has become a tremendously popular attraction in this central Asian city, the capital of the Soviet republic of Kazakhstan.

It was an electronics stock market yesterday. Even though Chrysler led the field as the most active issue of the day, electronics were the chief movers. Strength in such issues allowed the market to close on the plus side.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10--The British selected two Ryder Cup newcomers today to oppose Arnold Palmer and his partner, Johnny Pott, in the opening match of the professional golf competition against the United States tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UPI)-- Wheat and soybeans closed mixed, rye fell, oats rose and corn was steady to down today on the Board of Trade.

Home appliances are selling so well this year that at least one major company is predicting an industry record of 13,700, 000 units--8 per cent above the record 1962 level.

Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan has shelved his hopes for an important Federal post, apparently because he believes his departure would be likely to set off a bitter fight within the Democratic party over the borough presidency.

Directors of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad ordered yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to the regular quarterly 50-cent payment. Both distributions will be made Dec. 12 to holders of record of Nov. 4.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. EVERYONE and anyone who has anything to sell is stocking up in Cambridge, Mass., for a money-making weekend.

The Norfolk and Western Railway Company will declare a yearend extra dividend of $1 a common share along with the regular fourth-quarter dividend of $1.25 a share, Herman H. Pevler, president, announced yesterday.

Stock of the Xerox Corporation spurted to a historic high of 353 yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The action was attributed largely to institutional buying.

Sugar futures tumbled yesterday for the first three in more than a week. All months of the world and domestic contracts fell 50 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), the daily trading limit.

The London stock market registered more gains than losses in heavy trading yesterday.

International Minerals and Chemical Corporation expects earnings to rise 20 to 25 per cent to a record in fiscal 1963-64, for the company's fifth successive record year, T.M. Ware, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.

The Board of Health called on the Park Department yesterday to abolish pigeon-feeding areas. Its request was a result of the disclosure three weeks ago that two persons had died recently of a brain disease transmitted in pigeon droppings.

The New York State Council on the Arts, aided by community organizations, will sponsor four revivals in single performances on successive nights at Brooklyn's Academy of Music and the Bronx High School of Science.

Walter W. Heller, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, observed recently that "opportunities for tax reduction do not come often in a nation's lifetime." WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--The American Negro is now caught in an ironical situation. In his fight in Congress for equality, he is now being hurt not only by his ancient enemies but by his exuberant friends.

Record sales and higher steel prices swelled profits of the Inland steel Company in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

LONDON, Oct. 23 A huge expansion of Britain's higher education system was proposed today to give more students access to a university education and help the nation "meet the competitive pressures of the modern world."
The Department of Justice continued its investigation of the steel industry yesterday with the impaneling in Federal court here, of a special grand jury.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 Governor Rockefeller insisted today that Senator Barry Goldwater had advocated that the United States withdraw from the United Nations. He quoted from three statements to support his point.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The space agency postponed today the launching of the Ranger 6 mooncraft until early next year.

The Board of Education said yesterday that its Advisory Committee on School Construction, composed of private architects and engineers, would examine "every single instance of alleged inefficiency" in the school building program.

Three trade associations representing 265 insurance companies throughout the country agreed yesterday to end an alleged conspiracy to channel damaged automobiles to appraisers and repair shops they controlled.
HARRISBURG, Oct. 23 (AP) Col. Jorge A. Canaves beat Hugo Arambide in an all-Argentine international jumping final tonight at the Pennsylvania national horse show.
The Esterhazy Orchestra, founded and conducted by David Blum, began its third season last night in Town Hall.

MIAMI, Oct. 23 (UPI) A hurricane drifted closer to the central east coast of Florida tonight. The Weather Bureau said it was withholding hurricane warnings because of the "minimal intensity of the storm," designated Ginny.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Treasury announced today its financing plans for the rest of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration gave its belated public blessing today to Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s becoming a major stockholder and director of a Texas bank near the new Manned Spacecraft Center.

Importers here are asking for 90 days of grace to complete import transactions before the United States imposes any retaliatory duties against the European Common Market countries for raising the duty on United States chicken.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Secretary of State Dean Rusk and two Predecessors shared honors tonight at the dedication of the new home of the School of Advanced International Studies at The Johns Hopkins University.
Two, and possibly three, "very important" indictments are expected to be handed up in the next week by the grand jury investigating corruption in the administration of the state's liquor controls.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Airlines and aircraft manufacturers attacked today what they called the "staggering risks" posed by the Government's requirement that they share the cost of developing a supersonic transport.

Net income of Philip Morris, Inc., rose slightly in the third quarter to $5,952,000, or $1.60 a share, from $5,947,000, or $1.58 a share, in the same period last year, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president, announced yesterday.
Josef Krips will conduct the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall at 8:30 tonight. Jerome Lowenthal will be piano soloist.

IN Jessica Mitford's incisive indictment of the flamboy ant commercialism of some funerals, told in her book entitled "The American Way of Death," there were no pictorial illustrations. "C.B.S. Reports" corrected the oversight last night in a documentary called "The Great American Funeral."
If you can't lick 'em, join 'em." Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the Chicago North Western Railway, is endeavoring to reverse that adage. He is in a fighting mood.

Amory H. Bradford, former vice president and general manager of The New York Times, was appointed yesterday as assistant general business manager of Scripps-Howard Newspapers.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 23 (Reuters) The United States "ship American" principle came under heavy criticism today from the influential Norwegian Journal of Commerce and Shipping, which said United States shipping discrimination amounted to a Marshall Plan in reverse.

The advertising fraternity, which takes special pride in its ability to change the habits of the American housewife, now is trying to erase one especially well entrenched belief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Representative Bill Stinson, Republican of Washington, said today that correspondence between former Navy Secretary Fred Korth and the Fort Worth, Tex., bank he once headed may be evidence that Mr. Korth broke the law.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 23 The longest losing streak of the current meeting at Roosevelt Raceway terminated tonight, when Jim Grundy steered Worthy K. to victory in the first race.
HAYATO IKEDA has been termed too logical a man to be a good Japanese politician.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 Henry Garfinkle, the largest single stockholder of The Boston Herald Traveler Corporation, has formed a voting trust in order to set at rest rumors of a change in management.
The right of the Board of Education to revoke a teacher's license because he refused to participate in civil defense shelter drills was upheld yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.

All the fighting over the civil rights legislation in the House Judiciary Committee is being done by the friends of civil rights against one another. For an understanding of this bizarre battle, it is helpful to look both backward and forward.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 Negro leaders hailed today a one-day boycott of Chicago public schools as a national victory for civil rights. They promised further mass action against racial segregation in the school system here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Supreme Court took under advisement today one of the most important international law cases to come before it in recent years.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI) Rear Adm. Irving Hall Mayfield, retired World War II logistics expert, died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 78 years old.

New York University will celebrate the opening of a vast library of rare books and manuscript in new and comfortable quarters at 13-19 University Place today. In a deeper sense, the occasion will be more like a dedication.
The American Can Company showed a sharp drop in sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.
All sectors of the Government securities market advanced yesterday in more active trading.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Dr. Olaus J. Murie, a leading naturalist and supporter of wilderness preservation, died Monday at Jackson, Wyo. He was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) A Senate subcommittee today turned down a request for an on-site investigation of the detention of four civil rights demonstrators in Americas, Ga.
Reports were confirmed yesterday that Tallulah Bankhead would return to Broadway in the revised version of Tennessee Williams's "The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Any More."

Alumni of the Peace Corps will be invited to continue to serve the public by joining the domestic battle against racial discrimination, Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative to the United Nations, said yesterday.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 23 (AP) Spending on space projects is an investment in education, James E. Webb, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said today.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23 Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary for special political affairs, was sharply critical today of Negro "carriers" of the "racist virus" as well as white supremacists.
FINN JUHL, creator of a sculptured teak chair that, in 1948, introduced Danish modern furniture in New York, is appalled by the change to traditional furniture he observes in this country.

Several months ago seven West Side families, distressed at the thought of moving from their neighborhood to make way for improvements, came up with a "dream" plan whereby they could have comfortable homes in their area.
NEIL SIMON is a droll fellow, and not only has he spun "Barefoot in the Park" into a bubbling, rib-tickling comedy but has also brought off the neat trick of a running gag about walking.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 Premier Hayato Ikeda dissolved the Diet (Parliament) today in preparation for a general election to be held on Nov. 21. His action had been expected for some time and all of Japan's major parties have already begun preparations for the campaign.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is prodding the Administration to carry out "a major reorganization" of the nation's foreign aid program. It suggests that the United States shift most of its aid for economic development away from the traditional bilateral approach to a multilateral basis, operating through the World Bank and other international agencies.

More than $4,700,000 was disbursed by the New York Foundation, one of the country's oldest philanthropies, during the five years from 1958 to 1962, it was reported yesterday. Most of it went to organizations in the New York metropolitan area.
ALGIERS, Oct. 23 The Al gerians won Emperor Haile Selassie's approval today for an "extraordinary session" of African foreign ministers to take up the nine-day-old AlgerianMoroccan border conflict.
SALZBURG, Austria, Oct. 23 The International Air Transport Association is having another go here at reducing transAtlantic fares.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The "Bobby Baker case," which has stirred up more gossip and speculation over influence peddling than anything else in years, moved closer to clarification today.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has withheld its approval from six of the candidates for judicial office whose names will appear on the voting machines in the Nov. 5 election.
Seven men, including two known hoodlums were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to transport and negotiate a stolen stock certificate valued at $27,000.
A winning bid of about 2 cent per $1,000 landed a Chase Manhattan Bank syndicate $118,700,000 of New York City bonds yesterday. However, the auction cost the city
PARIS, Oct. 23 Francisque Gay, a founder of the Christian Democratic movement in France died here today of a heart attack. He was 78 years old.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 23 The price of gasoline and other petroleum derivatives rose to 30 from 27 per cent today throughout Brazil.
Miss Judith Lee Lewis and Dr. Morris H. Lampert will be married on Saturday night by Rabbi Lewis Statlow in Temple Emanuel, New Hyde Park, L.I.

PARIS. THE Regie Renault has gone into the snack bar business on the Champs Elysees, which is like General Motors opening up a French bistro in Times Square. The snack bar, called the Pub Renault, is in the car showroom at 33 Champs Elysees. It is open from 9 A.M. to 2 A.M. for the night life crowd.
SPESBACH, Germany, Oct. 23 Troops of the Second Armored Division, a few hours after having been flown in from Fort Hood, Tex., began loading ammunition today aboard tanks drawn from stocks here.
Three men with criminal records pleaded the Fifth Amendment yesterday rather than testify before a Bronx grand jury investigating an underworld loan-shark racket that lent $4 million a year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge is scheduled to return from Saigon shortly to confer with President Kennedy on the military and political situation in South Vietnam.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham told 750 Protestant ministers yesterday that "something tremendous" was happening to both Protestantism and Roman Catholicism. He defined this as an "awakening" of reform and revival within Christianity.

The Lincoln Center Repertory Theater, which will constitute part of the multimillion-dollar cultural complex at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, held its first rehearsal yesterday in a large and prosaic hall above a Second Avenue dairy restaurant.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 22 The United States Steel Corporation, the largest employer in Birmingham, appears to be making significant strides in opening up Negro job opportunities in its Alabama plants.

All five of Canada's maritime unions have been put under Government trusteeship in the expectation that the trustees can end the labor warfare that has disrupted Canadian shipping on the Great Lakes and has imperiled friendly relations between that country and this.
Canada's serious maritime labor crisis appeared to have ended last night after a series of rapid-fire developments.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 24 Col. Osvaldo Lopez Arellano, chief of the Honduran military government, said today he had no wish to continue in public life once his country had been returned to constitutional government.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Ann King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. King of Tidioute, Pa., to William Zeckendorf Jr. of New York and Mount Kisco, N.Y., president of Webb Knapp, Inc., took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Irving Kolodin of New York and William Zeckendorf.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Department-store sales in the week ended Oct. 19, were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 (AP) Nine integration leaders were fined and sentenced to jail today for defying a state injunction against interfering with business at the Jefferson Bank and Trust Co. here.
Exhibit A., the fine jumper owned by Frank Manheim's Overbridge Stable, had what amounted to a walkover in record-breaking time on the United Hunts program at Aqueduct yesterday.
THE Metropolitan Championships begin today at the New York Hilton Hotel and will continue through Sunday.

LONDON, Oct, 24 Every So often legends are supposed to become reality. One had a chance at Covent Garden tonight when Rudolf Nureyev danced the title role in "Petruchka" for the first time. The legend obstinately remained a legend, but the performance was far from disappointing.
CIRCLING around the huge runway at the Belgrade fair grounds each night this week are a score of skinny girls from Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and West and East Germany.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24 Gov. J. Millard Tawes commuted the death sentences of three young Negroes to life imprisonment today. They had been doomed for the rape of a 16-year-old white girl.

GENEVA, Oct. 24 The International Cocoa Conference ended five weeks of closed-door meetings here today without reaching a hoped-for-agreement to stabilize the market and prevent extreme price fluctuations.

Electronics called the turn on yesterday's strong market, with Chrysler supplying the drive. Bullish news, plus Chrysler's somewhat unexpected two-forone split and a doubling of its dividend, were all that the market required to boom ahead in active trading. All popular averages rose.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24 (AP) A United States Air Force transport carrying four Americans and four Vietnamese crashed today while it was on a flare-dropping mission over the Mekong River delta. All aboard apparently were killed. The wreckage burned.
BEING up the creek, even without a paddle, is no disgrace for a pleasure boat in a hurricane. In fact, it's one of the best places to be.
An application filed six months ago to establish a national bank at 25th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan was approved yesterday by James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency.
Yogi Berra broke two records merely by lining out in his only appearance as a player during the recent World Series.
The cost of the Consolidated Edison Company's nuclear plant at Indian Point, N.Y., should not be passed on to consumers of electricity, the New York City Housing Authority contended yesterday.
The Chilean National Ballet and Ar Irang, a Korean dance company, will make their first United States tours in the fall of 1964 under the direction of Columbia Artists Management.

Rubin (Hurricane) Carter of Paterson and Joey Archer of New York are expected to draw a crowd of 9,000 and a gate of $35,000 at Madison Square Garden tonight for their 10-round, nontelevised middleweight fight.
ROME, Oct. 24 The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States took a strong stand for racial equality today at the Ecumenical Council.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 24 Even the serene and historic surroundings of Deerfield Academy's vast campus seems to be undergoing a slight change of tempo in this busy age of automation, jet travel and Telstar.

ALGIERS, Oct. 24 President Ahmed Ben Bella announced tonight that Col. Mohand ou el Hadj, a leader of the Kabyle rebellion, had joined the Government in its fight with Morocco. He was said to have led troops to the border.

The Secretary of the Navy, who has resigned, saw nothing wrong with advancing, from his prestigious position, the interests of the bank he once headed. So has the secretary of the Senate majority who had astonishing success in getting vending machine contracts from firms doing business with the Government.
Third-quarter net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation rose to $12,893,349 or $1.16 a share, from $10,637,776 or 96 cents a share, in the 1962 period.

The six-day ocean voyage made by seven members of the Legislature at the expense of the New York State Association of Savings Banks or of member banks will be discussed next Wednesday by Republican leaders of the Legislature.

"Spoon River," the drama now playing at the Booth Theater, will be taped early next month for presentation on paytelevision in Hartford, Conn.
PARIS, Oct. 24 Richard M. Nixon said today that the West was in the process of forming a much looser federation political, military and economic "than we thought was right 10 year's ago."
Conditions in the New York money market eased this week but the change did not show up in the Federal Reserve's weekly figures for the national banking system.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 The Ciudad de Valencia, 5,885ton Venezuelan freighter, sailed for New York today after having been idle at a Delaware River pier for three days under a writ of attachment.

Justin K. Thannhauser, who has given an impressive gift of 75 paintings, including 34 Picassos, to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, said yesterday, "I hope it will be appreciated. It's my whole life."
Dr. Samuel Harris Averbuck, a specialist in internal medicine and cardiology, died Wednesday in his home, 1192 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

The mother and the quadruplets who were born Wednesday night at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center were "doing fine last night, but the father of the three girls and one boy reported that he was confused and very weary.
The Maritime Administration rejected yesterday a proposal for building three big containerships for the country's intercoastal trade.

The hydrant-shaped folk hero called Yogi Berra is a cuddly noble savage who lusts after comic books, innocently scratches himself in public, loves children and dogs, exudes natural humor and swings down from his tree house to excel in a game he would happily play for nothing.

Is there no way to compel our indefatigable New York legislators to take a rest from state work while Albany is in recess? First it was Assemblyman Plumadore's Joint Committee on Physical Fitness, whose members insisted on slaving away at Toots Shor's and in faraway Las Vegas, at state expense.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24 Not since Navy played Army here during the Second World War has Annapolis staged a football game that has excited as much interest as the one coming up with Pittsburgh.

Representatives of 25 nations attended a City Hall ceremony yesterday in observance of the 18th anniversary of the United Nations. Mayor Wagner issued a proclamation designating the day as United Nations Day.
The Canadian dollar rose yesterday in trading on the New York foreign exchange market.
Cotton futures closed yesterday unchanged to up 25 cents a bale on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Gaston Espinal remained in control of the Dominican Republic consulate in Rockefeller Center yesterday after a State Supreme Court justice stayed an arrest proceeding pending a hearing Monday.

Saw Dr. Josh Antonio Correa, new Ambassador of Ecuador; signed Mental Retardation Bill; addressed luncheon meeting of the National Association for Retarded Children, Mayflower Hotel; met with Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (UPI) Despite the great rise in freight rates since the Communist countries started to buy huge tonnages of grain in the West, 328 ships of 2,182,103 tons are still laid up in ports around the world for lack of work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Intercity truck, tonnage in the week ended Oct. 19 was 2 per cent above the volume in the corresponding week of 1962. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported this was the third consecutive week truck tonnage was gained on a year-to-year basis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The apparent disappearance of discussion and controversy over "the new kind of inflation," "administered prices" and "cost push" is a striking aspect of present Washington economic life.
WASHTNGTON, Oct. 24 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has disclosed that in 1945 he believed dropping an atomic bomb on Japan was "completely unnecessary."

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Sandy Koufax the Los Angeles Dodgers' left-hander who almost lost a finger and his baseball career a year ago today became the first unanimous, winner of the Cy Young Award as the major leagues outstanding pitcher.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The House Republican leader served notice on the Senate today that the Administration's foreigin aid authorization bill would be in "serious jeopardy" if it is increased substantially over the $3.5 billion voted by the House.

Mayor Wagner won a promise at City Hall yesterday from the parents of 500 school children who have been boycotting a Brooklyn school to send their youngsters back to their classes if school repairs proved satisfactory.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) The first shipment of Canadian wheat has been unloaded in the Black Sea port of Odessa, Izvestia reported today.
Commissioner Anna M. Kross opened the gates of the Women's House of Detention yesterday to show the press what a terrible place it is.
TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 24 (AP) Hans Natonek, a European journalist, novelist and poet, died here yesterday at the age of 71.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Col. Stig Wennerstrom, being held here on charges of spying for the Soviet Union, was rushed to a hospital today after taking poison in his cell.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Prospects for Federal aid to colleges this year brightened today when the way was opened for negotiations over differences between the Senate and House.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UPI) Soybeans closed mixed, wheat futures ended strong, and other grains moved narrowly today on the Board of Trade.
HARTFORD, Oct. 24 Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona declared today that he would accept the Republican nomination for President if he is offered it by the Republican National Convention next summer.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 Long lines of art fans have become a weekend feature at the Los Angeles. County Museum of Art since the opening, of the exhibition of Mexican art masterpieces on Oct. 2.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The difference between what public men here say in public and what they say in private is greater today than at any time since the war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Two more sales of corn to Hungary totaling nearly $2.4 million were approved today.

MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 24 King Hassan II warned President Ben Bella today that he was playing with fire in employing "psychological tactics of lies, insults and accusations" against brother Arabs of North Africa.

Record quarterly earnings were achieved by United Air Lines for the second time this year in the three months ended Sept. 30, W.A. Patterson, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 24 Lord Nathan of Churt, a leader of Britain's organized Jews, died in London's Westminster Hospital today of complications following an appendectomy. He was 74 years old.
Sugar futures fell sharply in late trading yesterday, but most other New York commodities scored moderate gains on the day.

IN the fashion industry, where a sense of personal drama is considered part of a designer's tools of the trade, Mme. Alix Gres is an original. She lets her work spear for itself. For 30 years she has been the classicist of the Paris couture.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor and builder, has contracted to sell the taxpayer containing 10 stores at 221-13 to 221-25 Linden Boulevard, corner of 222d Street, in Queens Village. The property, which has a plot of about 200 by 100 feet, includes a parking lot. The major tenant is Vamco Automatic Dry Cleaners, which occupies 5,000 square feet.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 24 Maclean Kirkwood, a retired electrical engineer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 72 years old.
A September decline of $428,000,000, or 6 per cent, in the volume of commercial paper outstanding was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

GRINNELL, Iowa, Oct. 24 (UPI) With all the pep of a college freshmen, former President Harry S. Truman laughingly absorbed a whack from an initiation paddle today and shrugged off a tumble into a clump of campus shrubbery.
Leaders of the Liberal party believe they are posing a challenge to Governor Rockefeller's Presidential hopes in the oddman-out campaign for councilmen at large in Manhattan.
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 24 Charles A. Holcomb, vice president and a director of the Kudner Agency, Inc., a New York advertising company, died today in his home at 6 Woodland Drive. His age was 67.

Not long ago President Kennedy complained on television that people often talked about the "Kennedy bear market," but they seldom mentioned anything about a Kennedy bull market. Yesterday someone did.

A line of customers that kept expanding yesterday at the Biltmore Theater, where "Barefoot in the Park" opened Wednesday night, and the demand at the ticket agencies was sufficient proof that Broadway's first smash of the season had arrived. All of the six local drama critics had commended Neil Simon's comedy.
PINEHURBT, N.C., Oct. 24 (AP) Ada McKenzie of Richmond Hill, Ont., won the North and South senior women's golf tournament today with a 54hole total of 235.
BACK in the old days Casey Stengel used a flippant reference whenever he spoke of his favorite ballplayer, Yogi Berra. Ol' Case didn't first-name him or last-name him.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 Argentina declared today she would go ahead with plans to cancel contracts with American oil companies here, even if it means loss of Alliance for Progress aid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 A Russian and an American physicist were given the Atoms for Peace Award this evening. They were honored for their independent discovery of the principle that made possible powerful atomic particle accelerators for exploring the heart of the atom.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 24 Eight 3-year-old pacers today were named to start in the eighth annual Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway on Nov. 2. With the owner of each standardbred posting $1,500 as the starting fee, the mile race will offer a purse of $146,324.87, the second-richest in the history of the event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Representative Earl Wilson charged today that Assistant Navy Secretary Kenneth M. Belieu had gives false information to a congressional committee and should be dismissed unless he had a satisfactory explanation.
The Cleveland City School District raised $10,000,000 yesterday in the bond market.
The police said yesterday that a 17-year-old boy had confessed to the murder of a cab driver in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn late Wednesday night.
Investigations of traffic deaths by public agencies are "a national disgrace," according to a team of Harvard University researchers.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Oct. 24 Without mishap the United States completed the "Big Lift" of an armored division and supporting troops from Fort Hood, Tex., to West Germany tonight in a minute short of 63 hours. This was nine hours ahead of schedule.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 24, The Mormon Church appointed Ezra Taft Benson today president of its European Mission with headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 24 The alliance of Syria and Iraq is to become the nucleus for a proposed Baathist state to be known as the Arab Democratic People's Republic, according to decisions taken by the International Baathist Congress. Baghdad is to be the capital.

President Tito of Yugoslavia, who canceled a reception scheduled yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria, spent his last night in the country as a surprise guest at the United Nations Day Ball in the same hotel.

In the face of a continued, Arab military buildup, Israel under Premier Eshlcol appears to be adopting a more flexible, not to say conciliatory, policy. Like Mr. Ben-Gurion, his redoubtable predecessor, Mr. Eshkol has vainly appealed to the Arabs, especially to President Nasser, to make peace and has offered to meet any Arab leader at any time, anywhere, to discuss it.
Joseph. C. Bevis is a tall, dignified man who always has a mountain of statistics at his finger tips.

DALLAS, Oct. 24--Anti-United Nations demonstrators shoved, booed, beat and spat in the face of Adlai E. Stevenson, the chief United States delegate at the United Nations, tonight, following a speech he made here marking United Nations Day.

The Board of Education, which awards about $150 million worth of contracts each year for construction, equipment and supplies, is seeking the reason why relatively few business concerns are willing to do work for the city system.
CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct, 24 A medical examination showed today that a 61-year-old woman, thought to have died in a fire, had been strangled.
Drought conditions, water shortages and forest fires plagued the country yesterday from the Mississippi Valley to New England.
ST-NOM-LA-BRETECHE, France, Oct. 24 The largest crowd ever to see a golf match in France about 5,000 persons watched the start of the Canada Cup tournament today.
A confident Treasury securities market swept forward again yesterday in more active trading. Dealers said business appeared to be "more normal than in recent weeks."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 President Kennedy signed a $355 million bill today to combat mental retardation.

A dispute between Roger Euster, owner of the Little Theater, and members of the stagehands' union, Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, brought the sudden cancelation of last night's rehearsal of "Tambourines to Glory." The Negro play with music, by Langston Hughes and Jobe Huntley, had been scheduled to open there Nov. 2.

IT takes a fashion, for clothes or a hair style, at least a few months to jell. Suddenly the evolutionary period is over, and a new style has arrived. Right now, last summer's hairdo looks as outmoded as last summer's hat.

The lawyer for a bookstore accused of selling a copy of "Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure" to a 16-year-old girl argued in court yesterday that a state penal law, 484-H, violates Constitutional guarantee of freedon of expression.
NINETY years ago Anthony Trollope was at work with his usual industry on one of his longest and most inter esting novels. "The Way We Live Now."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Most of the meteoroids in space appear to be fluffy flakes of dust from decaying comets rather than dense chunks of metallic rock, a Harvard astronomer said today.

Health Department inspectors were searching the city last night for two brands of canned pork liver patd packed in Canada and believed responsible for the botulism death of a boy in Montreal on Sunday. Three other youngsters who ate the pate are in serious condition in Montreal hospitals.

EVERYBODY prays for rain, but in "110 in the Shade" there is not much more than tears. Although this new musical play, which opened last night, is as dry as the parched land outside the Broadhurst Theater, there is no danger that even a lightning bolt could ignite it.
A Federal grand jury indicted four union officials yesterday on charges of embezzling more than $50,000 in union funds.
"Manon" will be given at the Metropolitan Opera at 8 tonight.
BONN, Oct. 24 Chancellor Erhard received a polite warning from the ranks of his own party today against "false illusions" on the prospects for relaxation of international tensions.
LONDON, Oct. 24 Parliament recessed today until Nov. 12 after a bitter attack by the Labor and Liberal parties on Sir Alec Douglas-Home's decision to postpone the reopening from Oct. 29.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 Premier Khrushchev sent a letter today to Premier Fidel Castro promising large-scale assistance to help Cuba recover from the extensive damage caused by the recent hurricane that struck the island.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 A surgeon told the American Heart Association here today about an operation he has performed on six patients to reduce the amount of cholesterol in the blood.

The Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia said yesterday that the demonstrations here against President Tito had been staged by "professional terrorists" who collaborated with German occupation forces during World War II.
THE New York City Opera, which had "Don Giovan ni" in its repertory from 1947 to 1954, brought back the Mozart opera last night in a new production.
Like any woman with something else on her mind, Mrs. Marie Cirile made a slight traffic error yesterday she drove the wrong way up a oneway street.

John Exter, a senior vice president of the First National City Bank, said yesterday that the United States could solve its balance-ofpayments problems if the Federal Reserve halted what ha called its policy of easy money.

"Louis the Hat," a wearylooking man of 63 with steelgray hair and a mouth that turns down at the corners, told yesterday how he had faked evidence against himself for a ritual arrest by the yonkers police.

The London stock market was buoyed yesterday by good financial reports from leading industrials.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP) Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino charged tonight that the statements of four Englishmen had been distorted in Mayor Wagner's report on legalized gambling.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations called for major changes in the Administration's tax bill today, but urged quick action on the measure.
Nearly half of the country's airborne foreign trade last year passed through Idlewild Airport, the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) An agreement making Federal aid available for a wide variety of services to elderly people in public housing projects was signed today.

Lehigh will attempt to toss Columbia off balance on Saturday with two sophomore quarterbacks who can throw. They have been splitting the assignment this season and together they hope to outdo Archie Roberts.

Herman Robiliart, one of Belgium's leading industrialists, died of a heart attack in Brussels on Oct. 17. He was 68 years old. His death was made known yesterday by the BelgoAmerican Development Corporation.

Amendment 5 to the State Constitution, which will be submitted to the voters for ratification on Nov. 5, would grant municipalities throughout the state the right to borrow money outside their debt limits for construction of sewage facilities.

WITH little chance of the drought's being broken over the weekend so that the woods and marshes can be reopened for gunning purposes, those with a consuming need to be outdoors might do worse than pick up a fishing rod.
Disorders in the Katanga region of the Congo are creating serious problems for Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga in a continuing number of resignations of its European and African employes.
Amid all the fanfare usually reserved for a visiting potentate, Lawrence Peter (Yogi) Berra was named yesterday as manager of the New York Yankees.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 Governor Rockefeller all but officially announced today his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964.
HARRISBURG, Oct. 24 (AP) Dr. Hugo Arrambide of Argentina won the "gambler's choice" tonight in international jumping competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP) The Philadelphia Eagles signed Ralph Guglielmi today, bolstering their quarterback corps for Sunday's National Football League game with the Chicago Bears in Chicago.

"PENNY CHANGE," a play by Helen Eisner that opened last night at the Players, is about a woman named Henny. What a complicated soul she is, and what a complicated way her creator has chosen to tell her doleful tale a mixture of fantasy and realism that emerges as one of the major mishmashes of the off Broadway season.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 24 Giorgos S. Seferiades, a former Greek diplomat noted for poetry written under the pen name of Giorgos Seferis, has won the 1963 Nobel Prize in Literature.
The Philadelphia String Quartet, for its debut here last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, offered the first of a series of six programs, each to present one work by Beethoven, Bartok and Schoenberg.
LONDON, Oct. 24 Sir Charles Snow, the author, said today that a "third culture" was rising to bridge the widening gap between the scientific and literary communities.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 African and Asian representatives called today for a meeting of the Security Council to consider new action against the racial policies of South Africa.

H.L. Hunt of Texas, one of the world's richest men, complained yesterday that he had been "pressured and taken in" by Robert Moses. ON the sixth floor of 27 West 23d Street, two men pace like acrobats across a rope walk, a weaver treadles his loom with the footwork of an organist and a young woman wraps a hula skirt of fringe around a wood tassel.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes was hospitalized yesterday for what his physician described as "complete exhaustion."
A milk strike deadline was extended to today after labor negotiations bogged down and were suspended at 11 o'clock last night.

Henry Crown, chairman of the finance committee of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, said yesterday that the line might have "to go it alone" should plans to merge into the Union Pacific Railroad fail.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 24 An aura of hope and well-being, probably unequaled since Oct. 24, 1945, when the United Nations came into existence, was in evidence today on the organization's 18th anniversary.
The first man to be convicted in the 15-month-old investigation into frauds involving highway construction received a suspended sentence, yesterday in State Supreme Court.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum organization, reported yesterday for the nine months to Sept. 30, a record consolidated net income of $773,000,000, or $3.57 a share.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The search for a way out of the impasse on civil rights legislation continued without apparent results today.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) Harry Howell, a defenseman, and Howie Glover, a wing, scored their first goals of the season tonight and gave Jacques Plante and the New York Rangers a 2-0 shutout victory over the Boston Bruins.

THE American child can look as elegant as his European cousin if his mother shops at Ohrbach's. The store's Young Import collection has clothes from Spain, Italy, Switzerland, France, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and England, as well as a charming contribution from Ireland. Sizes run from infant through 6x.
A half-dozen types of illnesses have been linked to air pollution in a United States Senate staff study, including one that appears to kill eight times as many men as women.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Since Shakespeare said it first, the men of Kennedy can only second the motion: How distressing these "cankers of a calm world and a long peace."

Few conductors seem to have as much unadulterated fun on the job as Josef Krips. Mr. Krips returned to the New York Philharmonic as a guest last night after one season's absence. He will be here for eight weeks, and it's good to have him back.
Robert Moses challenged the "economic royalists" of Fifth Avenue yesterday to support the rebuilding of New York's less elegant areas.
MIAMI, Oct. 24 (AP) The season's seventh hurricane lashed the north Florida and Georgia coasts with gales today and took a northern tack that threatened the Carolinas.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 24 An official of the Kennedy Administration charged today that an attempt by Governor Rockefeller to build an image pleasing to "Republican die-hards" had resulted in the stagnation of New York State's economy.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 24 (UPI) Mason, Rudolph, who has been out of the money only once this year, shot a six-underpar 66 today for the first-round lead in the $25,000 Fig Garden Village open golf tournament.

Amos Basel, the Liberal candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan, said yesterday that an "interlocking directorate" between the World's Fair Corporation and the Transit Authority was spending public money "without public scrutiny."
The Chrysler Corporation, a heavy money-loser only four years ago, underscored its comeback yesterday on several fronts.

The first of three programs scheduled this season by the United States National Committee of the International Folk Music Council was given last night at the Mannes College of Music. Jean Ritchie, Kentuckyborn singer, and 16 members of the Country Dance Society of America were the performers.
DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UPI) The board of directors of the Detroit Lions voted unanimously today to accept William Clay Ford's $6,000,000 offer for the National Football League franchise.

LONDON,. Oct. 25 (AP) Medical researchers say they have found laboratory evidence that the growth of human cells is slowed by sodium fluoride.
ALGIERS, Oct. 25 President Ahmed Ben Bella agreed tonight to meet King Hassan II of Morocco and five other African leaders to discuss the Algerian-Moroccan border cunflict.

ROME, Oct. 25 Pietro Nenni, leader of the Italian Socialist party, asked the party today to authorize direct participation in a center-left Government.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 25 The failure of the Soviet Union's effort to influence the Arab states of the Middle East was stressed here today by experts on the region.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 25 The United States plans to follow up its successful transAtlantic Big Lift next year with two more difficult airlifts of Army divisions. One will cross the Pacific to the Far East and another will fly to the Middle East.
The Metropolitan Opera will present "La Boh me" at 2 today and "Don Giovanni" at 8 tonight.

THE Moys, the Engs, the Wongs, the Wus and the Lees have deep feelings of family responsibility. It is reflected in the exemplary behavior of their children, who attend Public School 23, 70 Mulberry Street, in Chinatown.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 25 President Victor Paz Estenssoro of Bolivia told the General Assembly today that an outlet to the sea and stabilized prices for raw materials were essential to the development of his country.

Eight prominent Broadway playwrights have agreed to write plays for a nonprofit project designed to stimulate and develop the production of serious drama in university and community theaters across the nation.
Prices of some world sugar contracts rebounded yesterday, leading a broad upturn in commodities markets here.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) The United States won the Prix des Nations at the Pennsylvania national horse show tonight in a test so difficult that three riders were thrown, a horse was injured and only one competitor had a faultless round.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 23 Emerging from a meeting between the European Common Market and British Cabinet Ministers, this morning, Britain's new Foreign Secretary, Richard A. Butler, reported "a very successful morning, with a very good atmosphere emanating from all sides."
Spain received her first loan yesterday from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

About 100 leaders of the fashion industry contributed over $15,000 yesterday, in memory of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Wiltwyck School, a center for disturbed boys. The proceeds will be used for operating costs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 A bitter controversy over the promotion of three Negroes to supervisory positions in the Dallas Post Office has been settled by reassigning the Negroes to other jobs at no loss in pay.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The Kennedy Administration pursued a course of quiet persuasion today in hope of achieving a consensus by Tuesday on a House civil rights bill.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) Defense experts watched in amazement today as a tiny "flying motorcycle" helicopter leaped straight up at almost rocket speed, hundreds of feet above the Pentagon building.
Joey Archer, a classic boxer from the Bronx, took the best punches of the slugging Rubin (Hurricane) Carter last night in Madison Square Garden and earned a split decision.
A grande dame made her debut here last night at a party without a theme and without inspiration from season or city, but attended by those who love her a group both conservative and social.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The diversified business interests of Robert G. Baker, former majority secretary of the Senate and a protege of Vice President Johnson, were disclosed today to have included a struggling Capitol Hill Travel agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Administrator denied today that any admission of guilt by his agency was implied in the Government's decision to pay 24 per cent of the lawsuits arising out of history's worst air disaster.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--Efforts to stave off repeal of the 4 per cent tax credit on income from dividends got under way in the Senate Finance Committee today.

THE McCall Corporation, which publishes McCall's, with a monthly circulation of more than 8,000,000, and Redbook, with a circulation hovering around 3,000,000, signed contracts last week to buy The Bridge World, a magazine whose circulation once reached a peak of 18,350.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) Mason Rudolph strengthened his bid for a victory in the $25,000 Fresno open golf tournament today when he fired a five-under-par 67 for a 133 total and a five-stroke lead at the halfway mark.

Directors of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc. declared an extra dividend yesterday of 20 cents on the company's common stock, together with a regular quarterly dividend of 60 cents. The dividends are payable Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 4.
Profits of the Armco Steel Corporation in the third quarter this year doubled those of the 1962 quarter.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (UPI) The New York Knicks gained their first victory of the National Basketball Association season by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, 136 112, tonight after trailing by 14 points early in the third period.
Mitchell Andrews, pianist who made his solo debut here in 1960, came to Town Hall for another recital last night and showed that in some kinds of music, at least, he is one of our major pianists.

A tobacco farmer from the Tennesse hills whose musical career began about 1910 on the horse-drawn wagon of a traveling medicine show is making his New York night club debut at Gerde's Folk City, 11 West Fourth Street.

President Tito sailed for Britain yesterday aboard the Holland-America liner Rotterdam after a visit to New York punctuated by incidents, recriminations over police security and finally by a bomb scare that delayed his departure 40 minutes.

The adoption of a world calendar and the fixing of Easter on a specific day in it, as proposed yesterday at the Vatican Council in Rome, have long been considered one of the most promising areas of exploration by those seeking to reunite the Christian churches.

MOSCOW, Oct, 25 Indications mounted tonight that the Soviet Government was planning to stage a major show trial of many persons accused of forming an embezzlement and speculation ring led by two Jews.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The National Conference on Medical Quackery, sponsored by the Food and Drug Administration and the American Medical Association, opened here today.
The last regularly operating steam locomotive in the East died yesterday.
The New York Board of Rabbis has asked its 800 members in the metropolitan area to pay special tribute in their sermons today to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

Demands for a more definitive state code of ethics grew yesterday as a result of the ocean voyage taken by seven members of the Legislature and their wives. Their six-day cruise was paid for by the Savings Banks Association of New York State or member banks.

CAIRO, Oct. 25 Award of the Nobel literary prize to Giorgos Seferiades reminds us pleasantly that great poets, even in complex modern days, need not divorce themselves from the world in order to nourish their genius. And, strangely enough, diplomacy seems the trade best suited to encouraging their muse.

Charles C. Baldwin, an author and newspaperman, died Wednesday at Will Rogers Memorial Hospital in Saranac Lake, N. Y. He was 75 years old and lived at 346 East 18th Street.
A $12,799,336 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against the New York World's Fair 1964-65 Corporation. Two other corporations and an individual also were named defendants.
A state investigation of the city's Women's Home of Detention was threatened yesterday by the chairman of the New York State Assembly Standing committee on the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara rejected today the Navy's request for a second nuclear-powered aircraft carrier. He ordered construction of a conventionally powered ship.

HOUSTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The Manned Spacecraft Center said today that a Connecticut concern had been asked to study and design a one-man rocket-powered device for movement in space and on the surface of the moon.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25 The Canadian Government announced measures today to increase the production of automobiles and parts at home and for sales abroad. The move is designed to make Canadian products more competitively priced in foreign markets, primarily in the United States.

BONN, Oct. 25 Princess Clementine von Metternich-Sandor, last surviving grandchild of the Austrian statesman who organized the Congress of Vienna, died Tuesday at Schloss Corvey in lower Saxony, it was disclosed today. She was 94 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 The 41st annual season of opera in San Francisco is nearing its end, and observers here say that it has probably been the most successful in its history. As at the Metropolitan Opera, most performances play to sold-out houses, with standees jamming the back areas, and with beseeching would-be customers crowding the box office every evening.

Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday a record net income of $384,514,000, or $3.02 a share, for the first nine months of this year. This is an increase of 13.2 per cent over net earnings of $339,598,000, or $2.66 a share, in the corresponding period of 1962.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The General Electric Company will receive a patent next week for its tiny new computer, the GEVIC, designed for aerospace purposes, including navigation and course control.
ROME, Oct. 25 The Ecumenical Council took a first step today toward expressing the willingness of the Roman Catholic Church to accept a fixed Sunday for Easter.

DALLAS, Oct. 25 City leaders, reacting with indignation and shame, apologized today to Adlai E. Stevenson, who was struck and spat upon here yesterday. One hundred civic and business leaders sent a telegram to Mr. Stevenson, the chief United States representative at the United Nations.

SOCTRANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 The mud-spattered hamlet of Tra Met a handful of sodden houses that rise a foot or two above the flooded rice paddies near here lies in the heart of the Mekong Delta, the lush rice bowl that has become the most critical battleground in South Vietnam's war against the Communist-supported Vietcong.
LONDON, Oct. 25 Premier Cheddi B. Jagan of British Guiana joined in a request to the British Government today to impose a constitution on his country.

Vigorous buying pushed the London Stock Exchange on to fresh gains yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct, 25 The trial by court-martial of former Premier Song Yo Chan on charges of murder and libel opened here today. It was recessed this afternoon to await a ruling by the Supreme Court on the legality of a military trial.

BROISTEDT, Germany, Oct. 25 (AP) Seven of 50 miners trapped in a flooded iron mine were rescued tonight. There was scant hope for the 43 others.

A sweeping change in the method of compensating school custodians will take effect Jan. 1, the Board of Education announced yesterday. The board said the change was intended to "correct the recently publicized exorbitant overpayments."

The New York Jets will be seeking their fourth straight home victory when they face the Denver Broncos in an American Football League game at the Polo Grounds tonight. The kickoff is scheduled for 8 o' clock.
Two of the bluest of the blue-chip issues helped push the stock market to historic highs yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 25 There are few midnight knocks on the door by the Security Police in South Africa. Sometimes there is only the late afternoon ringing of the telephone.

The 14,000 account holders in the Beverly Savings and Loan Association of Chicago, now in voluntary liquidation, will be able to get their money out in full, it was announced yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers, who meet the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight, made another addition to their everchanging squad yesterday by signing Gene Shue.

Stevenson by anti-United Nations demonstrators last night in Dallas might indicate that Texans were "fed up with persons who are soft on Communism."
