WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 25 Speedy Count, the colt who "couldn't lose" the Volomite Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, did, but it took an interference break to do it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration urged housewives across the nation today to destroy any smoked fish products they had under refrigeration unless they knew that the product had not come from fish caught in the Great Lakes or processed in plants in the Great Lakes area.

The April in Paris Ball, which has a reputation for being bigger, flashier and more expensive than the rest of New York's charity galas, lived up to expectations last night for the 12th successive season.

Six-story apartment houses, the high-rise buildings of yesteryear, are still making their modest contribution to New York's skyline. Although six-story structures have long since been over-shadowed by high-rise apartment buildings, they remain an important part of the city's residential inventory.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 26 --The United States Merchant Marine Academy defeated Wagner College, 14--13, today before a crowd of 5,142 on Homecoming Day at Captain Tomb Field.

It's likely to be in the neighborhood of 83,000, which is still a most attractive neighborhood.

Logan of Greenville, to Gardner Williams Mein took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's father. Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Mein of San Francisco are the parents of the bridegroom.

ABOUT three years ago Cynthia Cox wrote an engaging biography of the fifth Duke of Richelieu, a man whose outstanding characteristics were probity and devotion to the services of others. That the Duke appeared a little colorless was the fault of his qualities rather than of his biographer. The subject of her more recent biography possessed in abundance all those lively qualities that Richelieu lacked--and not a scintilla of his outstanding virtues.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 27 Participants in Columbia University's 24th American Assembly at Arden House urged the United States today to try to persuade the Arab states and Israel to agree to repatriation of the Palestinian refugees to Israel or to resettlement elsewhere.
SALZBURG, Austria, Oct. 27 (AP) The International Air Transport Association failed today to reach an agreement on a reduction in trans-Atlantic air fares.

A phenomenal young violinist made an unheralded debut yesterday afternoon at a "Trick or Treat" concert given at Town Hall by the New York Orchestral Society and dedicated to the 13th annual "Trick or Treat for UNICEF." The fund campaign for the United Nations Childrens Fund will be held Thursday.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 The Teamsters Union said today that an analysis of Federal statistics showed that the growth rate of personal incomes in New York had slowed down since Nelson A. Rockefeller became Governor.

Three 20,000-ton passenger liners that served with distinction under the United States flag in peace and in war have reached the end of the line.

Inflation remains entrenched as a way of life in Brazil. The economic policies just announced by Dr. Carvalho Pinto, Brazil's new Finance Minister, fail to give priority to halting the inflationary spiral. He is evidently planning to tinker with some of the pressure valves while neglecting to curb the boiler of Government spending, which is the source of the problem.
Regulations to implement the law barring unsafe tires in this state have been drafted by Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults. The pioneering legislation will go into effect Jan. 1.

TWENTY-THREE minutes in heavy traffic from the center of Paris, an iron gate at the end of a village gives access by land to a small island in the Marne. Down the path through the tangled undergrowth, a Louis XVI house emerges from the tall trees. Beyond it, a mill, its foundations dating from 1482, spans an arm of the river to overlook surrounding woods.

The evening of Oct. 31, 1950, a group of Philadelphia children donned masks of varying frightfulness and went out into the streets of their neighborhood. They knocked on doors and spoke the time-honored passwords of Halloween.

For many years Queens has been the most independent politically of any of the five boroughs. It has frequently swung back and forth between the Republican and Democratic parties. This year Queens is filling the highest elective office to he contested anywhere in the city.

A committee of the State Legislature published over the weekend the first tangible result of an inquiry on banking authorized in 1955. Completion of the inquiry is likely to take several years more.

Aqueduct returns to Aqueduct today with the start of the fall thoroughbred racing campaign here. For the last 24 days, the meet at the Big A had been called the Belmont-at-Aqueduct meeting.

The City Club of New York announced yesterday that all privately commissioned architectural projects completed in the city after Jan. 1, 1960, would be eligible for competition in the 1964 Bard Awards Program.

Gov. Henry Bellmon dedicated the new wing of the largely reconstructed institute and Dode McIntosh, chief of the Creek nation, gave the invocation.

SOME of the most beautiful scenery in the world is to be found where the vine grows, and California is no exception. To the north, east and south of San Francisco, among redwood trees and rolling hills, beside winding rivers or close to rugged, rocky coastal stretches, carefully tended vineyards contain all manner of vines and produce all manner of wines.

The Phoenix Theater will begin its new season on Nov. 25 with a new work by James Gaunders, "Next Time I'll Sing to You." It will supplant "The Imaginary Invalid," which has been placed in "abeyance." Peter Coe, who was to have staged "The Imaginary In valid," will direct Mr. Saunders's script.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27 President Joao Goulart announced today that he wanted Brazil's controversial remittance of profits law applied "rigorously" to limit dollar transfers abroad. BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 (AP) Elijah Pitts, one of two substitutes in the backfield, raced 34 yards for a touchdown late in the fourth quarter today to give the Green Bay Packers a 34-20 victory over the Baltimore Colts.
Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital and the Navy have an informal arrangement whereby Navy medical corpsmen work in the wards and operating rooms during their off hours.
The 1963 James. J. Hoey Awards for Interracial Justice were bestowed yesterday by the Catholic Interracial Council of New York on Dr. James T. Carey and Percy H. Williams
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 27 (AP) Cotton Davidson's 9yard scoring pass to Glenn Shaw today gave the Oakland Raiders a 34-33 American Football League victory over the San Diego Chargers.
State lawmakers are approaching the problem of enacting a stiffer code of ethics at their forthcoming legislative session with all the wariness of a small boy confronting a spoonful of castor oil.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 27 Mrs. Adelaine Hain wanted to attend her daughter Jo-Anne's 10th birthday party here the other day, but it was illegal for her to be there.

There are 2,804 ships of 1,000 gross tons or more in the nation's fleet of merchant ships. But only 911 of them are in the active fleet, and of that total 896 are privately owned and 15 are owned by the Government.
A study of the statement by Premier Khrushchev, published in Moscow Saturday, shows that he comprehensively summarized the current Soviet position on a wide range of international issues.
ALGIERS, Oct. 27 President Ben Bella will leave tomorrow for a meeting with King Hassan in Bamako to discuss their border conflict.
The City Planning Commission announced yesterday that 33 city agencies had requested a total of $1,072,592,472 in new capital funds for the 1964-65 fiscal year.
A Jesuit affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola has begun a fast that he said will continue until the city takes direct action to stop the sale of pornographic literature.
Actuaries, those human computers of the insurance industry, will be well represented in Atlantic City, where the Society of Actuaries opened its three-day annual meeting today.
A heat record was set yesterday for the third day in a row, It was also the 24th day without rain here.

If you were a squirrel, the owner of a bicycle-renting serv ice, or a salesman of shaved and flavored ice, yesterday was a fine, beautiful day. If you made your living selling roasted chestnuts or overshoes, it was a rotten 82 degrees.
In contrast to the simple naivety of most folk-music concerts, the solo program by Bob Dylan at Carnegie Hall Saturday night left his listeners stirred, thinking and cheering for more.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 Westtern observers here have singled out as having special significance two points contained in the 10,000-word statement by Premier Khrushchev that was published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 An energetic contest is developing over the appointment of a Republican member to the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Its outcome will affect the future of the nation's 1,700 state-chartered banks.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway reported over the weekend that for the September quarter net income was $14,201,749, or 58 cents each, on 24,350,405 common shares outstanding. Gross revenues were $154,566,766.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 When Abdul Rahman Pazhwak of Afghanistan was chosen to head the United Nations' inquiry into Buddhist troubles in South Vietnam, he immediately pledged to give the matter a completely impartial review.
Union members ratified a contract yesterday that was to end today a strike that had shut down the American Sugar Company's refineries in Brooklyn, Philadelphia and Boston for 27 days.

PITTSBURGH, Oct, 27 (AP) Ed Brown connected for four touchdown passes three to Buddy Dial and an 85-yarder to Red Mack in the closing minutes of the game to give the Pittsburgh Steelers a 27 21 triumph over the Dallas Cowboys today in a National Football League game.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (UPI) Thousands lined the streets of a 10-block section in downtown Cincinnati today for a civil rights rally called to appeal for more jobs for Negroes.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 27 Negro leaders here today said they would appeal to the City Council to halt the police prattice of photographing civil rights demonstrations.
LONDON, Oct. 28 Tin prices soared today as the International Tin Council's buffer stock ran out for the second time in twenty-eight months.

The General Motors Corporation, largest auto maker in the world, said yesterday that it had rolled up records for sales and earnings in the first nine months of 1963. No other industrial concern in this country has approached these figures.
Speed in supplying capital funds for construction of the $27,830,000 transit tunnel between Manhattan and Queens was urged yesterday by Joseph E. O'Grady, chairman of the Transit Authority.

"The Beverly Hillbillies" continues in first place in the season's first rating, which estimates the popularity of all of the season's new shows and attractions from earlier years. The results were made available last night to the networks by the A.C. Nielsen Company of Chicago.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development World Bank made a loan yesterday equivalent to $35,000,000 for the improvement of railway transportation in Yugoslavia. The 20-year loan carries an interest rate of 5 per cent.

ROME, Oct. 28 A system has been installed in St. Peter's Basilica to allow participants in the Ecumenical Council to hear, in any of Six languages, translations of the Latin speeches as they are being delivered. The system may go into service next week.

LONDON, Oct. 28--Britain's political glamour spot is Kinross-West Perthshire, the lonely, craggy Scottish constituency where Sir Alec Douglas Home is making his bid for a House of Commons seat as the country's new Prime Minister.

The Government securities market backed away yesterday in light trading. Dealers attributed the small markdowns to the $11,000,000,000 of Treasury issues being sold this week, rather than to any selling pressure.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 28 Italy is expected to show the greatest, and West Germany the least, economic expansion in 1963 among the Common Market members.

Five men were named recipients of the 1863 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes yesterday for "distinguished journalistic contributions to the advancement of international friendship and understanding in the Americas."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 American shipowners sought a 10 per cent increase in aid shipment rates in their meeting with Federal officials on carrying wheat to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Administration and House Republican leaders reached substantial agreement today on a bipartisan civil rights bill.
Attendance at American Football League games is substantially ahead of last year, Commissioner Joe Foss said yesterday.
Attitudes of coat and suit buyers regarding the merchandise they sell were outlined yesterday to the executive board of the National Board of the Coat and Suit Industry.

LONDON, Oct. 28 Prophets often go without honor in their own land. The Western Theater Ballet, after its recent successful foray to the United States and the Continent, is still lacing the dance season.

Negotiations began yesterday between Actors Equity Association, the performer's union, and some 65 live industrial show producers for a new basic agreement to replace the one expiring Jan. 15, 1964. The first of a series of conferences was held in the Floral Room at the Hotel Edison.

In Frankfurt Dean Rusk demonstrated that this country now has a Secretary of State. He spoke with clarity and force about American policy and what we expect from our allies. He had spoken with equal force and clarity to the Pentagon and the White House before he left Washington.

THE first spring fashion crocuses turned up on Sev enth Avenue on New York's first rainy day in nearly a month. Early indications point to a diversified crop of suit silhouettes, including many casually open jackets and capes, narrow coats, bold abstract prints, and a deluge of white.
A citizens' advisory committee to the city's Office of Cultural Affairs was formed yesterday as Mayor Wagner inducted 87 New Yorkers prominent in the arts and in allied fields as its members.
If the Soviet Union really does not intend to challenge the United States in its bid to be the first on the moon, why not do everything reasonable to clinch the victory?
The deterioration that Brazil is experiencing in domestic economic conditions has been matched by a steady worsening in her financial relations with the rest of the world.
A Negro leader last night criticized television's "fantastic tendency to be objective" about its coverage of the civil rights campaign.

Four men described as members of Brooklyn's Gallo gang were sitting in a parked car in the borough's East New York section yesterday quietly munching hot dogs, but two police detectives thought the men looked suspicious.
Directors of Deere Co. increased the company's regular quarterly dividend yesterday to 60 cents a share from 55 cents and declared a special year-end extra dividend of 35 cents.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 28 Hollywood, which has dealt repeatedly with Robinson Crusoe on desert islands, has now decided to put him on Mars for its next adaptation of Daniel Defoe's 18th-century novel.
The sale of wheat to the Soviet Union has been encumbered by a maze of red tape and illogical decisions.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 28 The Moroccan Government reported today that its troops had pushed a new salient into disputed territory along the Algerian frontier, advanc ing to within eight miles of the mineral center of Tindouf in the Southwest Sahara.
ST.-NOM-LA-BRETECHE, France, Oct. 28 Jack Nicklaus carded five birdies on the first six holes today to clinch the Canada Cup for the United States and low medal honors himself.
Tom Ewell has agreed to star in "Ask Me No Questions," due here Jan. 29. Michael Ellis will produce the comedy, written by Ira Wallach.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 28--Gert and Ben Schaffer's Harry's Laura, a bay filly by Adios Harry-Steinway by Billy Direct, scored a three-quarter length victory over Tarport Rose tonight in the $33,831,20 Lady Maud Pace for 3-year-old fillies before 15,619 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.
Camille Henry, the smallest man in the National Hockey League, yesterday added to his stature when he said that this season's Ranger team "is the best team we've had in New York."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)--A reporter testified today that he had spent more than a week getting "unclassified" figures from the Department of Agriculture on Federal payments to a shipping company dominated by Aristotle S. Onassis, the Greek shipowner.
COTONOU, Dahomey, Oct. 28 (AP) The commander of Dahomey's 800-man Army seized control of the Government today after workers demanded the ouster of President Hubert Maga.
Both domestic and world sugar futures declined the daily limit yesterday while other commodities on the New York exchanges were mixed.
WHETHER it is called hamburger or chopped meat ground beef is economical, versatile and an important part of most family budgets, and it appears regularly on the weekly shopping list.

The Commercial Credit Company led seeral other major finance companies in a 1/8 percentage point rise on two maturities of directly placed commercial paper. The move followed a general downtrend on finance company paper during the preceding week.

The Ohio Power Company and Buckeye Power, Inc., announced plans yesterday in Columbus for construction of a jointly owned $125,000,000 electric power plant with 1,230,000 kilowatts of generating capacity.
The recommendation that the State abandon its compulsory posting of minimum retail liquor prices will be opposed strongly by the liquor industry.
Four years ago the citizens of Morris County, N.J., learned that their Great Swamp a primitive wild area within 25 miles of New York City had been selected as the site of a jetport. Now it

The office of the future was put on display yesterday. Visitors by the thousands with 60,000 expected by Friday evening took a look at the Business Equipment Exposition, the annual show of what's new in data processing, office machines and business equipment.

Three of New York's five counties are electing district attorneys next month. Upon their character, ability, vigilance and independence will depend, to a large extent, how well the law is enforced in their respective areas.
Mayor Wagner ordered yesterday a speed-up in plans to replace the Women's House of Detention with a new institution on Rikers Island.
MUCH of New York's fascination lies in the fact that neighborhoods rarely are static. Yesterday's slum suddenly becomes chic and vice versa. Now that artists are finding Greenwich Village too expen

Agreed to review a district court decision that acquisition by the second largest metal container manufacturer of the third largest maker of glass containers did not violate the Celler-Kefauver act because the two concerns were in distinct lines of commerce (No. 367, U.S. v. Continental Can.)
LONDON, Oct. 28 Britain lifted today the veil of secrecy that has shrouded her newest military weapon, the TSR-2 fighter-bomber.
The Pacific String Trio, a well matched group, gave a New York debut recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall that burst with vitality. The group is robust in sound and sensitive in the amenities.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28 Lorenz G. Straub, a hydroelectric engineer who was iternationally known as the "river doctor," died yesterday at the age of 62. According to the coroner's preliminary report, Mr. Straub was found dead in his office at the St. Anthony Falls Hydraulic Laboratory, apparently of natural causes.
JOHN JACOB ASTOR was mentioned favorably by Thomas Jefferson in an 1808 letter to Meriwether Lewis, new Governor of the new, vast, vague American territory called Upper Louisiana.

THE Metropolitan Championships tournament, played at the New York Hilton Hotel the last weekend, was concluded Sunday night with a team-of-four contest in two flights, the first for players of senior master or higher rank and the other for players with fewer master points.
In a move to strengthen the role of the layman in the education of rabbis, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America announced yesterday a "restructuring" of its top administrative echelon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Supreme Court will pass on the constitutionality of a statute stripping naturalized Americans of their citizenship if they return to their native land for three years.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 28 The N'turei Kar ta, the most zealously Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem, will observe a day of fasting on Thursday to protest traffic on the Sabbath near the ultra-Orthodox quarter of Mea Shearim.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, is extending its medical and social service programs to the newly emerging African nations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 A United Nations factfinding commission visited a "re-education center" today and talked with about 20 students who had been arrested during a demonstration supporting Buddhist demands.

In a new policy statement the City Commission on Human Rights reaches the conclusion that what it calls the "old methods" employed by governmental civil rights agencies have failed. For 50 years, says the commission's chairman, Stanley H. Lowell, the civil rights movement has promoted "color blindness" that is, the belief that any reference to a man's ethnic origin is discriminatory. Now, he observes, "the time has

ROME, Oct. 28 General discussion at the 35th congress of the Italian Socialist party closed late tonight with the virtual certainty that tomorrow the congress would authorize the party leader, Pietro Nenni, to negotiate the party's entry into a center-left government.
THE New York Giants' next opponent, the Cardi nals, will combat Y.A. Tittle on Sunday in St. Louis with a secondary defense that has permitted only three touchdowns by passim this season.
The earnings of the Union Oil Company of California, for the third quarter and the nine months to Sept. 30, were at record levels, A.C, Rubel, president, reported yesterday.

Texas, which owns major-college football's longest regularseason winning streak, yesterday became the first team in the 14-year history of the United Press International Coaches Board to be selected unanimously as No. 1 in the nation.

CONTRARY to popular belief, theatergoers are made, not born. Although the city has excellent examples of audience-participation shows for children, the kind of living theater that makes for Broadway customers later on, and mannerly customers at that, is less easy to come by.
A prominent Roman Catholic theologian has proposed a White House conference to find ways to help underdeveloped countries meet their critical problems of population growth.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 The United States and the Soviet Union offered today a deliberately noncontroversial resolution for future test-ban talks, but failed to sell it to a group of neutral countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 A member of the House of Representatives raised the question today whether a young German woman who has been mentioned regarding the affairs of Robert G. Baker, the former Senate majority secretary, had been forced to return to Germany because of security violations.

PARIS, Oct. 28 The United States' Seventh Army in Germany is regarded by allied generals, including Americans as the most powerful national military unit in Europe, not excepting Soviet forces in East Germany.

Considering that the Charter of the United Nations is based on the principles of the dignity and equality of all human beings and seeks, among other basic objectives, to achieve international cooperation in promoting and encouraging respect for human rights and for fundamental freedoms for all without distinction as to race, sex, language or religion,

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) The United States auto industry built its 6,000,000th passenger car of the calendar year 1963 last week and continued on toward its goal of more than 7,000,000 autos for the year.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 28 The Board of Education's plan to end racial imbalance in the elementary schools went into effect today. For the last two years the imbalance has been the center of much controversy and the cause of sitins, boycotts, desegregation rallies and law suits.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 In the Soviet Union, Tchai kovsky's "Queen of Spades" is considered his operatic masterpiece. Outside, it is not performed too often. Very few Tchaikovslcy operas are Mel
Prices advanced on the London stock market yesterday despite a warning of possible inflation by Chancellor of the Exchequer Reginald Maudling.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Former Senator Tom Connally of Texas, a Democratic stalwart of the Senate for many years and one of its most effective debaters, died at his home here today at the age of 86 after a long illness. He had been in virtual retirement since 1953. Pneumonia was given as the cause of death.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 A declaration against all forms of racial discrimination was adopted by the General Assembly's Social Committee here today. The vote was 89 to 0, with 17 abstentions.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 "I picked the University of Washington to go to the Rose Bowl and I have not changed my mind."

THE woman who leaves her job as director of the Bu reau of Policewomen today to become a deputy police commissioner is a living exception to the rule that social workers and the Police Department do not understand each other. Mrs. Theresa Ma

ONE day last week the normally careful Allie Sherman stepped completely out of character while trying to be helpful to some newspapermen who were prodding him for a forecast on the forthcoming GiantBrown game. They didn't want anything vague and innocuos. They were after a prebattle statement that would attract attention.

To give a concert on a late Monday afternoon--a gloomy one, at that--may be a hazardous enterprise, but Melvin Ritter and Jane Allen, the violin and piano duo, decided to do just that. They drew few people to their program in Town Hall yesterday, but those few were fortunate, for it was an occasion of absorbing music-making.
Guideposts for Children, Inc., will benefit from A Night in St. Moritz, a supper-dance to be held in the Carnival and Crystal Rooms of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Nov. 15.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 23 After two and a half years of national attention engendered by its controversial city manager, this pleasant city on the Hudson is looking forward in these brown October days to three events.

Eastgate House, a 14-story and penthouse apartment building at 350 East 52d Street, southwest corner of First Avenue, has been sold by the 350 East 52d Street Corporation. It was bought by investors who were represented by Koeppel Koeppel. William Gold was the lawyer for the seller. Nat Schneier and Samuel Shapiro Co. were the brokers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 The United States called on the deficit-ridden United Nations today to reduce the number of conferences it holds.
Mayor Wagner pledged last night that the city would exert "all available controls" over the sale of pornographic material to children.
A tour of four private art collections has been arranged for next Sunday in behalf of the scholarship fund of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York.
The policy of having a stateappointed committee select candidates for the city's Board of Education came under sharp attack yesterday.
HINTON, W. Va., Oct. 24 This ilroad town, depressingly poor even by West Virginia standards, has talked itself into a strange state of euphoria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Gen. James Francis Collins, Commander in Chief of the United States Army in the Pacific, was elected today president of the American Red Cross to succeed Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther.
March 27, 1950 Agreement was signed creating the Chinese-Soviet Nonferrous and Rare Metals Company to mine uranium and other ores in China's Sinkiang Province.
The world's largest cable suspension roof has been lifted into place on its sixteen 100-foot supporting columns at the New York State Pavilion at the World's' Fair.
Mayor Wagner hedged yesterday on the question whether the call by the City Commission on Human Rights for "preferential treatment" for Negroes constituted city policy at this time.

Every year about this time, the pious improvers of the standardbred breed make a pilgrimage to a spacious private lawn in Matinecock, L.I. There, in soil hallowed by a million torn pari-mutuel tickets, lie the remains of Messenger.
Riding the crest of an economic boom, Premier Ikeda of Japan has put his party's rule to the test of a national vote of confidence next month, a year ahead of time.
Brooklyn Tech's football team had the last laugh Saturday on New Utrecht High in general and Bill Wade, a New Utrecht halfback, specifically.
Pennsylvania Station, a grimy monument to an age of expansive elegance, suffered the fate of an anachronism yesterday.

The city's Air Pollution Control Commissioner criticized officials of neighboring areas in the 22-county Metropolitan Regional Council yesterday for failing to put into effect an air rpollution warning system. He He said they had ignored two years of urging by Mayor Wagner.

Young persons who have won honors in regional and national school science fairs will demonstrate their achievements on "Science All Stars," a new program to be televised by the American Broadcasting Company on Sundays from 4:30 to 5 P.M., beginning Jan. 12.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The "invasion" of Western Europe, and particularly the Common Market, by American manufacturing companies has passed its peak and may already have begun to taper off.
High school students will not fool college admissions committees by taking easy elective courses instead of harder academic subjects to get higher grades.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Chief Justice Earl Warren alluded briefly to the civil rights problem today as he received an honorary degree from Georgetown University.
The Board of Education said yesterday that it would begin a project next spring or fall to spur readings and arithmetic proficiency among students in the public schools.
PINE BEACH, N.J., Oct. 28 Stan Slaby, the head football coach at Admiral Farragut Academy, said today he hoped "summer" had ended.

Students in the school district in Levittown, L.I., ought to be assigned to read the history of witch-hunting in colonial Massachusetts. They might discover an odd parallel between what took place there and what they now have been asked to do.

The classrooms and corridors of Junior High School 115 in Manhattan were silent yesterday as nearly all of the 1,500 pupils were kept home by their parents to protest the Board of Education's alleged slowness in building a new school in the area.
Eight Naval Branch Oceanographic Offices, including the one here, will be closed late this year or early in 1964 as an economy measure, the Navy announced yesterday.
Hurricane Ginny veered toward the mainland late last night and threatened the metropolitan area with gale force winds today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) The Canadian Government has complained to the United States about interference with Canadian ships in United States lake ports following Canada's imposition of Federal trusteeship on five marine unions, Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson told the Commons today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 The nation's top surgeons, gathered here in the 50th anniversary year of the American College of Surgeons, took a second questioning look today at a new therapy for ulcers that has been widely accepted thoughout the United States.

The word "growth" has been gaining stature in the stock market. As most investors remember, it was a sad word when applied to stocks at the time of the May 28 break last year. Things have changed with the rising market.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 A chief economic policymaker insisted today that the best attack on high unemployment must be a tax cut to stimulate demand and thereby create jobs.

Businessmen should plan ahead if they wish to gain maximum benefits under the proposed tax law now before the Senate Finance Committee. The obvious long-term benefit is rate reduction. But there is a less obvious benefit that should be considered before the year ends by those willing to gamble on eventual passage.

Mrs. Fanny Jane Bowers of 151 East 80th Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Paris Bowers, to Alexander Winslow Liggett. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Coventry Liggett of Litchfield, Conn., Washington and Clearwater, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Treasury bill rate fell back slightly this week after a recent series of small increases.

Merry Ruler cavorted on his favorite stomping ground with his customary competence yesterday. Henry Frelinghuysen's 5-year-old gelding was one of the overlooked entrants among the nine starters in the $22,600 Sport 'Page Handicap at Aqueduct, where the 29,189 customers made the Jaclyn Stable's Ahoy the strong favorite.
IN its best scenes, "Walk in Darkness" throws a scorch ing light on what it is to be a Negro in a world he never made.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI) Most grain and soybean futures ended weak in nervous dealings today on the Board of Trade.

One of Broadway's more active angels, J.S. Seidman, told more than 100 members of the Harvard Business School Club of New York yesterday of the inherent hazards and the potential profits in theater investing. He spoke at a luncheon held at the Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street.

Steel production appears to be leveling off on a plateau of less than two-thirds of estimated steel-making capacity. However, output at even this low level for the rest of the year would make 1963 by far the best steel production year since 1957.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today a reorganization of the manned space flight program. The changes are designed to clarify the sometimes confused responsibility for directing the lunar expedition.

A member of the Cosa Nostra crime syndicate, reputed to be one of the most important racketeers in the garment industry, was indicted yesterday on charges of having failed to report $7,000 in earnings on his income tax returns for 1960 and 1962.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 28 August Stout Jr., who was a member of the Suffolk scandals grand jury from 1955 to 1960, was indicted today on a change of neglect of duty, growing from his term as supervisor of the Town of Brook haven in 1960-61.
In Queens, stronghold of the city's middle class, conservatives have hoisted their battle flag in a determined bid for political supremacy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) A spokesman for the maritime trades department of the labor federation insisted today that his unit was not opening a wide-scale boycott of Canadian Great Lakes shipping to protest Canadian maritimeunion trusteeship.

IN the midst of the manifold foreign and domestic prob lems which for nearly two years had absorbed our attention, I could not forget the importance of a Republican political success in 1954 to the Administration's still-unfolding legislative program and, as I saw it, to the progress of the nation.
Plans for repaying some of the city's badly pitted main streets, including "a showcase" part of Fifth Avenue, wire approved yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The work will cost $1,300,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Administration's foreign aid program was alternately defended and condemned today as the Senate opened debate on the $4.2 billion authorization bill.
BONN, Oct. 28 Secretary of State Dean Rusk's call upon Western European nations to rise to the responsibilities of Atlantic partnership met with praise and some reservations here today.
Motion picture theaters in suburban shopping centers will require an increased number of "quality" films, either from America or abroad, members of the Theater Owners of America were told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 A Senate subcommittee charged today that the Kerr-Mills program of medical aid for the elderly had proved to be "an ineffective and piecemeal approach to the health problems of the nation's 18 million older citizens."

Whitey Ford, the New York Yankees' pitcher who last year did testimonial commercials for Camel cigarettes, has started appearing in a new series of testimonials. This time he discusses the evils of smoking.
The country music of Mamma Maybelle Carter and a visit by a Swiss industrialist from Zurich are scheduled to mark the debut today of the nation's newest primary aluminum reduction plant.
Few athletes in professional sports are as admired for their conduct as a competitor as is Richie Guerin.
TRENTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Dewey D'Agostino, Trenton's best-known painting contractor, died yesterday in Jefferson Hospital, Philadelphia. His age was 60.
Record sales and increased earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 were announced yesterday by the Allied Chemical Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Premier Khrushchev's latest demonstration that more often than not he can push the United States into an embarrassed re-examination of a high policy in full operation is the direct consequence of this Government's tragic miscalculation of Soviet Russia's designs that was reflected in the agreements at Yalta and Potsdam.
PARIS, Oct. 28 France warned Algeria today of cuts in aid if there were further acts against French interests.
The Brooklyn Appellate Division struck down yesterday a temporary injunction preventing the Queens County Bar Association from campaigning for Supreme Court Justice George W. Herz.
The Police Department yesterday appointed its first women deputy commissioner in more than 29 years. She will head the Youth Program.
MASSENA, N.Y., Oct. 28 (UPI) Traffic on the St. Lawrence Seaway for April through September showed an increase of three million tons over the same months of last year.

50 For Columbia Journnlism In celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, "Journalists in Action" will be published by Channel Press on Nov. 12. The book is a collection of essays by 62 Columbia alumni, edited by Edward W. Barrett, dean of the school. The contributors cover all aspects of journalism and some adjacent professions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that the fact that Washington had one of the finest sports stadiums in the country but no national cultural center was a pational disgrace.
A City Commissioner visited two housewives in their kitchens yesterday, questioned them about their dish-washing habits and instructed them in ways to conserve the city's low water supply.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Secretary of the Interiof Stewart L. Udall disclosed today the creation of 85 "showcase" areas in the West as examples of the conservation of resources on public lands.
Strength in blue chips led the market into new high ground yesterday.
TOKYO, Oct. 28 Communist China's Foreign Minister said today that his country would probably not be ready to explode an atomic bomb for several years.
The five story apartment house at 2970 Bainbridge Avenue, near Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by the Mackmond Construction, which erected the building in 1927. The buyer was Louis
JOHN F. KENNEDY will attend the football game between Northeastern and the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., Saturday.

In the 15 years since he won a Naumburg Award, Paul Olefsky has shown himself to be a dependable and interesting cellist. He strengthened that impression in the recital he gave last night at Town Hall.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UPI) Soybeans led grain futures in a sharp tumble from strong levels today on the Board of Trade.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 29 South Africa's biggest trial of persons accused of violating the anti-sabotage law opened today to shouts of African nationalist slogans.
Mayor Wagner has invited city officials and clergymen to City Hall next Monday to discuss action against the sale of pornography to children.
CAIRO, Oct, 29 Nasser's foreign policy intrudes throughout the Middle East and Africa and is committed to backing revolutions in Yemen and Angola. Nevertheless, its slogan is nonalignment.
Illegal gambling operations that take in $30 million a year enjoy the protection of local police departments in Westchester County, the State Investigation Commission declared yesterday.

Graham Court, an apartment house landmark in Harlem dating from the turn of the century, has been sold by the Edward W. Browning estate to Phillip P. Zipes Co., realty investors and builders, who plan to modernize it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Administration is revising the travel rules for Communist diplomats in this country, incorporating for the first time some security controls that are not strictly retaliatory.

The downward movement in Government securities prices gathered momentum yesterday. A lack of demand in an apathetic market caused prices to be marked down in all maturity sectors, and the day's lows prevailed at the close.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Senate Democratic leaders talked confidently today of preventing heavy cuts in the $4.2 billion foreign aid authorization bill. But they considered making some important concessions to the opposition to insure this result.

The McCrory Corporation the 1,500-store retailing chain that was rebuffed last month in an attempt to raise $50,000,000 by selling a major division announced a $57,000,000 revolving-credit agreement with its banks yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The capital of the United States is involved once more in official scandal, and no wonder.
Maybe Get Around should have come from Belmont Park by helicopter instead of van yesterday for the $10,000 Ace Admiral Purse at Aqueduct. The motor trip apparently slowed him down.
A pilot program to provide 1,000 low-rent apartments a year for five years in middleincome housing developments was proposed yesterday by James W. Gaynor, State Housing Commissioner.
Another ambitious attempt to unite the whole Arab "nation" has now been launched by the Governments of Syria and Iraq, both dominated by the socialist Baath party.

The top New York State labor organization has declared itself strongly opposed to the power of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor and has said it will fight to curb the bistate agency's control over waterfront job policies.

THE taste and the manners of the new musical "The Streets of New York," which arrived last night at the Maidman Playhouse, are agreeable.

Don Trull of Baylor, last year's national major college passing champion, moved into first place in that department and within range of Roger Staubach of Navy in total offense last weekend.
Hurricane Ginny, as capricious a storm as ever to come this way, spun northeastward over Nova Scotia last night.
MIDLAND, Tex., Oct. 29 (AP) Mrs. Fred Turner, wife of a wealthy oilman, was beaten to death early today by a burglar.

A band of shouting pickets hurled placards and leaflets at Chief Justice Earl Warren last night as he left the New York City Bar Association building at 42 West 44th Street.
Sugar prices, world as well as domestic, rebounded and rose in active trading yesterday after dropping the day before.

A witness in the investigation of state highway frauds in Suffolk County said yesterday that he had been beaten up on Sunday night by four men who threatened to kill him and his family if he testified before a grand jury.
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 29 (AP)--Eddie Cotton of Seattle jabbed his way to a unanimous 15-round decision over Henry Hank and won the Michigan version of the world light-heavyweight championship tonight.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 29 Western diplomats here see the possibility of an East-West arms race in North Africa arising from the border conflict between Algeria and Morocco. It is feared that the arms race may go on for months after the present crisis has died down.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 29 Adolphe Menjou, suave, debonair actor in more than 200 motion pictures, died in his home today of chronic hepatitis. He had been ill nearly nine months. His age was 73.

An indictment was dismissed yesterday against a deputy medical superintendent of Bellevue Hospital who had been accused of paying a $4,000 bribe to get the questions to a New York State licensing examination in advance.

Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, who has appeared regularly in this country since her recital debut in New York in 1953, will be heard at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time during the 1964-65 season.

Frank Sinatra, who withdrew from the cast of Bing Crosby's first television show of the season after a sponsor objected to his scheduled appearance, will be a guest on Mr. Crosby's second show on Feb. 15 over the Columbia Broadcasting System. The advertiser that objected about the first show will not be a sponsor of the second.

The woman who is referring to the Bresident of the United States when she says "My son, Jack," can speak today, a little less painfully than before of another of her nine children, Rosemary.
The famous painted bedroom from Boscoreale at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be on view again today after being closed for about a year. It will be in a new location.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30 Parking problems and pay television were topics that enlivened the annual stockholders, meeting today of the National Exhibition Company, owners of the San Francisco Giants.
Senator Barry Goldwater indicated here last night that should he become an active Presidential candidate he would challenge Governor Rockefeller for New York State's Republican convention delegates.
ROME, Oct. 30 The Roman Catholic Bishops of the world took a significant step today toward increasing their authority and influence compared with the powers of the Roman Curia, or papal cabinet.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UPI) Export buying sparked a brisk rally in soybeans, bringing sharp gains today on the Board of Trader Corn closed weak, but other grain futures ranged steady to firm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Consumer prices showed the usual smattering of individual rises and declines in September, but the average remained unchanged from that of August, the Labor Department reported today.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 30 (UPI) Britain extended diplomatic recognition today to the Dominican Republic's civilian junta. It was the fifth nation to do so.
The chairman of the Congressional subcommittee that holds the purse strings for most medical research called the efforts in this field yesterday "the most significant Federal action of our era."

Owen H. Klepper has a problem. He is staging the world's largest theater party on Broadway May 25 and is in the market for 5,000 tickets. His selections will determine whether some funny things happen on the way to the next annual meeting of the Philco Corporation.

THE blockade the prevention of the advance of an enemy pawn by posting a piece directly in front of it was a pet theme of Aron Nimzovich, who devoted a whole chapter to the idea in his book "My System."

This has been the year of the picket. According to the Police Department, there have been more demonstrations in New York City in the last 10 months than in any other year in the department's memory.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, which on Tuesday rejected two suits opposing a city referendum on off track betting, declared yesterday that the city clearly lacked the authority to hold the referendum.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 30 In a most unusual season, Blair Academy's football squad still finds itself seeking its first victory. The pattern of the campaign has been a series of nearmisses in which the outcome of games could well have been the reverse.

A local law establishing a 12member temporary commission on city finances was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The commission's study of city costs is expected to hasten a showdown with the state on city financing.

Having questioned 400 persons in the murder of two East Side career girls on Aug. 28, the police have extended their investigation to the point of checking all crimes in which knives were used, inmates entering and leaving state institutions and persons moving out of the neighborhood where the girls lived.
Michael J. Quill declared yesterday that contract negotiations with the Transit Authority had ended before they started, and he threatened a bus and subway strike for New Year's Day.
Teamster officials gave assurances to World's Fair representatives yesterday that picketing at the gates of the fair would be stopped pending further meetings to resolve the dispute.
THE mystery about who really wrote today's satirical extravaganza, "The McLandress Dimension," is surpassed only by the mystery over why anybody wrote it at all.
SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP) James Logan Cranwell, a retired Pennsylvania Railroad vice president, died yesterday. He lived here and would have been 58 years old tomorrow.
Beethoven sonatas were the material of Iso Elinson'a recital when the pianist played here on Oct. 30 after an absence of 25 years.
ROME, Oct. 30 Premier Giovanni Leone and his stopgap Government are expected to resign next week, perhaps on Tuesday. The formation of a new cabinet is expected to be difficult.

IN almost every country of the world today people sit on Danish chairs, sip from Swedish glasses and walk on Finnish rugs. And in cities around the globe where imported Scandinavian designs cannot be found, there are often copies of the style.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 The nation's surgeons have started a campaign to slow down ambulances and make them obey the traffic rules. With this they hope, through improvement in hospital emergency departments, to get a better deal for injured people.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 M'hammed Yazid, Algerian special envoy, charged today that distorted reports had improperly depicted Algeria's legitimate arms purchases as a menacing military build-up in North Africa.

"The Blight on the Ivy," by Dr. Richard E. and Mrs. Katherine K. Gordon, to be published by Prentice-Hall on Nov. 12 is a book about emotional stresses of college life. Dr. Gordon is a psychiatrist and his wife a social psychologist, both dealing with educational problems.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 30 (AP) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, abandoned hope today for an early vote on President Kennedy's $4.2 billion foreign aid program.

The economic liberals among the Democrats are slowly waking up to the fact that they have suffered a big defeat in the battle for tax reduction. Liberal Democrats in and out of the Administration favor tax cuts. But they also insist on the need for increased Government spending.

Raymond G. Mullee, a patent lawyer and, since 1931, head of the patent department of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, died Tuesday of a heart attack in a taxicab at First Avenue and East 37th Street. He was 60 years old and lived at 435 East 79th Street.

Stockholders of the New York and Honduras Rosario Mining Company approved at a special meeting yesterday a previously proposed three-for-one split of the company's common stock. The shares will be distributed on Nov. 27 to holders of record of Nov. 6.
Soaring income and revenues were reported yesterday by Trans World Airlines for the quarter and nine-month period ended Sept. 30. Record net income was achieved for both periods.

A group of top state Democrats, including William H. McKeon, the state chairman, listened for five hours yesterday to suggestions for improving the Legislature, for dealing with Robert Moses and for facing the state's financial problems.

The city must expedite major construction on Rikers Island to relieve pressure on overcrowded facilities before there is a "major disturbance," the Commissioner of Correction, Anna M. Kross, warned yesterday.
Feb. 7 Australia accused Ivan F. Skripov, first secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Canberra, of trying to enlist a woman intelligence agent to spy. Skripov and his wife were expelled.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 30 A Supreme Court judge dismissed today an indictment accusing 10 men of "willfully and Illegally" resorting to sabotage and violence to end South Africa's policy of apartheid.

Fifty-seven widely known works of modern art were sold for a total of $1,121,300 in the Parke-Bernet Galleries last night in an auction that brought several surprises and an embarrassing moment for the auctioneer.

MANY young mothers have first mixed feelings when they first discover that their child has a non-existent playmate. These parental feelings, as well as the child's imaginary companion, are normal, according to child-care specialists.
The decline in prices of Government securities slowed considerably yesterday. Dealers said the selling was drying up after three days of a sliding Treasury market.

The pending publication of former President Dwight D. Prices continued to advance in selective trading on the London stock market following the settlement of a dispute on working hours of British dockers. Buying sentiment also was helped by reports of increased steel production.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the three months to Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $84,603,000, or $1.18 a share. This compares with $79,960,000, or $1.11 a share, in the 1962 period.

Open market cash purchases by the Federal Reserve yesterday failed to arrest the slide in Government coupon issues. Treasury bills also declined. As a result of the continuing uneasiness, prices closed at the lows of the day.

A citizen who saw a husband beating his wife and fought him and held him for 20 minutes until the police came was complimented by a judge yesterday. He also was awarded $145 to compensate for his torn clothing and the teeth marks the husband left in his right elbow.

St. Patrick Miss demonstrated yesterday to the 24,125 customers at Aqueduct that it was hardly a trick to win at a mile against fillies her age. Competing in the Catbird Seat Purse, St. Patrick Miss treated her backers to a clear triumph.

Murray Cohen, former vice president of Jay Thorpe, Inc., women's fashion apparel store at 24 West 57th Street, which closed last year, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital, after an illness of several months. FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 31 --Capt. Richie Kessinger, the skipper of Capt. Jack VI, was one of the happiest men on the Woodcleft Canal today. He looked at the quiet water, squinted at the bright sun, then patted the bow of his gleaming white 65-footer with unmistakable affection.

The Kennedy Administration has reportedly decided to prohibit access to certain parts of the United States to Communist diplomats, whether or not the country they represent imposes similar restrictions on American diplomats. This is a change in a policy which in the past has placed restrictions on Communist diplomats in the United States only as a retaliatory measure.
PARIS, Nov. 1--Exiled Vietnamese politicians here were jubilant today over the military coup against the Government of Ngo Dinh Diem.

Public bond offerings in October were more than double the level of the corresponding 1962 month, according to a survey compiled yesterday by The New York Times. The total was almost twice as much as that in September.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating and Mayor Wagner called yesterday for the end of the national origins system as a basis for immigration quotas.

When 135,128 shares of a railroad's stock change hands, plenty of interest is aroused. On Sept. 25, Chicago North Western sold that many shares, or a 13 per cent interest, in the Gulf, Mobile Ohio in the open market, Yesterday, Glen Brock, president of Gulf, Mobile, fended off a question about the names of the new owners of the stock, saying he could not divulge that information.

CARLSBAD, N. M., Nov. 1 (UPI)--Marilynn Smith of Tequesta, Fla., was virtually a one-putt golfer on the first nine holes today as she took a stroke lead in the opening round of the $7,500 Cavern City ladies open. She posted a three-under-par 69 at Riverside Country Club.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 1 --Thirteen young men and one young woman were indicted today for causing $3,202 worth of damage at a Southampton mansion after a debutante party on the night of Aug. 31. Several are members of prominent families in New York and Philadelphia.

A picture of colleges already bursting at the seams and confronted with an oncoming rush of new students was drawn yesterday for the City Planning Commission at a hearing on the Board of Higher Education's capital budget.

Governor Rockefeller reopened virtually all the state's woodlands for recreational use yesterday after intermittent rains had reduced the danger of forest fires. His order also meant, in most counties, the reinstatement of the hunting season, which had been halted Oct. 13.

LONDON, Nov. 1--A new spirit of excitement is bubbling behind the gray facades of the City of London. Thanks to President Kennedy's proposed restrictions of foreign borrowings in Wall Street, the City is once more becoming an international market for raising capital.

California plans to sell $50,000,000 of tax anticipation notes on Nov. 21. The state announced that the notes would be sold in anticipation of the proceeds from the sale of bonds as part of the $1,750,000,000 water project.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The Senate repudiated a bipartisan leadership agreement on the foreign aid authorization bill today and cut $25 million extra from funds earmarked for longterm development loans.
HARVARD athletic officials expect a near capacity crowd of 35,000 for the Princeton game Saturday even though the elation over Harvard's defeat of Dart-- mouth two weeks ago seems to have evaporated.

EFFORTS in the conservation field often involve huge bond programs and vast land acquisitions; everything is on a megadollar scale. But modest efforts often may return values far beyond the cost and scope of an undertaking.

RICHMOND, Nov. 5--Byrd organization Democrats maintained their overwhelming control of the Virginia Legislature today but Republicans increased their bridgehead in their strongest campaign effort of the century.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5--A predawn flight through subterranean tunnels, a speeding car ride, a visit to a suburban church, a trip inside an armored personnel carrier and sudden death.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower says Senator Barry Goldwater is "impulsive," but he does not think the Arizona Republican would get the United States "into trouble" if elected.

The five-story building containing 49 apartments and nine stores at 1683-85 University Avenue, corner of West 176th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by White House Properties, Inc. The property, with a plot 157 by 122 feet, has been purchased by an investing client of Morris Greenberg, lawyer. The sale was negotiated by Leonard Schiller, brokers, for cash over mortgages of $257,000.
Twelve thousand Lutheran children in the metropolitan area played the role of preChristmas Santa Clauses yesterday.
Democratic candidates won by wide margins all of the 13 judicial offices in the city's court system at stake in yester day's election.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 5-- Nassau County Democrats scored a major victory in today's election by electing the first Democrat supervisor in the Town of Oyster Bay in more than 30 years.

After the Giants' weekly press luncheon in the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Coach Al Sherman reaffirmed the three position changes the team must make for its game here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Nov. 5--John Black Cornell of Bryant Avenue, chairman of the board of the Cornell Iron Works in Long Island City, Queens, died Sunday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Philip MacPhail, in Boulder, Colo. His age was 78.
PARIS, Nov. 5--A resolution that would unify Western policy on trade with the Soviet Union has been approved by members of the parliaments of the countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

John Loeschhorn, a slightly built sophomore from New York University, ran away from the pack yesterday for individual honors, but undefeated Rutgers paced the team standing in the 37th Metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
The site of the former 50th Street Greyhound Bus Terminal has been sold to Loew's Theaters, Inc., for $2 million, it was disclosed yesterday.
Following are phonetic pronunciations of the names of some of the leading figures in the current situation in South Vietnam and their identifications:
The Police Department is considering using a dart gun that contains a tranquilizer for its more difficult, violent cases.
LACKAWACK, N.Y., Nov. 5 --Despite a rainfall last weekend that allowed woodlands to be reopened. New York City's water supply in its watershed area remained unchanged today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, under some personal pressure to return to his academic career at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, plans to resign early next year as the President's scientific adviser.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 5 (UPI)--An insurance agent testified today that T. Eugene Thompson bought policy after policy of insurance on his wife with a "sense of urgency." He also said that 11 months before Mrs. Thompson's slaying, Mr. Thompson had told him of a "premonition" she would meet with a tragic accident.
YESTERDAY'S spring readyto-wear openings on Sev enth Avenue ranged from styles in the upper price bracket to lively fashions for juniors.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5-- Alfred M. Klein, lawyer, newspaper columnist and a member of the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission since 1955, died tonight of a heart ailment. He was 62 years old and lived in Jenkintown.
One of America's historic playhouses, Ford's Theater in Baltimore, is scheduled to vanish.

Federal mediators will intervene Friday in a machinists' strike against private shipyards in the port, where work has halted on navy ship repair contracts totaling $339,000. The stoppage has made 800 to 1,000 men idle.

AQABA, Jordan, Nov. 5--The splendid vista at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba leads into the Red Sea east of Suez and provides a brilliant view of Middle East confusion. The gulf itself, hemmed in by sawtoothed peaks, is a lovely piece of water endowed with subtropical clarity and climate.
LENGEDE, Germany, Nov. 5 --An attempt to rescue 11 miners trapped underground here since Oct. 24 continued at a hectic pace today.
Scientists who learned yesterday that they had won the Nobel Prize had mixed reactions.

ROME, Nov 5--The transition Government of Premier Giovanni Leone resigned today. President Antonio Segni asked the outgoing Premier and his ministers to act as a caretaker Cabinet until a new government was formed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The official assumption here is that a negotiated political settlement in Vietnam is impossible and maybe even dishonorable, but how do they know?
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5--Mayor James H.J. Tate, who had strong support from President Kennedy, was elected to a full four-year term today.

WITH the ancient Hebrew welcoming song, "Hevenu Shalom Aleichem" ("We are bringing peace to you"), a cluster of 20 children joyously greeted newcomer John Lande to their classes at the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 6--The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne, the Most Rev. Dr. Daniel Mannix, died today. Reputed to be the world's oldest Catholic prelate, he would have been 100 years old next March.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) --President Kennedy today proclaimed Nov. 28 as Thanksgiving Day and told the nation it "must never forget that the highest appreciation is not to utter words but to live by them."
THE turmoil now convulsing Africa from Tangier to Cape Town provides a his-- torical spectacle of almost tragic gran deur and of immeasurable importance.

THE Guggenheim Museum is keeping up such a re lentless barrage of provocative exhibitions that it may become the Museum of Modern Art of the Sixties, leaving the latter institution to the pleasures and historical joys of exhumations such as Medardo Rosso, Art Nouveau and Gustave Moreau.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4--"Four days ago," an American said, "there was no chance. Now there is a chance."

The 76th National Horse Show in 80 years began in Madison Square Garden yesterday. When the last class was finished close to midnight, West Germany and Canada stood ahead of the rest in the international jumping competition.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 5--Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu canceled late tonight her plans to fly to Rome. She annuonced that she would bring her three younger children to the United States from Rome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The State Department decided today to remove Otto F. Otepka as its chief security evaluations officer. It charged that he had given confidential documents to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.
DENVER, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Sonny Liston, the heavyweight champion, and the challenger, Cassius Clay of Louisville, signed contacts today for a 15round title fight.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5-- Stocks on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange fell sharply, but recovered partly before the close today in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's increase in the margin requirement.
Two of the city's representatives at Albany will prefile idtical bills to restore the right of grand juries to make presentments after investigations not resulting in indictments.
ROME, Nov. 5--A draft, decree on bishops and the government of dioceses came under strong criticism at the Ecumenical Council today.
Erie county Republicans weathered a bitter intraparty feud to retain control of the county government, which they have held for three decades.
The Worlds of Benny Goodman," the title of a concert presented last night by Mr. Goodman at Philharmonic Hall, proved to be two in number. There was a world of chamber music and one of jazz.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes suffered a stunning setback in the New Jersey election yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5--The Russians said tonight that the move leading to the halting of the Berlin-bound United States convoy was a "deliberate provocation by United States military authorities."
The soft life had the James Bond girl round the neck and was slowly strangling her.

WERE it not for the fact that his "Buntscheh the Silent" had been borrowed for use in "The World of Sholom Aleichem" and proved to be one of that fondly remembered production's glittering gems, it would be tempting to declare categoryically that the works of Isaac Loeb Peretz were not meant for the stage.

MOST of the diners missed the byplay, but those who noticed it smiled in appreciation. The incident occurred last week during a sports dinner at Toots Shor's fueling station. Among those decorating the dais was Jack Dempsey, lean, trim, quickmoving and the youngest 69-years-old anyone ever did see.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Melvin Price, a leading Congressional authority on Government research, entered a broad "indictment" today of alleged mismanagement of costly research and development programs'.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) --A visitor shattered a mirror in the Red Rom of the White House today by hurling an urn.

The Election Day process began in Greenwich Village's 33d Election District of Manhattan's First Assembly District yesterday before dawn. Patrolman Charles Vroom arrived in his Volkswagen at 5:12 A.M. after a 30-mile drive from his home in Staten Island by way of New Jersey.
The Musical Arts Woodwind Quintet offered an evening of sturdy, satisfying music-making and an attractive panel of rarely heard works for its New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

WORK by outstanding 20thcentury School of Paris Painters and sculptors from the Edward A. Bragaline Collection goes on view today at Knoedler's, 14 East 5th Street, to aid the newly founded Museum of Early American Folk Arts, 49 West 53d Street.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 5-- Republicans retained control of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors for the 55th year today, but by a reduced margin, and they suffered major losses to the Democrats in some key communities.
LONDON, Nov.5--Britain is resisting renewed United States pressure for an agreement among members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to refuse long-term economic credits to the Soviet Union.

Political workers were "pulling" all over town yesterday. Pulling is political jargon for enticing voters away from their television sets, kitchen chores or leaf-raking and getting them to the polls to vote for the "right" candidate.
Mayor Wagner declared last night that the voters of New York City had presented the Legislature with a clear mandate to authorize off-track betting here.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov.5-- Lieut. Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr., pledged to continue Gov. Ross R. Barnett's massive resistance to racial integration, was elected Governor of Mississippi tonight over a strong conservative Republican.

Basic scientific research can produce immediate and dramatic effects upon our lives, or it can add depths to the ocean of knowledge that are too profound for recognition by most laymen. Yesterday's Nobel prizes in chemistry and physics honored both types of discovery.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 5--A plan was unveiled today to speed establishment of a single market for agricultural products in the European Economic Community.
An association of 400 commercialy print shops in New York City charged yesterday that the contract demands of the typographical union, if granted, could bring slow death to the industry here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- High authorities here do not believe the military committee that seized power in South Vietnam planned or ordered the assassinations of President Ngo Dinh Diem and his brother Ngo Dinh Nhu.
Alfred C. Thompson, who made a success in the disparate fields of boxing and retail merchandising, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital after suffering a stroke on Thursday. He was 65 years old.

GREGOR GRANT, editor of the British weekly Autosport and the No. 1 expert on Formula One racing, has named his fellow Scotsman, Jim Clark, as the international driver of the year with a top ranking of five stars.

The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, recently opened a new addition to its toy section: the McDonald Doll Collection, which contains 38 dolls of the 18th and 19th centuries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Senator B. Everett Jordan, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, said today that he now favored employing outside counsel to direct the commmittee's investigation into activities of Robert G. Baker, former Senate majority secretary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Merchant marine representatives and Government officials today scheduled another meeting Thursday in talks aimed at unlocking the sale and shipment of wheat to the Soviet Union.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 5--Twenty-six countries in the African-Asian group urged today that all countries stop supplying arms, military equipment, petroleum and petroleum products to South Africa.
New Yorkers endorsed off-track betting by a margin of more than 3 to 1 yesterday in an election marked by party-line voting, a light turnout and no surprises.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 5--Two American nuclear scientists, one of them a woman, were named today to share the Nobel Prize in Physics for 1963 with a nuclear scientist from West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--Walter P. Reuther reported modest success today for the experimental organizing drive begun last spring by the Industrial Union Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Brooklyn's Hasidic Jewish community appeared to be stirred but unremorseful yesterdays over the arrest on Monday of five of its youths who were trying to dramatize the ultraOrthodox sect's quarrel with the Government of Israel.
ATHENS, Nov. 5--Constantine Caramanlis, former Premier and leader of the defeated National Radical Union party, declared today that he had changed his mind and would remain active in Greek politics.
The establishment of the post of Secretary of Education with Cabinet rank was recommended yesterday by Dr. Michael F. Walsh, former Commissioner of Education in Rhode Island.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Otto Fred Otepka, the husky, dark-eyed career civil servant who was ordered dismissed today as the State, Department's chief security evalua tor, has been called a victim of changing times, a target of technological unemployment.

IF "News in Perspective" had its difficulties in its premiere last month on Channel 13, last night's installment of The New York Times's presentation was a first-rate job. The program, with Lester Markel, Sunday editor; Tom Wicker, White House correspondent, and Max Frankel, diplomatic correspondent, not only unfolded much more smoothly but also achieved the desired meaningful depth.

Retail liquor store owners were urged yesterday to enlist the aid of "Parent-Teachers Associations, the Boy Scouts and other civic-minded groups" to prevent changes in the state's liquor control laws.
Sales of United States savings bonds rose 9.8 per cent in October from the 1962 level, the Treasury Department reported yesterday.
For many New York City politicians, Election Day, 1963, was dominated by thoughts of Election Day, 1964--and what Mayor Wagner would be doing then.
The most trying hour that Richard S. Aldrich spent yesterday came not during the counting of ballots but after his election to the City Council was assured.

The opening of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night was a lot like any other opening pageant-- theatrical or sports. Despite the in-group lingo, which makes one sound as if he'd just won the Maryland Hunt Cup, most spectators neither own nor ride horses. They were simply fans or people who came to see or be seen.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 5--Thirty-nine members introduced a resolution today under which the General Assembly would recommend that the 18-power Disarmament Committee resume negotiations in Geneva "with zeal and determination" on "general and complete disarmament."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The volume of consumer installment credit outstanding increased in September the smallest amount for any month this year.
PARIS, Nov. 5--The British Labor Party's chief spokesman on foreign affairs proposed today a directorate to "control" strategy within the Atlantic alliance, including that concerning nuclear weapons.

Nikita Khrushchev misjudged the fiber of the American people a year ago in Cuba. Subsequently, it seemed that he had learned something from that experience. The recent series of incidents on the Berlin Autobahn makes one wonder whether all this has been forgotten. If it has been, Mr. Khrushchev is in for another rude shock.
Five new Democratic and five new Republican members were added to the City Council last night in the most dramatic change in the composition of that body in 16 years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 6--United States officials have turned over to the military Government a brother of the dead President, Ngo Dinh Diem. The brother, Ngo Dinh Can, had sought refuge in the United States Embassy after the revolt ended his family's rule.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 5-- Castleton Farm's Campus Queen proved the best of an unimpressive group of 3-year-old trotting fillies in the Lady Suffolk Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 5-- Edgar S. Reed of West Hartford, second vice president in charge of personnel for the Travelers Insurance Company here, died today in Hartford Hospital after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

Two more producers are joining Herman Shumlin in the sponsorship of "The Deputy," Rolf Hochhuth's controversial drama about the alleged failure of Pope Pius XII to prevent Hitler's extermination of 6,000,000 Jews.

The Presbytery of New York City unanimously nominated a Negro minister from the Bronx yesterday as its candidate for Moderator of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church, the highest elective office in the denomination.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 5-- Thomas C. Mayers, a Republican, was elected Mayor today over State Senator William F. Hickey Jr. The unofficial count was 18,570 to 16,383 votes.

The Economist, that stately, 120-year old British weekly, is showing signs of youthful levity these days. Traditions are tumbling right and left.
Seven amendments to the State Constitution won voter approval yesterday.
The Bowery Savings Bank, the world's largest mutual savings bank, has withdrawn from participation in any future floating conventions of the Savings Bank Association of New York State.
WEST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 5-- North Babylon High won for the first time in its four seasons of football today. It registered a 13-12 victory over West Islip and snapped a 28-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)--The Pentagon consolidated its "brush-fire" emergency forces today. It assigned to the Army-Air Force Strike Command all defense responsibility for the Middle East, South Asia and much of Africa.

MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press)--Hal C. Banks, president of the Seafarers International Union of Canada, was arraigned today on a charge conspiracy to commit assault in the beating of Capt. Henry Francis Walsh in 1957.
As in years gone by, the opening of the National Horse Show last night was preceded by many dinner parties given by the box holders.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 5 (AP)--William Haggin Perry's Lamb Chop left no doubt today that she was just about the best 3-year-old filly in the nation.

HOUSTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)-- The Manned Spacecraft Center announced today a far-reaching reorganization that puts Project Mercury personnel into new duties with the Gemini and Apollo programs. Major Donald K. Slayton was named head of flight crew operations.
The eruptive potential of the civil rights issue came through as an indecisive tremor in most local and state elections across the land yesterday.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Nov. 5--A faculty committee urged today that New Jersey state colleges be expanded to become liberal arts institutions. They are now primarily, teachers' colleges.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 5--Edward T. Breathitt, Democrat, won the Kentucky governorship tonight, although white reaction to civil rights pressure cut his margin to fewer than 16,000, votes.
Record sales and earnings were reported, yesterday by North American Aviation, Inc., for the fiscal years ended Sept. 30.
YAPHANK, L.I., Nov. 5-- H. Lee Dennison, a Democrat, scored his second upset victory in predominantly Republican Suffolk County today by winning a second four-year term as County Executive.
Prices of domestic and world sugar futures dropped sharply yesterday in trading here. Wool futures, meanwhile, showed a sharp advance.
