WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) The chairman of the Federa Communications Commission had a hard time today trying to convince a House Commerce subcommittee that the Ameriican television viewer deserved longer stretches of movies and fewer commercials on his late show.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 A priest who is a Negro has charged in a magazine interview that the Roman Catholic Church maintains racial segregation in some parishes and consequently creates "second class Christians."
Irvington House will benefit from the 10th annual art and antiques auction to be held on the evening of Nov. 26 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Roman Catholic nuns including one whose solos are a smash hit, have taken to cutting popular records and are ringing up quick sales unheard of in the more patient and traditional pursuits of making bread brandy and cheese.
Is a nonstop flight between New-York City and Buffalo intrastate or interstate if it flies over parts of neighboring New Jersey or Pennsylvania?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Investigators for the Senate Rules Committee have begun sifting through a mass of charges and reports concerning the outside business activities of Robert G. Baker.

LONDON, Nov. 6 A minister of the Church of Scotland says he has proved with a computer that St. Paul could not have been the author of more than five of the 14 epistles attributed to him in the New Testament.
Advertising men, who like to think that they understand the psychology of the average consumer, were told by a psychology professor yesterday that their theories had fallen badly behind the times.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters decided today to demand wage and fringe-benefit increases from the trucking industry amounting to about $600 million over three years.

"Mara weather" a legend that sprang up as a result of numerous observed instances that when the Mara-owned New York Giants are scheduled to play at home, bad weather miraculously clears is no mere weekend phenomenon. Yesterday it allowed the Giants to conduct their workout.
Mayor Wagner directed Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin yesterday to proceed with the condemnation of 250 acres of land for the projected Breezy Point Park on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.
MONTREAL, Nov. 6-John Wilson McConnell, financier and former publisher of The Montreal Star, died here today in Royal Victoria Hospital. He was 88 years old.
Two more public buildings were damaged yesterday by vandals who threw egg shells or electric light bulbs filled with enamel paint.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 6 "There can be no Florida vacations this winter, because you will be needed here to vote on county business" was the word circulated today among the 30 Republicans on the Westchester Board of Supervisors that was elected yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6 On Saturday mornings Cosmo Iacavazzi wakes up scared, wishing he had never entered Princeton, that he had never gone out for football. He swallows two bites of the pre-game steak and climbs into his uniform as the feeling of dread that started in his toes on Tuesday begins to reach his head.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) Soybeans and wheat closed firm to strong while most other grain futures worked lower today on the Board of Trade.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made its first two loans to Portugal yesterday for electric power development. The loans totaled $12,500,000.
In the paddock before the feature at Aqueduct yesterday, Howard (Buddy) Jacobson gave Bob Ussery some familiar instructions on how to handle Hellman Stable's Audience.

The co-chairman and the program director of the Protestant and Orthodox Center planned for the New York World's Fair have resigned in protest against a film on Christianity being prepared for showing at the center.
Six communities in Puerto Rico raised a total of $9,530,000 in the bond market here yesterday.

ELMIRA, N.Y. A tiny girl in a red-and white, checked dress and bonnet turned over a spoonful of ground last month outside this city, 226 miles from Manhattan. This ground-breaking ceremony represented more than just the advent of a new industrial plant to a community, however. It also symbolized the rebirth of a city that was in danger of being declared a distressed area only a few years ago.
A dozen pickets demonstrated in front of Grand Central Terminal yesterday against the loss of their jobs as freight handlers for the New York Central Railroad.

Mike Nichols and Elaine May have joined the cast of "That Was The Week That Was," the special program spoofing current events that will be televised on Sunday from l0 to 11 P.M, by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--The Justice Department will continue its legal prosecution of the recent merger of the Crocker-Anglo and Citizens National Banks in California.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors, and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on that exchange.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 Premier Khrushchev indicated today that he had rejected a reported United States compromise plan to break the shipping-rate impasse holding up sales of wheat to the Soviet Union.

Three men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission to conceal a stock fraud in which the public lost $60,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) Walter P. Reuther issued a call today to America's workers to go to the polls in 1964 to destroy what he called an "anti-labor, right-wing conspiracy" in Congress.

After leaving its "Faust" in storage for three seasons, the Metropolitan Opera biought it forward again last night. Again it was the production that has Siebel looking like George Sand and Mephistopheles looking like Paganini.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon spoke by telephone with Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu today, it was reliably reported.
ABERDEEN, Md., Nov. 6 (AP) A record flight of approximately 3,900 miles from Pennsylvania to Alaska, has been completed by one of the Army's largest helicopters, the CH-47A, called the Chinook.

Officers of major distilling companies have been subpoenaed, with their records, by the state's Moreland Act Commission in an effort to learn why the cost of bottled liquor is substantially lower in Washington, Chicago, Miami and other cities than in New York.
ROME, Nov. 6 The Communist party stepped up pressure today for what it described as a bold shift to the left to resolve the new governmental crisis.

Drago Shoe Repair, House of Cards, Inc., and Fredwin Shops, Inc., women's apparel, have leased the three stores in the new one-story taxpayer at 126 to 130 East 44th Street, adjoining the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue. The building is on a plot 54 by 83 feet. The leases were negotiated through Lester Feldshon and Irving T. Wallach of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., brokers.
DO NOT be put off by the cadenced lugubriousness of that title. The happy truth is that Mrs. Thomas, widow of the poet Dylan Thomas, 1914-53, writes with her own poetic gusto and fire.

Linderest Gardens, a garden apartment development for 284 families on a nine-acre tract in Linden, N.J., has bee sold by the builder, the Linden Housing Corporation, a family group headed by Jack Albert of New York. The development consists of 39 two-story buildings and 100 garages and is bounded by St. Georges Avenue (Route 27) , Stiles Street, Academy Terrace and Hollywood Road. It is bisected by University Terrace.

TOKYO, Nov. 6--The $13,000,000 atomic reactor with which Japan proudly inaugurated power production 10 days ago has been out of operation for a week while officials, labor leaders and United States business representatives wrangle.

The directors of the Colorado Interstate Gas Company proposed yesterday, a stock distribution of two shares for each five shares held. The cash dividend rate of $1.25 a year will be retained on the new shares, the directors said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Treasury and Federal Reserve officials went out of their way today to emphasize that yesterday'S increase of the margin requirements on purchases of securities did not signal a further tightening of credit.
CLOSER fit and feminine softness were the signifi cant themes in yesterday's spring fashion openings on Seventh Avenue.

Rossini's "Semiramide" with Joan Sutherland; Poulenc's "Dialogues des Carmelites," and Virgil Thomson's "The Mother of Us All" will be among the operas given in concert form by the American Opera Society this season at Carnegie Hall. Massenet's "Herodiade" and Bellini's "I Capuletied I Montecchi" also will be given.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6--The General Assembly called on Britain today, by a vote of 73 to 2, to refuse independence to Southern Rhodesia until that self-governing colony established "majority rule based on universal adult suffrage."
ANOTHER small college in the East is making itself heard. This one is Hamilton, . in upstate New York, which has one of the area's four remaining undefeated smallcollege teams.
It there's a behind-the-scenes battle concerning the April in Paris Ball, it's one of the most peaceful disputes since Alphonse was polite to Gaston.
Cotton futures advanced 25 to 55 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 (UPI) A legal controversy that halted the murder trial of T. Eugene Thompson in the slaying of his wife was carried to the Minnesota Supreme Court today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Nov. 7 Dr. Djuanda, First Minister of Indonesia, died of a heart attack at 1 A.M. today. He was 52 years old.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 6 A private trial was assured today for 18-year-old Edward O'Connell of Glen Cove, one of 14 young persons indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury last Friday for causing $3,202 worth of damage to a Southampton mansion last Aug. 31.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The Senate cut deeper into its $4.2billion foreign aid authorization today as the combined leadership yielded more ground to prevent its retreat from becoming a rout.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 6 Lester A. Grimes, a retired engineer who designed and patented many fire prevention devices, died Monday at his home, 325 Lincoln Avenue. He was 79 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 6 There was nearly an inch of rain and wind gusts of 40 miles an hour tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. But it was a beautiful night for Joseph Mariano, a 39-year-old bartender from Waterbury, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today to give three helicopter airlines almost $1.2 million in subsidies for the remainder of the year.

CONCORD, Mass., Nov. 6--Ted Childs, Middlesex School's head football coach, told his players today that only one-half of their season was over, even though they already have played six of the seven games on the schedule.

LUTON, England, Nov. 6 The shopping streets of this factory town 30 miles northwest of London were crowded today, but scarcely anyone expressed an interest in what concerned the visitor: tomorrow's by-election.
Wall Street observers took a fairly confident long-term view of the stock market yesterday despite the sharp sell-off triggered by an Election Day increase in marlin requirements.
The physical mishandling of prisoners by the police in New York County during interrogations is waning, according to a Legal Aid Society lawyer.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6 Private oil companies were warned today that the Government was prepared to curtail their activities further.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--A compromise college aid bill cleared the House with ease today, but it still faces a final and more difficult hurdle in the Senate.
TOKYO, Nov. 5--The "New York Look" was introduced here yesterday before an audience of Japanese and foreign notables and immediately caused a wave of excitement in the Japanese fashion world.
The New York City school system is planning to ask for $23.5 million for school repairs next year $5 million more than it received this year.
LONDON, Nov. 6 Dr. Frederick Everard Zeuner, an archeologist and an authority on the age of the earth, died last night in a hospital here.
ALBANY, Nov. 6.(AP) New York City, fighting a proposed rate increase by thee Consolidated Edison Company, obtained a court order today in a move to examine the company's financial figures.
The City Housing Authority asked the Civil Court yesterday to order Assemblyman Carlos M. Rios to move out of a public housing project because his income had exceeded the permissible limit.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 6 (AP) Ralph Lowe's Big Raff, carrying Robert McCurdy, an apprentice, to his third victory of the day, splashed to a narrow triumph in the rain at Garden State Park today. McCurdy scored his fourth victory in the next race, riding Tilmar.
A decline of 682,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Deputy Secretary of Defense Roswell L. Gilpatric said today that the economic impact of defense programs could be handled without serious over-all economic disruption.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The United States protested to the Soviet Union today against the detention of a Berlinbound military convoy but refused to argue with Premier Khrushchev about who had won the latest autobahn confrontation.

John Moors Cabot, former United States Ambassador to Colombia and Brazil and former Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said last night that the last 25 years "have been a period of distinct retrogression in inter-American relations."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP)-The tie-up of Canadian vessels in Chicago continued today. Four ships axe affected here. Others are being picketed elsewhere.

MINEOLA, Nov. 6--Republicans remained in solid control of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today despite the election of a Democratic Supervisor in the Town of Oyster Bay yesterday for the first time in more than 30 years.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6 The thin margin by which Edward T. Breathitt won the governorship appeared to spell trouble today for Kentucky Democrats in next year's election.
MAJ. GEN. JAMES HILLIARD POLK, the United States commandant in Berlin, who said yesterday that his troops were "ready for any type of incident," is a collateral descendant of James K. Polk, States.

BELGRADE, Nov. 6 Borba, the newspaper of the Yugoslav League of Communists, commented warmly today on recent remarks of George F. Kennan, the former United States Ambassador to Belgrade, attacking members of Congress who sought to alter this country's trading status with Washington.

After eight years of peace, progress and prosperity, Greece has been plunged into political uncertainty as a result of an election upset which toppled the ruling National Radical Union patty of Constantine Caramanlis but failed to give a majority to the victor.
LONDON, Nov. 6 Sheffield's two top police officers were suspended today as a result of a Government inquiry into brutality in the force they headed

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 Political analysts came up with little more than a headache today in projecting future voting trends from the returns in the municipal election here yesterday.

WHEN the Robert Scullys-entertain in their Manhattan home, and they do, so on the average of twice a month, the food is often Austrian. Mrs. Scully, a handsome young woman, is a splendid cook, Viennese by birth.

MRS. WALTER CALLEY of Asheville, N. C., a bridge player of 68 years' standing, was 91 years old yesterday. Mrs. Calley's distinction in bridge is not so much her age, but that she has a favorite suit, clubs.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 6 United States trade officals here estimated today that American grain exports of about $400,000,000 a year were at stake in the European Common Market's new agricultural plan.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 Governor Rockefeller will announce his entry into the race for the Republican nomination for President in a statement at the Capitol tomorrow at 8:30 A.M.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board's efforts to curb what it considers the dangernusly fast growth of a number of savings and loan associa tions points up some key questions about Government regulation of business.

Morocco's chief delegate at the United Nations accused President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic yesterday of having exploited the Moroccan-Algerian border dispute to interfere in North African affairs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Cuba was reported tonight to be preparing to release 19 refugees seized by Cuban marines last August in a raid, on Anguilla Cay, a British islet in the Bahamas.
